Subsection Title: IMPORTANT: You must read the following before continuing. The following applies to the preliminary

In accessing the offering memorandum, you agree to be bound by the following terms and conditions, including any modifications to them any time you receive any information from us as a result of such access. NOTHING IN THIS ELECTRONIC TRANSMISSION CONSTITUTES AN OFFER OF SECURITIES FOR SALE IN ANY JURISDICTION WHERE IT IS UNLAWFUL TO DO SO. THE SECURITIES HAVE NOT BEEN, AND WILL NOT BE, REGISTERED UNDER THE US SECURITIES ACT OR THE SECURITIES LAWS OF ANY STATE OF THE UNITED STATES OR ANY OTHER JURISDICTION AND THE SECURITIES MAY NOT BE OFFERED OR SOLD WITHIN THE UNITED STATES EXCEPT PURSUANT TO AN EXEMPTION FROM, OR IN A TRANSACTION NOT SUBJECT TO, THE REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS OF THE US SECURITIES ACT AND APPLICABLE STATE OR LOCAL SECURITIES LAWS. Confirmation of your representation:** In order to be eligible to view the offering memorandum or make an investment decision with respect to the securities described therein, investors must be either (1) QIBs or (2) persons who are outside of the United States in an offshore transaction in reliance on Regulation S; provided that investors resident in a Member State of the EEA or the United Kingdom are not retail investors (as defined herein). The offering memorandum is being sent at your request. By accepting the e-mail and accessing the offering memorandum, you shall be deemed to have represented to us and each of the Initial Purchasers (as defined in the attached offering memorandum) that: 1. you consent to delivery of such offering memorandum by electronic transmission; 2. either: (a) you and any customers you represent are QIBs; or (b) (i) you and any customers you represent are outside the United States and (ii) the email address that you gave us and to which the Offering Memorandum has been delivered is not located in the United States, its territories and possessions (including Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, Wake Island and the Northern Mariana Islands), any state of the United States or the District of Columbia; and 3. if you are resident in a Member State of the EEA or the United Kingdom, you are not a retail investor. ----- Prospective purchasers that are QIBs are hereby notified that the seller of the securities will be relying on the exemption from the provisions of Section 5 of the US Securities Act pursuant to Rule 144A. You are reminded that the offering memorandum has been delivered to you on the basis that you are a person into whose possession the offering memorandum may be lawfully delivered in accordance with the laws of the jurisdiction in which you are located and you may not, nor are you authorized to, deliver the offering memorandum to any other person. The materials relating to the offering do not constitute, and may not be used in connection with, an offer or solicitation in any place where offers or solicitations are not permitted by law. If a jurisdiction requires that the offering be made by a licensed broker or dealer and the initial purchasers or any affiliate of the initial purchasers is a licensed broker or dealer in that jurisdiction, the offering shall be deemed to be made by the initial purchasers or such affiliate on behalf of the issuers in such jurisdiction. Under no circumstances shall the offering memorandum constitute an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy nor shall there be any sale of these securities in any jurisdiction in which such offer, solicitation or sale would be unlawful. The offering memorandum is not being distributed by, nor has it been approved for the purposes of section 21 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 as amended (the “FSMA”) by, a person authorized under the FSMA. The offering memorandum is only being distributed to and is only directed at persons who (i) are outside the United Kingdom, (ii) have professional experience in matters relating to investments (being investment professionals falling within Article 19(5) of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Financial Promotion) Order 2005, as amended (the “Financial Promotion Order”)), (iii) fall within Article 49(2)(a) to (d) (“high net worth companies, unincorporated associations, etc.”) of the Financial Promotion Order, or (iv) to the extent that doing so does not prejudice the lawful distribution of the offering memorandum to the foregoing, are persons to whom an invitation or inducement to engage in investment activity (within the meaning of section 21 of the FSMA) in connection with the issue or sale of any securities may otherwise lawfully be communicated or caused to be communicated (all such persons together being referred to as “relevant persons”). Accordingly, by accepting delivery of this offering memorandum, the recipient warrants and acknowledges that it is such a relevant person. The offering memorandum is directed only at relevant persons and must not be acted or relied upon by persons who are not relevant persons. Any investment or investment activity to which this offering memorandum relates is available only to relevant persons and will be engaged in only with relevant persons. The offering memorandum has been sent to you in an electronic form. You are reminded that documents transmitted via this medium may be altered or changed during the process of electronic transmission and consequently neither the initial purchasers, nor any person who controls the initial purchasers, nor any of their respective directors, officers, employees, agents or affiliates, accepts any liability or responsibility whatsoever in respect of any difference between the offering memorandum distributed to you in electronic format and the hard copy version available to you on request from the initial purchaser.

Subsection Title: UK MiFIR Product Governance / Professional Investors and ECPs Only Target Market
Subsubsection Text: Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer’s product approval process, the target market assessment in respect of the Notes has led to the conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is eligible counterparties, as defined in the FCA Handbook Conduct of Business Sourcebook (“COBS”), and professional clients, as defined in Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (“UK MiFIR”); and (ii) all channels for distribution of the Notes to eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending the Notes (a “distributor”) should take into consideration the manufacturers’ target market assessment; however, a distributor subject to the FCA Handbook Intervention and Product Governance Sourcebook (the “UK MiFIR Product Governance

Subsection Title: Rules”) is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of the Notes (by either adopting
Subsubsection Text: or refining the manufacturers’ target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

Subsection Title: Prohibition of Sales to EEA Retail Investors
Subsubsection Text: The securities described in the attached offering memorandum are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the EEA. For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of Directive 2014/65/EU (as amended, “MiFID II”) II, (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive 2016/97/EU (as amended, the “Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer would not ----- qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II, or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 (as amended, the “Prospectus Regulation”). Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended, the “PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the securities or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the securities or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation. The attached offering memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of securities in any Member State of the EEA that is subject to the Prospectus Regulation will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the securities.

Subsection Title: Prohibition of Sales to UK Retail Investors
Subsubsection Text: The securities are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the United Kingdom (the “UK”). For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 2017/565 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (as amended, the “EUWA”); (ii) a customer within the meaning of the provisions of the FSMA and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement Directive (EU) 2016/97, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA; or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in Article 2 of Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA. Consequently, no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (as amended, the “UK PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the UK has been prepared and, therefore, offering or selling the securities or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the UK may be unlawful under the UK PRIIPs Regulation. The attached offering memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of the securities in the UK will be made pursuant to an exemption under Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA (as amended, the “UK Prospectus Regulation”) from a requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of securities. The attached offering memorandum is not a prospectus for the purpose of the UK Prospectus Regulation. ----- **SUBJECT TO COMPLETION—DATED OCTOBER 4, 2021 CONFIDENTIAL PRELIMINARY OFFERING MEMORANDUM** ### Maison FinCo plc
_Guaranteed on a senior secured basis by Maison BidCo Limited_

Section Title: NOT FOR GENERAL DISTRIBUTION IN THE UNITED STATES
Subsubsection Text: Maison FinCo plc, a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales (the “Issuer”), is hereby offering £275.0 million aggregate principal amount of its      % Senior Secured Notes due 2027 (the “Notes”). The Issuer is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of Maison BidCo Limited, a private limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales (the “Company”). The Notes will be issued pursuant to an indenture (the “Indenture”) to be dated on or around          , 2021 (the “Issue Date”). The offering of the Notes is referred to herein as the “Offering.” The gross proceeds of the Offering will be on-lent to the Company. In turn, the Company will use the proceeds therefrom, together with certain equity contributions, to finance the acquisition (the “Acquisition”) of Keystone TopCo Limited (the “Target”), including the repayment of the Existing Target Indebtedness (as defined herein) (the “Refinancing” and, together with the Acquisition and the Offering, the “Transactions”). The Notes will bear interest at the rate of      % per annum, payable semi-annually in arrear on           and           of each year, commencing on          , 2022. The Notes will mature on          , 2027. At any time on or after          , 2023, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or part of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in this preliminary offering memorandum (the “Offering Memorandum”). Prior to          , 2023, the Issuer may redeem, at its option, all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium, as described in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, prior to          , 2023, the Issuer may also redeem, at its option, up to 40% of the original principal amount of the Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional Notes (as defined herein)) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at the redemption price set forth in this Offering Memorandum, if at least 50% of the original principal amount of the Notes (including the original principal amount of any Additional Notes) remains outstanding. Prior to          , 2023, the Issuer may redeem, during each twelve-month period commencing with the Issue Date, up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes originally issued (including the original principal amount of any Additional Notes) at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any. The Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law. Upon the occurrence of certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase all of the outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any. However, a change of control will be deemed not to have occurred if a specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.” Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, to the extent the Acquisition will not complete on or shortly after the Issue Date, the Initial Purchasers (as defined herein) will deposit the gross proceeds of the Notes into a segregated escrow account (the “Escrow Account”) in the name of the Issuer but controlled by the Escrow Agent (as defined herein) pending release to consummate of the Acquisition, and charged on a first-ranking basis in favor of the Trustee (as defined herein) on behalf of the holders of the Notes. The release of the escrow proceeds will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within three Business Days). The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including, among others, certain regulatory approvals and the performance of certain closing actions. If the conditions to the release of the escrow proceeds have not been satisfied on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date (as defined herein) or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding such special mandatory redemption date. The Notes will be general senior secured obligations of the Issuer, and on the Issue Date, will initially be guaranteed on a senior basis (the “Issue Date Guarantee”) by the Company. Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection requirements, the Notes and the Issue Date Guarantee will be secured on a first priority basis on the Issue Date by (i) a charge over all of the shares in the Company on a third party limited recourse basis granted by Maison Hold Limited (“Holdco”); (ii) an assignment over structural intercompany receivables owing by the Company to Holdco; (iii) a charge over all of the shares in the Issuer granted by the Company; (iv) an English law debenture granted by the Company with respect to its material bank accounts and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets; and (v) an English law debenture granted by the Issuer with respect to its material bank accounts and any structural intercompany receivables owed to it by the Company and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets (collectively, the “Issue Date Collateral”). Within 150 days of the Completion Date (the “Post-Closing Date”), the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis (the “Post-Closing Guarantees” and, together with the Issue Date Guarantees, the “Notes **Guarantees”) by each of Keepmoat Limited, Keepmoat Homes Limited and M.C.I. Developments Limited (the “Post-Closing Guarantors” and, each of them, a “Post-Closing Guarantor” and, together with the Company, the “Guarantors”). Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection requirements, within 10 Business Days of the Completion Date, the Notes or the Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by a charge over all of the shares in the Target granted by the Company and an assignment over any structural intercompany receivables owing by the Target to the Company, and on or about the Post-Closing Date, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by (i) a charge over all of the shares in Keepmoat Homes Limited granted by Keepmoat Limited; (ii) a charge over all of the shares in M.C.I. Developments Limited granted by Keepmoat Homes Limited; and (iii) an English law debenture granted by each Post-Closing Guarantor over its material bank accounts and any structural intercompany receivables owed to it and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets in each case, subject to customary limitations and exceptions (collectively, the “Post-Closing Collateral” and, together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). See “Description of the Notes—Security” and “Description of the Notes—Notes _Guarantees.”_ The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes or the Notes Guarantees, as applicable, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (as defined herein), and will rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes. The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be effectively subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer and the Guarantors that is secured by property or assets that do not also secure the Notes and the Notes Guarantees or that are secured by a first priority fixed charge on property or assets that secure the Notes by way of a floating charge, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness. The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness and other liabilities of subsidiaries of the Company that do not provide Guarantees. The Notes Guarantees may be released in certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and our Structure,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—Security.” The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the security interests over the Collateral will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.” The property and assets that will secure the Notes and the Notes Guarantees thereof will also secure the Revolving Credit Facility on a first-ranking and pari passu basis. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), in the event of a distressed disposal of, or an enforcement of the security interests over, the Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain other future indebtedness permitted under the Indenture to be secured in priority to the Notes have been repaid in full. The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the security interests and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and Security Interests and Certain _Insolvency Law Considerations.” The Collateral and the Notes Guarantees may be released in certain circumstances._ There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The Exchange is not a regulated market pursuant to the provisions of Directive 2014/65/EU on markets in financial instruments, as amended.

Any investor or potential investor in the European Economic Area (the “EEA”) or in the United Kingdom should not base any investment decision relating to the Notes on the information contained in this Offering Memorandum after publication of the listing particulars and should refer instead to those listing particulars.

IN CONNECTION WITH THE OFFERING OF THE NOTES, CREDIT SUISSE INTERNATIONAL OR ONE OF ITS AFFILIATES (THE “STABILIZING MANAGER”) MAY OVER-ALLOT THE NOTES OR EFFECT TRANSACTIONS WITH A VIEW TO SUPPORTING THE MARKET PRICE OF THE NOTES DURING THE STABILIZATION PERIOD AT A LEVEL HIGHER THAN THAT WHICH MIGHT OTHERWISE PREVAIL. HOWEVER, STABILIZATION ACTION MAY NOT NECESSARILY OCCUR. ANY STABILIZATION ACTION MAY BEGIN ON OR AFTER THE DATE ON WHICH ADEQUATE PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF THE TERMS OF THE OFFER OF THE NOTES IS MADE AND, IF BEGUN, MAY BE ENDED AT ANY TIME, BUT IT MUST END NO LATER THAN 30 DAYS AFTER THE ISSUE DATE OF THE NOTES, OR NO LATER THAN 60 DAYS AFTER THE DATE OF ALLOTMENT OF THE NOTES, WHICHEVER IS THE EARLIER. ANY STABILIZATION ACTION OR OVER-ALLOTMENT MUST BE CONDUCTED BY THE RELEVANT STABILIZING MANAGER (OR PERSONS ACTING ON ITS BEHALF) IN ACCORDANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE LAWS AND RULES.

Section Title: NOTICE TO INVESTORS IN THE UNITED STATES

Prospective investors are hereby notified that the sellers of the Notes and the Notes Guarantees may be relying on the exemption from the provisions of Section 5 of the U.S. Securities Act provided by Rule 144A. Section Title: NOTICE TO INVESTORS IN THE UNITED KINGDOM
Subsection Title: Prohibition of Sales to UK Retail Investors
Subsubsection Text: Each Initial Purchaser has represented and agreed that it has not offered, sold or otherwise made available and will not offer, sell or otherwise make available any Notes to any retail investor in the United Kingdom. For these purposes: (a) the expression “retail investor” means a person who is one (or more) of the following: (i) a retail client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2 of Regulation (EU) No 2017/565 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (as amended, the “EUWA”); or (ii) a customer within the meaning of the provisions of the FSMA and any rules or regulations made under the FSMA to implement Directive (EU) 2016/97, where that customer would not qualify as a professional client, as defined in point (8) of Article 2(1) of Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA; or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in Article 2 of the UK Prospectus Regulation; and (b) the expression an **offer includes the communication in any form and by any means of sufficient information on the terms of the offer and the Notes to be offered so as to enable an investor to decide to purchase or subscribe for the Notes and the expression “UK Prospectus Regulation” means Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 as it forms part of domestic law by virtue of the EUWA, as amended. This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in the United Kingdom will be made pursuant to an exemption under the UK Prospectus Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes.

Section Title: NOTICE TO CERTAIN EUROPEAN ECONOMIC AREA INVESTORS
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the European Economic Area. For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II, (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive 2016/97/EC (as amended, the “Insurance Distribution

The Notes may be sold only to purchasers purchasing, or deemed to be purchasing, as principal that are accredited investors, as defined in National Instrument 45-106 Prospectus Exemptions or subsection 73.3(1) of the _Securities Act_ (Ontario), and are permitted clients, as defined in National Instrument 31-103 _Registration _Requirements, Exemptions and Ongoing Registrant Obligations. Any resale of the Notes acquired by a Canadian_ v ----- purchaser in the Offering must be made in accordance with applicable Canadian securities laws, which may vary depending on the relevant jurisdiction, and which may require resales to be made in accordance with Canadian prospectus requirements, a statutory exemption from the prospectus requirements, in a transaction exempt from the prospectus requirements or otherwise under a discretionary exemption from the prospectus requirements granted by the applicable local Canadian securities regulatory authority. These resale restrictions may under certain circumstances apply to resales of the Notes outside of Canada. Securities legislation in certain provinces or territories of Canada may provide a purchaser with remedies for rescission or damages if this Offering Memorandum (including any amendment thereto) contains a misrepresentation, provided that the remedies for rescission or damages are exercised by the purchaser within the time limit prescribed by the securities legislation of the purchaser’s province or territory. The purchaser should refer to any applicable provisions of the securities legislation of the purchaser’s province or territory for particulars of these rights or consult with a legal advisor. Pursuant to section 3A.3 of National Instrument 33-105 Underwriting Conflicts (“NI 33-105”), the Initial Purchasers are not required to comply with the disclosure requirements of NI 33-105 regarding underwriter conflicts of interest in connection with this Offering. Each purchaser of the Notes in Canada hereby agrees that it is the purchaser’s express wish that all documents evidencing or relating in any way to the sale of the Notes be drafted in the English language only. soient rédigés uniquement en anglais._ Upon receipt of this offering memorandum, each Canadian purchaser hereby confirms that it has expressly requested that all documents evidencing or relating in any way to the sale of the Notes described herein (including for greater certainty any purchase confirmation or any notice) be drawn up in the English language only. _Par la réception de ce document, décrites aux présentes (incluant, pour plus de certitude, toute confirmation d’achat ou tout avis) soient rédigés en anglais seulement._ Each prospective Canadian purchaser hereby acknowledges that: In this Offering Memorandum, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the markets in which we operate and compete. Unless otherwise indicated, we have generally obtained all information regarding market, market size, growth rate, development, trends and competitive position and other industry data pertaining to our business contained in this Offering Memorandum from industry publications, surveys or studies conducted by third-party sources, as well as internal surveys and estimates and publicly available information. Some of the information herein has also been extrapolated from market data, reports, surveys and studies using our experience and internal estimates. Elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, statements regarding the industry in which we operate, our position in this industry, the size of certain markets are based solely on our experience, internal studies, estimates and surveys, and our own investigation of market conditions. We believe that the sources of such information in this Offering Memorandum are reliable, but there can be no assurance that vi ----- any of these assumptions is accurate or correctly reflects our position in our industry, and none of our internal surveys or information has been verified by any independent sources. Industry and consultant publications and forecasts generally state that the information they contain has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. While we believe that each of the studies and publications we have used is reliable, neither we nor the Initial Purchasers have independently verified the data that were extracted or derived from these industry and consultant publications or reports and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. Market data and statistics are inherently uncertain and not necessarily reflective of actual market conditions. Such statistics are based on market research, which itself is based on sampling and subjective judgments by both the researchers and the respondents, including judgments about what types of products and transactions should be included in the relevant market. In addition, market data and statistics are often based on various assumptions. We cannot assure you that any of these assumptions are accurate or correctly reflect our position in the industry, and none of our internal surveys or information have or has been verified by any independent sources. While we are not aware of any misstatements regarding the industry or similar data presented herein, such data involve risks and uncertainties and are subject to change based on various factors, including those discussed under “Risk Factors.” As far as we are aware and have been able to ascertain from information published by such third parties, no facts have been omitted that would render the reproduced information inaccurate or misleading. Neither we nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation as to the accuracy or completeness of any such information in this Offering Memorandum.

We own or have rights to certain trademarks or trade names that we use in conjunction with the operation of our businesses. Each trademark or trade name of any other company appearing in this Offering Memorandum belongs to its holder. We own and have the right to use the trade names “Keepmoat,” “Keepmoat Homes” and the Keepmoat Homes logo among others. Solely for convenience, the trademarks, trade names and copyrights referred to in this Offering Memorandum are often listed without the TM and [©] symbols, but we will assert, to the fullest extent under applicable law, our rights to these trademarks and trade names.

Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION The Issuer and the Company
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a public limited liability company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales on September 7, 2021 for the purpose of issuing the Notes offered hereby and is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company. The Issuer conducts no business operations of its own and, as of the Issue Date, will have no material assets and its only material liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness (including its obligations under the Notes) and, as of the Completion Date, its only material assets will be its rights and claims under the Proceeds Loan. The Issuer has not engaged in any activities other than those related to its formation and the issuance of the Notes. The Company was incorporated on July 23, 2021 for the purposes of facilitating the Transactions. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Company has no material assets or liabilities, does not have any revenue generating activities of its own and has not engaged in actions other than those related to its incorporation and in preparation of the Transactions. As a result, no historical information of the Company is included in this Offering Memorandum. The Target has not prepared consolidated financial information and operates its business through Keystone Midco Limited and its subsidiaries. Because of the limited historical financial information available for the Issuer, the Company and the Target, unless otherwise indicated, the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is the historical consolidated financial information of the KM Group, which is generally representative of the financial information of the Group. See “—Differences Between the Financial Statements of _the Target and the KM Group.”_ Keystone Midco Limited was formed under the laws of England and Wales on May 21, 2014. For more information about our corporate structure, see “Summary Corporate and Financing Structure,” “Our Business” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: The consolidated administrative expenses of the Target were £96.9 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021, whereas the administrative expenses of the KM Group were £89.8 million for the same period. The Target’s consolidated income statement includes certain expenses that are recognized and affect cash flows at the Target consolidated level only, and which are not recognized at the KM Group level because they are not incurred within the KM Group. These expenses include an exit related Long Term Incentive Plan (“LTIP”) charge of £6.9 million which has been classified as exceptional. The Target operates an exit related LTIP, open to our executive directors and senior management with awards being made at the discretion of the board of directors of the Target. Awards under the plan are subject to being in service and an increase in the value of the group up to an exit event occurring.

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: The Target recorded finance income of £1.1 million and finance expense of £20.5 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021, whereas the KM Group recorded finance income of £0.5 million and finance expense of £19.6 million for the same period, respectively. The difference was due to additional interest expense of £0.9 million (in respect of a loan granted by Keystone JVco Limited to the Target in the amount of £7.5 million) and interest income of £0.6 million (in respect of preference shares issued by Keystone Midco Limited to the Target) recognized by the Target. The latter transaction is eliminated in the Target consolidation. x -----

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: The Target and the KM Group account for liabilities recorded on their respective consolidated statements of financial position in the same manner. As of July 31, 2021, the KM Group’s external debt for bank loans, finance leases and loans from others amounted to £178.8 million. The Target’s external debt of £187.7 million also includes the £7.5 million loan from Keystone JVco Limited to the Target, with interest accrued thereon of £1.4 million.

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: As of July 31, 2021, the consolidated equity of the Target was £9 million less than the consolidated equity of the KM Group. This was caused by certain differences recorded in the nine months ended July 31, 2021, as well as in past reporting periods, relating to variances in annual profit/(loss) results between the Target and the KM Group, including notably the £6.9 million LTIP charge in the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and a £2.0 million LTIP charge in previous periods.

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: As of July 31, 2021, the Target recognized an intercompany receivable of £8.7 million (primarily representing a £3.5 million investment in 12% preference shares issued by Keystone Midco Limited and £4.2 million of dividends owed thereon) as well as an intercompany payable of £0.5 million (representing a balance owed to Keepmoat Limited).

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: As of July 31, 2021, the Target also recognized a share-based payment liability of £7.9 million, an associated employer tax liability of £1.1 million in respect of the LTIP and accruals of £0.2 million.

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: As of July 31, 2021, the Target recognized a deferred tax asset of £0.4 million related to the LTIP liability. The KM Group recognizes a net deferred tax asset of £7.9 million.

Subsection Title: Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group
Subsubsection Text: The Target has not prepared consolidated financial information and operates its business through the KM Group. The financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the KM Group, unless otherwise indicated. As of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2021, the total operating revenue, operating profit, total assets and total (current and non-current) liabilities of the Target represented 100%, 47%, 100% and 102% of that of the KM Group, respectively.

Subsection Title: Financial Statements and Other Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: This Offering Memorandum also includes unaudited consolidated pro forma financial information which have been adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Transactions (i) on as adjusted cash interest expense as if the Transactions had been completed on August 1, 2020, and (ii) on as adjusted total debt, as adjusted total senior secured net debt and as adjusted net debt as if the Transactions had been completed on July 31, 2021. The pro _forma financial information is for informational purposes only and is not intended to represent or to be indicative_ of the consolidated results of operations or financial position we would have reported, had the Transactions been completed as of (i) August 1, 2020 for the purposes of the calculation of as adjusted cash interest expense and (ii) July 31, 2021 for purposes of the calculation of as adjusted total debt, as adjusted total senior secured net debt and as adjusted net debt, nor does such pro forma financial information purport to project as adjusted total debt, as adjusted total senior secured net debt, as adjusted net debt and as adjusted cash interest expense at any future date. xii ----- The _pro forma adjustments are based upon available information and certain assumptions that we believe are reasonable but may differ materially from actual amounts.

Subsection Title: Financial Statements and Other Financial Information
Subsubsection Text: In 2018, the KM Group changed its financial year end from March 31 to October 31. As a result, the KM Group’s financial year ended on October 31 for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020, and on March 31 for the financial year ended March 31, 2018. In addition, in connection with the change in financial year, the KM Group presented audited financial statements as of and for the seven months ended October 31, 2018. This Offering Memorandum includes or derives financial information from the following: - the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the financial year ended October 31, 2020, prepared in accordance with international accounting standards; - the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the financial year ended October 31, 2019, prepared in accordance IFRS (as defined herein); - the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the seven months ended October 31, 2018, prepared in accordance with IFRS; - the audited consolidated financial statements for the financial year ended March 31, 2018, prepared in accordance with IFRS; and - the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements as of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2021, prepared in accordance with IAS 34, including comparative information for the nine months ended July 31, 2020, which is prepared in accordance with International Accounting Standard (“IAS”) 34, Interim Financial Reporting. The results of operations for prior years or interim periods are not necessarily indicative of results to be expected for the full year or any future period. xi ----- The financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 has been derived from the restated comparative information contained in the audited financial statements for the year ended October 31, 2018 as restated to give effect to IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with _Customers). See note 26 to the financial statements for the seven months ended October 31, 2018 and_ “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers).” In accordance with guidance issued by The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, the independent auditor’s reports included in (i) the audited consolidated financial statements as of for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020; (ii); the audited consolidated financial statements as of for the seven months ended October 31, 2018; and (iii) the audited consolidated financial statements as of for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 each state that they were prepared for and only for the members of Keystone Midco Limited as a body in accordance with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act of 2006 and for no other purpose; and, to the fullest extent permitted by law, the independent auditor does not accept or assume responsibility for any other purpose or to anyone other than Keystone Midco Limited and its members as a body for its audit work or the opinions it has formed, save where expressly agreed by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP’s prior consent in writing. The independent auditor’s reports for the KM Group for the financial years ended October 31, 2020 and 2019 are included on pages F-58 and F-132, respectively, of this Offering Memorandum. The independent auditor’s report for the KM Group for the seven months ended October 31, 2018 is included on page F-195 of this Offering Memorandum. The independent auditor’s report for the KM Group for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 is included on page F-270 of this Offering Memorandum. See “Independent Auditor” for a description of the reports of the independent auditor of the Company. Investors in the Notes should understand that in making these statements, the independent auditor confirmed that it does not accept or assume any liability to parties (such as the purchasers of the Notes) other than to the Keystone Midco Limited and its members as a body with respect to the report and to the independent auditor’s audit work and opinions. The SEC would not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection with an offering of securities registered under the US Securities Act or in a report filed under the US Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the “US Exchange Act”). If a US court (or any other court) were to give effect to such limiting language, the recourse that investors in the Notes may have against the independent auditor based on its report or the audited consolidated financial statements to which it relates could be limited. In addition, we have included in this Offering Memorandum unaudited consolidated financial information of the KM Group for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, which has been calculated by adding the unaudited results of operations of the KM Group for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 to the audited results of operations of the KM Group for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and then subtracting the unaudited results of operations of the KM Group for the nine months ended July 31, 2020. The unaudited financial information for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 has been prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of our results of operations for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. We have not included financial information prepared in accordance with US GAAP in this Offering Memorandum. As of and for (i) the financial year ended October 31, 2019 and 2020; (ii) the seven months ended October 31, 2018; and (iii) the financial year ended March 31, 2018, our consolidated financial statements were prepared in accordance with IFRS, which differs in certain significant respects from US GAAP. In making an investment decision, you should rely upon your own examination of the terms of the Offering and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. You should consult your own professional advisors for an understanding of the differences between IFRS and US GAAP, and how those differences could affect the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum.

This Offering Memorandum contains certain non-IFRS financial measures and ratios, including Contribution, Adjusted EBIT, Adjusted EBIT margin, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Normalized EBITDA, gross margin, Free Cash Flow, free cash flow conversion, ROCE, tangible net operating asset value, tangible net asset value, as adjusted total debt, as adjusted total senior secured net debt, as adjusted net debt and as adjusted cash interest expense (collectively, “Non-IFRS Measures”) that are not required by, or presented in accordance with IFRS or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction. - “Contribution” represents gross profit adjusted for exceptional items within cost of sales, amortization of acquisition related intangible assets and acquisition fair value adjustments. - “Adjusted EBIT” represents operating profit/(loss) before exceptional items, shareholder monitoring fees, amortization of acquisition intangible assets, acquisition fair value adjustments to inventory and impairment losses of investments in associated companies. - “Adjusted EBIT margin” represents Adjusted EBIT divided by Group revenue. - “Adjusted EBITDA” represents operating profit/(loss) before exceptional items, shareholder monitoring fees, amortization of acquisition intangible assets, acquisition fair value adjustments to inventory, impairment losses of investments in associated companies, depreciation, depreciation of right-of-use assets and amortization of computer software. - “Adjusted EBITDA margin” represents Adjusted EBITDA divided by Group revenue. - “Normalized EBITDA” for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 has been calculated by subtracting the Adjusted EBITDA presented in our management accounts for each of the months ending August 31, September 30 and October 31, 2020 (with certain adjustments as necessary to present on a basis comparable to the Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021) (the “October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA”) from the Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 and then adding the Adjusted EBITDA presented in our management accounts for each of the months ending August 31, September 30 and October 31, 2019 (the “October 2019 Management Adjusted EBITDA”), as further described in footnote 9 under “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data—Other _Financial Information.” We believe that Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July_ 31, 2021 is a measure that assists in understanding our performance during a period impacted by the market disruption caused by COVID-19 by substituting the October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA for the October 2019 Management Adjusted EBITDA, comprising the months of our last calendar equivalent financial quarter prior to the market disruption caused by COVID-19. Our operations during the three months ended October 31, 2020 were negatively impacted following the government imposed lockdown and the subsequent delayed ramp up on home construction and sales, before resuming normalized operations during the three month period ended January 31, 2021. As a result, we believe Normalized EBITDA is more representative of our Adjusted EBITDA performance for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 and takes into account, on a highly illustrative basis, the cyclicality of our business. Normalized EBITDA presented herein is for informational purposes only. Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 might not represent what our Adjusted EBITDA would have been for the same period had the confinement measures not been implemented. In particular, Normalized EBITDA does not (i) give effect to any other event, favorable or unfavorable, that happened or could have happened during the three months ended October 31, 2020, other than the events directly related to the COVID-19 pandemic or (ii) adjust for the positive or negative effect of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic during the nine months ended July 31, 2021. The information has been prepared on the basis of certain assumptions as described herein but such assumptions do not take into account all conceivable variables and are therefore inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. In addition, such assumptions may not give an accurate or complete picture of the KM Group’s financial condition or results of operations, may not be comparable to the KM Group’s consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum and undue reliance should not be placed xiii ----- upon them when evaluating an investment decision. Normalized EBITDA has been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, the KM Group’s management, and has been prepared solely for the purposes of this Offering Memorandum. It is not necessarily indicative of our results of operations for any future period, is not prepared in the ordinary course by the Issuer, has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. - “gross margin” represents Contribution divided by Group revenue. - “Free Cash Flow” represents operating cash flow less capital expenditures and investments. - “free cash flow conversion” represents Free Cash Flow as a percentage of Adjusted EBITDA. - “tangible net operating asset value” represents net assets adjusted for goodwill, acquisition intangible assets, tax, cash, loans and borrowings, lease assets and liabilities and pension assets/liabilities. - “Adjusted tangible net asset value” represents tangible net operating asset value less net debt and net other non-operating items. - “ROCE,” or return on capital employed, represents the Adjusted EBIT for the relevant twelve month period divided by the average of the opening and closing tangible net operating asset value, expressed as a percentage. We believe that ROCE is a meaningful measure of our profitability and cash generation for individual sites, regions and the business as a whole. We believe that ROCE is therefore helpful for understanding the performance of our business. - “as adjusted total debt” represents the total principal amount of debt as if the as if the Transactions had taken place on July 31, 2021. See “Capitalization.” As adjusted total debt excludes unamortized fees in respect of Existing Senior Term Facility and obligations of the KM Group under the Company PIK Loan. - “as adjusted net debt” represents as adjusted total debt, less the as adjusted cash and cash equivalents set forth in “Capitalization.” As adjusted net debt excludes unamortized fees in respect of Existing Senior Term Facility and obligations of the KM Group under the Company PIK Loan. - “as adjusted total senior secured net debt” represents the as adjusted total debt of the KM Group secured by a first-priority lien on the Collateral, excluding any liabilities secured by a fixed charge or mortgage on Collateral subject to a floating charge, less any cash and cash equivalents as set forth in “Capitalization.” The calculation of as adjusted total senior secured net debt assumes that the Revolving Credit Facility has not been drawn as of the Issue Date. - “as adjusted cash interest expense” represents the cash interest expense on as adjusted total debt as if the Transactions completed as of August 1, 2020. As adjusted cash interest expense excludes obligations of the KM Group under (i) the Company PIK Loan and (ii) all of our lease liabilities. - “Completions” represent the number of new build homes that we have sold over the applicable period. For private homes this is the number of legal completions during the period. For Registered Provider homes this represents the equivalent number of units sold, based on the proportion of work completed under a contract during the period. - “ASP” represents average selling price. - “Land pipeline plots” include secured and preferred developer plots. Secured plots means that land on which we have a contractual right, a conditionally exchanged contract to develop. Preferred developer plots means that land where we have been selected as the preferred developer or has won a bidding process, but contracts have not yet been exchanged. - “Asset Turn” is defined as Group Revenue divided by average opening and closing tangible net operating asset value. xiv ----- - “Gross Development Profit” represents gross profit adjusted for marketing costs and exceptional items within cost of sales. - “Gross Development Margin” represents Gross Development Profit divided by Group revenue. Our calculation of Gross Development Margin includes certain projections, estimates and assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. Gross Profit Margin is provided for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to reflect the current returns on any particular site or for the Group as a whole or the potential returns that could be achieved on any particular site or the Group as a whole. Our calculation of Gross Development Margin may not be comparable with similarly titled measures used by other companies. - “forward order book” represents the aggregate reserved position at any point in time, including secured positions with Registered Providers as well as private reservations by individuals. Our forward order book includes (i) plots that are contracted for but homes have yet to be completed on the lot and (ii) plot reservations for which contracts have yet to be exchanged. Where presented, unaudited consolidated financial information of the KM Group for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 is a Non-IFRS Measure. We believe that the presentation of Non-IFRS Measures may or could enhance investors understanding of our operating performance and our ability to service our debt. In addition, we believe that EBITDA-based measures are commonly used by investors. Our Non-IFRS Measures may not be comparable with similarly titled measures used by other companies. For example, our definition of Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA includes certain adjustments which some companies might not include in the definition of “adjusted EBITDA.” Our Adjusted EBITDA and related leverage and coverage ratios are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction and should not be considered substitutes to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction. Our definition of Normalized EBITDA includes adjustments which we feel are appropriate to reflect the negative impact on our performance following the market disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, though which may not be appropriate for other companies or industries. Our Non-IFRS Measures have important limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our results of operations as reported under IFRS. In addition, Adjusted EBITDA may be defined differently from the definition of “Consolidated EBITDA” under the Indenture. Some limitations of EBITDA-based measures include: - they do not reflect our cash expenditures, or future requirements, for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs; - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments, on our debts; - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and - amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and the Non-IFRS Measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; - they do not reflect the impact of certain cash charges resulting from matters we consider not to be indicative of our ongoing operations; and - other companies in our industry may calculate Non-IFRS Measures such as adjusted EBITDA differently than we do, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure. Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to use to invest in the growth of our business or as a measure of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. Accordingly, you should rely on our IFRS results, as applicable, and use these Non-IFRS Measures only in a supplemental manner to evaluate our performance. In respect of financial data set forth in the main body of this offering memorandum, a dash (“—”) signifies that the relevant figure is not available, while a zero (“0”) signifies that the relevant figure is available but has been rounded to zero. By contrast, no such differentiation has been made in respect of the financial data set forth in the financial information section of this offering memorandum beginning on page F-1. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) was issued in 2014 and was endorsed by the EU in 2016. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) establishes a comprehensive framework for determining whether, how much and when revenue is recognized. It replaces existing revenue recognition guidance, including IAS 18 (Revenue). IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) is effective for annual periods beginning on or after January 1, 2018, with early adoption permitted. We adopted IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) from April 1, 2018 in accordance with the fully retrospective transitional approach without using the practical expedients for completed contracts or for modified contracts. We have applied the expedient allowing both non-disclosure of the amount of the transaction price allocated to the remaining performance obligations, and an explanation of when it expects to recognize that amount as revenue for all reporting periods presented before the date of initial application. Under IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers), revenue is recognized based on indicators of control, rather than solely when risks and rewards are transferred. This can lead to differences in revenue recognition on certain sites, based on the specific contractual arrangements in place. The majority of our revenue and profit, including revenue from open market sales, continues to be recognized on legal completion. For those sites in respect of which stage payments are received from Registered Providers of housing, revenue is recognized based on stage of completion rather than on legal completion. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) also sets out the requirements for recognition of noncash consideration as revenue. Previously, where we entered into arrangements to provide housing to Registered Providers at below open market value in exchange for discounted land from partners, the associated housing unit revenue was recorded at open market value. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) does not permit this, as the exchange transaction (land discount from partner) is not received directly from the customer (the Registered Provider) and so does not meet the criteria of non-cash consideration. This change has the impact of reducing reported revenue. Accordingly, the revenue recognized in respect of these housing units will be equal to the cash consideration received from Registered Providers, with no open market value adjustment. There are a limited number of developments where the eventual buyer of the affordable units is the same entity as the land xvi ----- vendor. In these instances, the discount received represents non-cash consideration, which continues to be recognized as revenue. The financial information presented herein for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 has been derived from the restated comparative information contained in the audited financial statements for the year ended October 31, 2018 as restated to give effect to IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers).

Our consolidated financial statements are prepared and presented in accordance with IFRS. On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on November 9, 2017. IFRS 16 (Leases) replaced IAS 17 (Leases) and the related International Financial Reporting Interpretations Committee’s and the Standards Interpretation Committee’s interpretations, and results in almost all leases being recognized on the balance sheet, as the distinction between operating and finance leases is eliminated. Under the new standard, the lessee recognizes an asset (the right to use the leased asset) and a financial liability to pay lease payments. The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases. IFRS 16 (Leases) is effective for fiscal years commencing on or after January 1, 2019, with early adoption permitted if IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) has also been applied. We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) from November 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach. Under this approach, comparative information is not restated and the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 16 is recognized in retained earnings at the date of initial application. In particular, as a consequence of IFRS 16 (Leases) our total assets and liabilities are expected to increase as the right of use asset associated with leases and the corresponding liability, which were previously treated as operating leases, are recognized on the balance sheet. In addition, operating lease expenditure has been reclassified and split between depreciation and finance cost, and as a result, our EBITDA is expected to increase. Prior to November 1, 2019 we accounted for Leases under IAS 17 (Leases). As a result the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the seven months ended October 31, 2018 and as of and for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2018 are not directly comparable to our audited financial statements as of and for the fiscal year ended October 31, 2019 with respect to the treatment of leases. IFRS 16 (Leases) was effective for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. The impact of adopting IFRS 16 (Leases) for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was the recognition of right of use assets of £8.0 million and lease liabilities of £8.6 million on transition in respect of offices, company vehicles, site plant equipment and show homes. The impact on adjusted EBIT for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was £0.6 million. This information may not be indicative of the impact of the adoption of IFRS 16 (Leases) on our total assets, total liabilities and EBITDA for the next financial year or any future period. xvii -----

Important risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause these differences include, but are not limited to those relating to: - dependence on the UK housing market and impact of potential deterioration of the UK economy, brought about by uncertainty, loss of consumer confidence, higher interest rates, increasing unemployment or other factors, which could lead to decreased affordability, reduced demand for housing and falling house prices; vii ----- - changes in local or Government funds, loans, grants or subsidies, or changes to or the discontinuation of mortgage assistance schemes or equity loan schemes; - impact of the spread of COVID-19 on our operations as well as customers and suppliers and its ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry; - reduced funding and other changes to the operations of Local Authorities, Homes England, Registered Providers and housing associations with whom we maintain a strong relationship; - availability, cost, quality and location of land, and failure to identify and secure suitable land; - competitiveness of the UK home building market; - inability of our customers to procure a mortgage or other form of funding, or increased costs of financing, which could lead to decreased sales and reservations and the cancellation of sale contracts; - cyclical nature of the home building and constructions industries as well as fluctuations in the price and supply of materials; - uncertainty, disruption or other consequences of Brexit; - continued availability, viability and cost of subcontractors and other service providers; - compliance with and changes to a complex regulatory environment; - increases in total costs or adverse effects on our returns caused by difficulties and complications encountered in connection with the construction process; - major health and safety incidents cost due to potential liabilities and reputational damage; - effects on our results of operations due to seasonal effects; - impacts of local and national planning policies; - failure in our procedures, systems and internal controls, including with respect to due diligence and design; - limitations and uncertainties associated with the land contracts; - changes in privacy laws; - changes in tax law or uncertainties in the interpretation and application thereof and challenges to our tax treatment of certain matters; - inability to obtain additional surety bonds; - potential changes to our current legal regime regarding leasehold properties, including retrospective application of new laws or regulations; - decline of the net realizable value of our build work-in-progress and land; - potential environmental risks and liabilities, including liability under claims for damages as a result of use of hazardous materials, including asbestos; - failure to successfully implement our business strategy or engage in future activities where we have limited expertise; - failure to attract, develop and retain highly-skilled, competent people at all levels; - negative impact on our image and reputation; viii ----- - risk of construction defects; - Scottish referendum which votes for independence; - failure to fully realize the potential benefit of acquisitions, dispositions, investments in joint ventures, partnerships, and other strategic alternatives; - interruption or failure of, or cyber-attacks on, our IT systems and data protection systems; - natural disasters, terrorist attacks, war, sabotage, social unrest, corruption and other unforeseen events outside our control; - risks in connection with corporate and contractual joint ventures, other associated companies and special purpose vehicles; - impact of the weather and the effects of climate change; - dependency on the strength of our brands, trademarks and other intellectual property rights; - requirement to make up shortfalls to unfunded contractual promises which sit outside of pension legislation; - other risks associated with the Transactions, our indebtedness, the Notes and our capital structure; and - the other factors discussed in more detail under “Risk Factors.” The foregoing factors and others described under “Risk Factors” are not exhaustive.
