The following table sets forth, for the periods set forth below, the high, low, average and period end Bloomberg New York Composite Rate expressed as US dollars per £1.00. The Bloomberg New York Composite Rate is a “best market” calculation, in which, at any point in time, the bid rate is equal to the highest bid rate of all contributing bank indications and the ask rate is set to the lowest ask rate offered by these banks. The Bloomberg New York Composite Rate is a mid-value rate between the applied highest bid rate and the lowest ask rate. The rates may differ from the actual rates used in the preparation of the consolidated financial statements and other financial information appearing in this Offering Memorandum. None of the Issuer, the Guarantors or the Initial Purchasers represent that the US dollar amounts referred to below could be or could have been converted into pound sterling at any particular rate indicated or any other rate. In this Offering Memorandum, references to “£” and “pound sterling” are to the lawful currency of the United Kingdom, references to “$” and “US dollar” are to the lawful currency of the United States of America, and references to “euro” and “€” are to the single currency adopted by participating Member States of the European Union relating to Economic and Monetary Union. The average rate for a period means the average of the final daily Bloomberg New York Composite Rates during that period. On October 1, 2021, the exchange rate published by Bloomberg for transfers between US dollars and pound sterling was $1.3561 to £1.00.

We are one of the UK’s oldest and most experienced partnership housebuilders, with “5-Star Homebuilder” status awarded in 2021. We are focused on creating sustainable communities in places where people want to live, and we specialize in the delivery of affordable and high quality homes, principally targeted at first-time buyers. Headquartered in Doncaster, England, we operate across England and Scotland through nine operating regions. We are a top ten UK housebuilder, measured by the number of homes sold, including delivering 4,035 homes in our financial year ended October 31, 2019. Unlike traditional housebuilders, our business model is based on partnerships with entities interested in seeing an increase in supply of homes as well as those with demand for our product. These partners are primarily land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) or Registered Providers, which include the traditional not-for-profit and the newer for-profit entities that are registered with the Regulator of Social Housing to provide affordable housing. We engage each of our key stakeholders in residential projects by establishing, aligning and prioritizing their needs and successfully delivering their objectives. We have built our reputation by aligning our approach to our partners’ objectives regarding the sourcing, procurement, planning and delivery of successful, affordable housing developments that create significant social value. We believe that we are the original partnership-focused housebuilder in the United Kingdom, having worked with over 200 partners to date, with many of these relationships enduring for over 20 years. Our partnership model allows us to have a high degree of certainty over our land pipeline, with sufficient land secured for six years of development based on our future development plans and on 2019 home deliveries, while also typically allowing us to defer payment until milestones are met. We are also able to minimize development and planning risks by partnering with land owners through the early stages of a development project. Coupled with the relatively low land costs for the affordable homes that we target, we are able to operate a capitallight business model relative to traditional housebuilders, and generate relatively strong cash conversion and return on capital employed (“ROCE”). In the financial year ended October 31, 2019, the last full financial year prior to the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, our ROCE was 32.8%. We focus on developing urban and suburban locations where there is an inherent demand and supply imbalance for new homes. We aim to meet this demand through our five core standard house type ranges. This standardization allows efficiency in procuring materials and construction, increased certainty of cost and timing of delivery, and assists in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and our partners’ preferences. We are continually working with new technologies that underpin and refine our designs. We are committed to deliver a range of affordable housing, predominantly for open market sale, social housing and shared ownership – which provides us with a higher degree of market resilience over the long term due to generally consistent demand from first-time buyers and well-funded Registered Providers. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site), with the remaining approximately 26% of our sales comprising sales to Registered Providers that are contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section 106 obligations. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 were to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (first-time buyers accounted for 76% during the financial year ended October 31, 2019). In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 45% of our total sales, including 67% of sales to first time buyers, involved the use of the United Kingdom government’s (the “Government”) Help to Buy (“HTB”) scheme. We believe that first-time buyers provide more resilient structural demand than the typically discretionary and cyclical home-mover segment. ----- ----- opportunities as a result. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrate the resiliency and strength of our business model. Our focus on partnerships provides us with an attractive financial model, benefitting from typically lower land values, attractive (and often deferred) payment terms, the potential for additional elective deals with Registered Providers (beyond sales in connection with Section 106 affordable housing obligations) and access to grant funding to optimize returns. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.”

Subsubsection Title: Strong Fundamentals Underpinning the UK Housing Sector, Supported by a Favorable Government Policy Environment
Subsubsection Text: The supply of housing in the UK market has lagged behind demand and the regions where we operate in particular are characterized by a structural supply-demand imbalance. The UK Government’s position has historically been that everyone should have the opportunity to own an affordable, decent home within a sustainable and mixed community. To this end, support for the housing market and first-time buyers has been a target of government policy over recent years, starting with the introduction of the National Planning Policy Framework (“NPPF”) in 2012. In its 2021 annual budget, the Government reiterated its pledge to increase the number of new homes built per annum, with the goal of delivering at least one million additional homes through this parliamentary cycle. Overall, the Government has a target to build 300,000 homes per year through the mid-2020s (as announced in the Budget 2017), and we expect there to be continued support for the housebuilding sector as the Government seeks to achieve this target. The following chart shows the number of homes completed by private sector and public sector funding, as compared to the Government target of 300,000 per year. In particular, the first-time buyer market outside of London, our core target market, is aided by a supportive structural and political backdrop promoting both home ownership and affordable housing, including through UK central Government funds, loans, grants and subsidies, which assist in both the viability of schemes and also pace of delivery. As demonstrated by the recently launched “First Homes” program, which offers firsttime buyers a minimum 30% discount on the purchase of a new build home, we expect this segment to continue to be a key focus area for the UK government in the future. This has contributed to a rise in housebuilding completions to 178,310 in England in the year ended December 31, 2019, the highest level since 2007. This is, however, far below the 300,000 per year needed in England as estimated by the UK Government in early 2021 despite the macro-economic uncertainty created by the pandemic. As household formation continues to rise and the pandemic has reinforced buyer preferences for houses over flats, we have experienced a strong recovery in 2021 to date. ----- The demand backdrop for housing remains supportive with the continued increase in UK household formation. The following chart shows the number of homes in the UK since 2011, as of June 29, 2020, with 20212039 data estimates completed by private sector and public sector funding, as compared to the Government target of 300,000 per year. (1) Office for national statistics While it is not currently known whether the HTB scheme will be extended after 2023, what modifications to any extensions may be, or if other government support for the sector may be put in place, we believe the Government will remain focused on supporting those purchasers who form our key customer base. For instance, when the HTB scheme was modified and extended to March 2023, reforms were implemented to restrict the scheme to support only first-time buyers from April 1, 2021 onwards and with regional price caps from £186,100 in the North East to £600,000 in London. As our ASP was £162,000 in the year ended October 31, 2019, we believe this modification will have little to no adverse impact for our business. Our ASP compares favorably for entry price point customers when compared to our listed peers. Further, based on our ability to navigate recent changes to the Scottish equivalent of the HTB scheme, we do not believe that any termination of the HTB scheme would have a material effect on the demand for our homes in England. In Scotland, the “Affordable New Build Scheme” remains available to larger housebuilders (including Keepmoat), though it stopped accepting new applications on February 5, 2021. The suspension of new applications has had no major impact on our performance in the region, which we believe is primarily a result of our target market dynamics, competitive entry price point and strong reputation as a 5-Star Homebuilder.

Subsubsection Title: We Operate in those areas of the UK Housing Market with the Highest Levels of Affordability and Resilience
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we are strategically positioned in the most attractive segment of the UK housing market, from both a demographic and a geographic perspective. Key attractions of this market segment include resilience in adverse macroeconomic environments, the greatest affordability levels in terms of income/price ratios and one of the strongest growth rates in historical and forecast volumes. This segment is also conducive to strong partnerships with land owners such as Homes England and other local authorities, as well as delivery partners, including Registered Providers, in their role as agents for the implementation of Government housing policies driven by social objectives. As a result, we have achieved consistently strong sales rates in recent years, outperforming more broadly focused housebuilders. From April 2017 to July 2021, Keepmoat has achieved an average open market sales rate per outlet per week of 0.82, which is above the broader housing sector’s average open market sales rate per outlet per week of 0.66. ----- ----- In terms of geographical footprint, we strategically focus on regions with fundamental affordability underpinned by strong customer demand and high growth rates. Each of these regions is characterized by belowaverage house prices and mortgage payments as a percentage of take home pay for first-time buyers. The average income to mortgage payment ratio for the regions we operate in is in excess of 4.0x, compared to approximately 2.0x to 2.5x for London and the South East or approximately 3.3x for the UK as a whole. Additionally, in each region, our ASP is below the regional average, leaving room for price inflation while remaining at the affordable end of the spectrum. The following chart compares our ASP with the market average in the respective regions shown below. (1) Average new build sales value from UKHPI Bulletin December 2020 (weighted average Nov ‘19 –Oct ‘20). Keepmoat Open Market Sales ASP for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 based on regional sales data. Keepmoat “South” region has been compared to the UKHPI “South East” region as the most applicable comparator based on locations served. We have a well-established presence in North England and are expanding our footprint in the Midlands and Scotland, where these regions are expected to have higher home completion volumes than the UK average in the medium term. Forecasted growth rates for ASP between 2021 to 2025 are 28.0%. in the North West, 28.0% in Yorkshire and the Humber, 23.9% in the East Midlands and 23.9% in the West Midlands, compared to an already strong UK average of 21.5%.

Subsubsection Title: Our Partnership Model Carries Inherently Less Risk than the Traditional Housebuilding Model, with High Barriers to Entry and Partners that are Structurally Aligned
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the UK’s leading dedicated partnership-focused housebuilders with a proven track-record and a strong reputation of delivering large scale, multi-faceted, residential-led regeneration schemes throughout England and Scotland. Unlike traditional housebuilders, we primarily develop in collaboration with partners that have some form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility) in the relevant development. We are a partner of land owners such as Homes England and other Local Authorities, as well as delivery partners, including Registered Providers of affordable housing, strategically catering to structural demand driven by social objectives and Government housing policies. Partnership relationships promote effective and capital light land sourcing and site development (often with deferred payment terms correlated to the pace of site development and unit sales), as well as the ability to unlock development sites often inaccessible to traditional housebuilders. Unlike the traditional model, the partnership model offers an attractive financial profile with lower land acquisition costs, favorable (often deferred) payment terms, cash generative and competitively priced deals with Registered Providers, access to grant funding and accelerated delivery, enabling us to pursue investments with an attractive ROCE. ----- The following chart provides an illustration of the lifecycle of a development and key differences in our model. (1) Keepmoat profile based on a sample of sites. Traditional profile based on management’s experience of the UK housebuilding industry. Over the past 25 years, we have developed strong relationships with many of the largest land partners in the UK, which are predominantly public land owners but also include private land owners, and have built a strong reputation for delivery, quality and place making (i.e., creating thriving, sustainable communities where people genuinely want to live, work and play). Relationships are maintained at multiple organizational levels, which help identify future projects and facilitate successful tender processes. This results in a high volume of repeat business and a strong visibility of the order book. Long-standing partner relationships such as ours are inherently difficult to replicate for new entrants. We believe that the partnership model also has a reduced risk profile, as it is fundamentally based on a structural alignment of objectives among ourselves and our partners, which results in pragmatism and flexibility when required. As demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, working with our partners, we were able to agree a deferral of 80% of committed land spend and 97% of forecast uncommitted land spend, without losing any site investment opportunities as a result.

Subsubsection Title: Operating Model with Best-In-Class Processes and Cost Structure
Subsubsection Text: We have specialized in offering a standardized product range of family homes as the optimal means of building affordable and high quality housing units, while minimizing execution risk and improving predictability of costs as well as improving construction build times. This focus on product standardization is a key differentiating element of our business model and commercial proposition to our partners, contributing to the creation of a strong brand. To facilitate standardization, we typically utilize our five standard house type ranges, catering to the requirements of private sale, sale to Registered Providers and local authorities, future mobility standards and Scottish building standards (where applicable), which assist in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and partner’s preferences. Although it varies from year to year, in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88% of our homes were built using standardized housing types. The in-house development process of our portfolio of core standard designs is based on internal feedback for saleability, buildability, customer feedback and land/commercial optimization, and is a key driver of the continued operational improvements across the Group that have resulted in enhanced operating margins. ----- Standardization of house types has enabled us to accurately reflect third party designs (such as heating, roofs, furniture and kitchens) for space and accessibility standards. These standard details allow us to promote best practices for quality, safety and precise material scheduling, optimizing waste as a result. Importantly, standard specifications facilitate forward demand planning, purchase leverage and rebate maximization. It allows contractors to bid aggressively on our projects as they have greater confidence around deliverability on cost and on time. The standardization process has also enhanced the quality of our products which, in turn, has increased customer satisfaction and reduced aftercare costs. The efficiencies across the supply chain and cost control and optimization have strengthened our ability to maintain strong margins and provide a partial defense from cost inflation pressures. This is further enhanced by our disciplined approach through all stages of capital allocation, acquisitions and cost control. Standardization has also enabled us to continue to maintain a low ASP, providing the potential to benefit from sale price increases during inflationary periods.

Subsubsection Title: Proven Ability to Source Land through a Disciplined Acquisition Process
Subsubsection Text: We have implemented a structured and agile land acquisition process, enabling a continued replenishment of our land pipeline that has contributed to sustained margin improvement over the last few years. As there is a lag between the securing of land and the ultimate delivery of finished product on that land, we may see benefit from this focus on land acquisition being realized over time. We have a controlled and disciplined internal land acquisition approval process, working within defined control gateways each requiring senior executive and/or Capex Committee approval. Our land approval protocol involves three stages. The Pre-Bid Capex proposal establishes the nature, suitability and targeted financial returns (for gross margin and ROCE) of the opportunity. The Capex 1 Proposal includes a review of planning, title and legal reports, site risks/mitigants and required approvals, with continued focus on delivering in line with the threshold financial returns. Finally, the Capex 2 proposal is the region’s final proposal to develop the site (including financial plan) once all legal matters and major approvals are received. We believe this rigorous land sourcing process, together with sales price optimization, build and sales management and the resulting increasing mix of higher quality and better procured sites, may all be contributing factors driving continued margin expansion. For example, for sites under development that were approved between 2017 and 2019 (excluding the North West MCI region), average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval range from approximately 22% to 23% by year, whereas for sites either approved since 2020 or within our secured pipeline and to be approved, average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval or for the “to be approved” category, range from approximately 24% to 25% by year or category. This is an increase from the average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for sites under development that were approved in 2016 and pre-2016, for which average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins are approximately 21% and 18%, respectively.

Subsubsection Title: Strong Management Team with Proven Operational Experience
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong management team with a proven track record in UK housebuilding, including expertise in land acquisition, construction, planning, development and partnering with housing associations, local authorities, and Registered Providers. This has been instrumental in helping us to achieve 5-Star Homebuilder status in 2021 with a 92.6% customer satisfaction score. Since the formation of our executive management team in 2018, we have delivered consistent year-onyear revenue growth, Gross Development Margin and EBIT growth (excluding the COVID-impacted financial year ended October 31, 2020). The team has accomplished this primarily through an increase in scale, improved operational efficiency and a disciplined land acquisition process spearheaded by the divisional management team which has extensive knowledge of the selected regions in which we operate.

Subsubsection Title: Strong Financial Track Record of Growth and Returns
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong track record of growth and increase in profitability in recent years, resulting from the combination of our geographical expansion process and strong focus on operational improvements and margin expansion. From the financial year ended March 31, 2015 to the financial year ended October 31, 2019, revenue grew by a CAGR of 22% and home completions grew from 2,133 to 4,035 (representing a CAGR of 15%), driven ----- by methodical expansion in established regions and into new regions, including in January 2017 the acquisition of MCI Developments Limited in the North West, as well as benefiting from ASP increases. The KM Group’s Adjusted EBIT increased 47.7% from £41.4 million for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 to £61.1 million in the financial year ended October 31, 2019. Inevitably, the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic had a negative impact in the KM Group’s financial performance in 2020. However, illustrating the strength and resiliency of our business model, we generated revenues of £628.5 million and Adjusted EBITDA of £73.8 million in the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, representing a decrease of 3.3% and an increase of 18.3%, respectively, as compared to the financial year ended October 31, 2019. Concurrently with this growth, we have made significant investments in structure and personnel at both regional and head office levels, creating a national platform optimally crafted to support our future growth in our target geographies. Margins have remained stable over this period, proving our ability and further potential to continue investing and increasing scale.

Subsubsection Title: High Visibility on Medium Term Revenue Growth, Risk Mitigation Opportunities and Margin Improvement
Subsubsection Text: Our current land pipeline reflects a strong level of land security to deliver on the business plan and continue to drive future growth, providing us with excellent forward visibility. As of July 31, 2021, there were 24,654 plots in our land pipeline, of which approximately 81% were legally secured, meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract. This equates to a land pipeline of six years at pre-pandemic annual volumes. We intend to continue to leverage our strong land pipeline and high near-term land visibility to increase delivery volumes. We currently characterize five of our nine regions (the East Midlands, South Midlands, North West MCI, Scotland and West Midlands regions) as “growth regions,” and we believe these regions have significant potential to deliver additional plots within the existing regional management structure as they mature. We will target both continued growth in volume and margin improvement, as the business delivers on regional management team investments that have been made in these growth regions and benefits from the continued realization of land acquired through improved sourcing processes. Approximately 86% of our land pipeline has agreed deferred land payment terms with our partners. Of our land pipeline plots that have been legally secured as of July 31, 2021, approximately 37% represents projects that were not legally completed and there remained conditionality (e.g., planning and groundworks survey) prior to finalizing the contract. There are further risk mitigation opportunities available to us within our partnership model such as land payments made by Registered Provider partners, overage agreements, pace and tenure delivery flexibility and multi-tenure development. The benefits of these risk mitigation features have been demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, with our strong relationships with partners providing flexibility to recalibrate land and delivery obligations during this challenging period. Altogether, we were able to either defer or pay in alignment with plot delivery £58.4 million of £65.5 million total forecast land payments (89%) from April 1, 2020 to August 31, 2020.

Subsubsection Title: Continued Development of Our Large and Strong Land Pipeline
Subsubsection Text: In addition to building out our strong land pipeline of over 24,000 plots, we intend to continue to pursue new land opportunities to maintain the secured land pipeline, particularly increasing the amount of higher quality, better procured sites (reflecting our enhanced requirements and processes prior to approval for an opportunity being granted). We expect to continue to have a structured, disciplined and agile approach to land acquisitions to facilitate securing suitable land opportunities across all of our regions, who each have dedicated land acquisition teams focused on high quality land opportunities within each region’s geographical area of operation.

We intend to build on our long-standing relationships with key stakeholders such as Registered Providers, Local Authorities, and Government agencies, such as Homes England. These relationships have been nurtured ----- over two decades and are held throughout our organizational structure and that of our partners, from executives to regional management and staff. We have a proven track record for delivery, quality and placemaking resulting in winning repeat business. Going forward, we will continue to align objectives with key partners in areas such as climate and biodiversity emergency targets, in addition to the growing need for affordable homes. We will also seek to develop new relationships through our new business teams.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to Focus on Delivering Best Services while Maintaining Strong ESG Benefits and H&S Standards at our Sites
Subsubsection Text: Customer satisfaction is at the heart of our business and we strive to deliver high-quality homes and customer service, reflected by our 5-star customer status. We intend to continue to focus on ensuring that our customers are supported throughout their house buying journey, meeting their expectations, and providing them with a high-quality new home. Sustainability is core to the partnership business model and we are committed to prioritizing ESG initiatives. Key stakeholders are aligned in their focus with approximately 74% of Local Authorities in the UK declaring a climate and biodiversity change emergency, with regeneration areas often more vulnerable to climate and environmental impacts. We are working with Wildscapes, which is a wildlife trust consultancy, to develop methodologies to support the delivery of a net gain in biodiversity for future developments. We are responsible for placemaking and regeneration which in turn helps create direct and indirect employment opportunities within low-income communities. We are focused on providing affordable, low carbon homes to contribute to delivering on our and our partners’ objectives of improving the environmental sustainability of the UK’s homes. We have committed to a number of near term ESG targets, including: introducing science-based carbon targets aligned to limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius along with carbon performance metrics (currently anticipated to be set in late 2021); setting our decarbonisation roadmap within 12 months from July 2021, with the aim of achieving a net zero carbon position by the mid-2040s; mitigating supply chain risks and supporting our supply chain to become more sustainable; and updating our sustainability structure, providing greater oversight and focus on sustainability with the function reporting directly to the CEO and receiving greater focus from the Board. Additionally, we have well-developed and structured H&S policies, certified to ISO 45001:2018, and training programs, as reflected in our health and safety track record. We have clear policies, best practice guides and robust standards and operate a number of forward looking and backward looking metrics. We continuously seek to improve our H&S performance and approach, focusing on risk throughout all phases of a development. Our strategic objectives are centered around (i) keeping people safe and healthy every day; (ii) protecting and enhancing the environment; and (iii) being assured and informed. Each of the these strategic objectives contain a number of initiatives focused on achieving the objectives and cover, amongst other matters, active and visible leadership; managing risk effectively and proportionately; accountability, behavior and culture; capability; contemporary management systems; and key performance indicators. As initiatives are implemented, they are reviewed for effectiveness by our executive EHS committee and monitored.

Our strategy is to maintain and strengthen our position as one of the leading partnerships-focused housebuilders in the UK, while delivering enhanced margins and returns from our maturing regional platform. To achieve this goal, we are focused on the following key strategic priorities.
On August 4, 2021, the Company entered into a share purchase agreement (the “Acquisition

Subsection Title: Agreement”) with the Sellers pursuant to which, among other things, the Company agreed to indirectly acquire
Subsubsection Text: 100% of the share capital of the Target. Completion of the Acquisition Agreement was conditional on a number of third party consents, all of which have now been obtained. The Acquisition will be consummated on or about October 27, 2021 (the “Completion Date.”) The estimated cash consideration payable by the Company on the Completion Date is approximately £517.1 million. The estimated cash consideration payable to the Sellers represents the agreed base consideration payable to the Sellers pursuant to the Acquisition as adjusted for our estimates of an agreed ticker fee accruing until the Completion Date and certain notified cash leakage items, certain payments arising as a result of the Transactions and certain other adjustments required under the Acquisition Agreement. See “Use of Proceeds.” ----- Certain members of management will settle and subsequently reinvest their shares into the Company in lieu of receiving cash. The Company will also be liable to: (i) repay the Target Group external debt of approximately £159.9 million (the precise figure will depend on break fees as of the Completion Date) (the “Existing Target

Subsection Title: Indebtedness”); (ii) procure the repayment by the Target of certain transaction costs of the Sellers and disclosed
Subsubsection Text: A portion of the cash proceeds from the offering of the Notes will be used to make the Proceeds Loan in order to repay substantially all of the Existing Target Indebtedness (which amount excludes accrued and unpaid interest thereon, prepayment and/or cancellation fees and/or redemption premia) expected to be outstanding on the estimated Completion Date, assuming the Completion Date occurs on or about October 27, 2021, comprising: (i) a senior term facility, between, among others, Keystone Bidco Limited as company and original borrower, certain GSO funds as original lenders, Elavon Financial Services DAC, UK Branch as agent and U.S. Bank Trustees Limited as security agent (the “Existing Senior Term Facility”); and (ii) the super senior revolving credit agreement, between, among others, Keystone Bidco Limited as company and original borrower, Barclays Bank Plc, Lloyds Bank plc and Royal Bank of Canada as original lenders, Lloyds Bank plc as agent and U.S. Bank Trustees Limited as security agent (the “Existing Super Senior Revolving Credit Facility” and, together with the Existing Senior Term Facility, the “Existing Debt”). On or about the Issue Date, the Issuer and the Company, as co-borrowers, will enter into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement which provides for the £70.0 million Revolving Credit Facility. If the amounts of debt outstanding under our Existing Debt on the Completion Date exceed the amounts set forth above and in the event that freely available cash on the balance sheet on the Completion Date is lower than our estimate due to, among other things, a negative movement in working capital, we may draw down amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Completion Date to fund any shortfall to complete the Transactions.

Subsubsection Text: To the extent the Acquisition will not complete on or shortly after the Issue Date, pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from the Offering of the Notes into the Escrow Account in the name of the Issuer on the Issue Date. The Escrow Account will be controlled by the Escrow Agent and will be charged on a first-priority basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the Notes. See “Summary—The Offering—Collateral.” The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within three Business Days). See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special _Mandatory Redemption.” If these conditions are not satisfied on or prior to December 31, 2021 (the “Escrow_ Longstop Date”) or upon the occurrence** of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption (the “Special Mandatory Redemption”). The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will ----- be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow _of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—_ _If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuer will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Account will not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on an additional equity investment from the shareholders.”_

Subsection Title: Indebtedness”); (ii) procure the repayment by the Target of certain transaction costs of the Sellers and disclosed
Subsubsection Text: transaction bonuses (net of estimated corporate tax savings)(to the extent that these costs exceed this amount, the amount of consideration for the Acquisition will be reduced to reflect this increased liability); (iii) repay certain debt-like items and adjustments to be repaid as part of the Transactions, including intercompany loans and other similar items; and (iv) pay certain fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. The Acquisition will be financed as follows: (i) the Issuer will issue the Notes offered hereby in an aggregate principal amount of £275.0 million; and (ii) Aermont and certain members of its management will make an equity contribution in an estimated amount of £476.1 million, which will be downstreamed through a series of intermediate holding companies to the Company (the “Equity Contribution”). The purchase price for the Acquisition is subject to customary purchase price adjustments in accordance with the Acquisition Agreement. The purchase price set forth in the Acquisition Agreement includes a profit ticker component, which is an agreed daily amount that accrues from and excluding April 30, 2021 to and including the Completion Date. As a result, the ultimate purchase price under the Acquisition Agreement will also be dependent on the timing of the Completion Date. In addition, the purchase price for the Acquisition Agreement will be reduced by the amount of leakages, being actions resulting in the loss of cash or other value from the Target in favor of the Sellers, such as the payment of any dividends, any other payments or disposals, assignments or transfer of assets or any payments made pursuant to any guarantee, indemnity or similar obligation, among other things, in each case to the extent not expressly permitted by the Acquisition Agreement (collectively, the “Leakages”).

Our financial performance during the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was affected significantly by the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of program disruption and the costs of operating with COVID-19 working practices and social-distancing measures, our delivery volumes declined significantly given construction activity was significantly stalled from April through August 2020, our margins declined slightly compared to the financial year ended October 31, 2019 and our EBIT and ROCE performance eroded significantly. However, as demonstrated by our performance for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and our forward order book, we recovered strongly from the COVID-19 pandemic by the first quarter of our fiscal year 2021 and believe that we are well positioned to deliver on our planned growth in the medium term. We have benefitted from a robust UK housing market, with a favorable mortgage environment, ongoing government support and strong demand, against the resilient economic backdrop during the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the strict lockdown measures that were imposed through April 2021, for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, our Adjusted EBIT and ROCE increased 12.8% and 150 basis points, respectively, as compared to the financial year ended October 31, 2019. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrates the resiliency and strength of our business model. The COVID-19 lockdown restrictions imposed in March 2020 caused our financial performance to decline but did not stress our overall financial profile given the lower risk inherent in our partnership model. In addition, during the financial year ended October 31, 2020, £24.4 million in partner payments were deferred, representing approximately 80% of our total commitments, which illustrates the flexible land creditor profile we maintain. -----

The following summary should be read in conjunction with, and is qualified in its entirety by, the more detailed information included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. Before making an investment decision, you should carefully read this entire Offering Memorandum to understand our business, the nature and terms of the Notes and the tax and other considerations which are important to your decision to invest in the Notes, including the more detailed information in the Financial Statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See the section entitled “Risk Factors” for factors that you should consider before investing in the Notes and the section entitled_ “Forward-Looking Statements” _for information relating to the statements contained in this Offering Memorandum that are not historical facts._

The diagram below provides a simplified overview of our corporate and financing structure on a consolidated basis as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions. The diagram does not include all entities within the Group, nor does it show all of our liabilities. For a summary of the material financing arrangements identified in the diagram, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.” (1) Maison BidCo Limited (the “Company”) is a private limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales which was formed to facilitate the Transactions. The Company will be indirectly wholly owned by Maison Hold Limited (“Holdco”), a private limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales. Holdco will be wholly owned by funds and co-investment vehicles advised by Aermont Capital LLP together with certain management shareholders. See “Our Shareholder.” On the Completion Date, the Company will directly own all the capital stock of Keystone TopCo Limited (the “Target”). See “Summary—The Transactions—The _Acquisition.”_ (2) The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor that is not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes or the Notes Guarantees, as applicable, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, and will rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Company PIK Loan (as defined in “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Company PIK Loan”). The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be effectively subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer and the Guarantors that is secured by property or assets that do not also secure the Notes and the Notes Guarantees or that are secured by a first priority fixed charge on property or assets that secure the Notes by way of a floating charge, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness. The Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be structurally subordinated to all existing and future indebtedness and other liabilities of subsidiaries of the Company that do not provide guarantees. (3) On the Issue Date, the Notes will initially be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Company. Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection and/or registration requirements, the Notes and the Issue Date Guarantee will be secured on a first priority basis on the Issue Date by (i) a charge over all of the shares in the Company on a third party limited recourse basis granted by Holdco; (ii) an assignment over intercompany receivables owing by the Company to Holdco; (iii) a charge over all of the shares in the Issuer granted by the Company; (iv) an English law debenture granted by the Company with respect to its material bank accounts and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets; and (v) an English law debenture granted by the Issuer with respect to its material bank accounts and any structural intercompany receivables owed to it by the Company and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets. See “Description of the Notes—Security.” In addition, on the Issue Date, to the extent the Acquisition will not complete on or shortly after the Issue Date, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured by the Escrow Charges relating thereto. Upon the definitive release of the Escrowed Property, the first-priority security interests over the Escrowed Property will be released and terminated. (4) Within 150 days of the Completion Date (the “Post-Closing Date”), the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by each of Keepmoat Limited, Keepmoat Homes Limited and M.C.I. Developments Limited. Subject to and in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles, the Intercreditor Agreement and certain perfection requirements, within 10 Business Days of the Completion Date, the Notes or the Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by (i) a charge over all of the shares in the Target granted by the Company and (ii) an assignment over any structural intercompany receivables owing by the Target to the Company, and on or about the Post-Closing Date, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by (i) a charge over all of the shares in Keepmoat Homes Limited granted by Keepmoat Limited; (ii) a charge over all of the shares in M.C.I. Developments Limited granted by Keepmoat Homes Limited; and (iii) an English law debenture granted by each Post-Closing Guarantor over its material bank accounts and any ----- structural intercompany receivables owed to it and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets in each case, subject to customary limitations and exceptions. See “Description of the Notes—Security” and “Description of the Notes—Notes Guarantees.” The property and assets that will secure the Notes and the Notes Guarantees thereof will also secure the Revolving Credit Facility on a firstranking and pari passu basis. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), in the event of a distressed disposal of, or an enforcement of the security interests over, the Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain other future indebtedness permitted under the Indenture to be secured in priority to the Notes have been repaid in full. The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the security interests and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the _Notes Guarantees and Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.” The Collateral and the Notes Guarantees may be_ released in certain circumstances. (5) The Issuer is a public limited liability company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales on September 7, 2021 for the purpose of issuing the Notes offered hereby and is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company. The Issuer conducts no business operations of its own and, as of the Issue Date, will have no material assets and its only material liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness (including its obligations under the Notes) and, as of the Completion Date, its only material assets will be its rights and claims under the Proceeds Loan. The Issuer has not engaged in any activities other than those related to its formation and the issuance of the Notes. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure—The Issuer is a wholly-owned finance subsidiary that, following the _completion of the Offering, will have no revenue generating operations of its own and will depend on cash flows from operating companies to make payments on the Notes.”_ (6) On or about the Issue Date, the Company will enter into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement. The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement provides for a revolving credit facility in the aggregate principal amount of £70.0 million. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by the Company, the Issuer and certain of the Company’s restricted subsidiaries which accede to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as additional borrowers of that facility and may be applied in or towards (directly or indirectly) financing or refinancing the working capital and/or the general corporate purposes of the Group. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Revolving _Credit Facility.”_ (7) Not all of our subsidiaries will guarantee the Notes. (8) As of, and for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, the Guarantors accounted for 99% of total assets, 100% of revenue and 99% of Adjusted EBITDA of the KM Group. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to contractual and legal limitations and may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—The Notes Guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and _Our Structure.”_ -----

Subsection Title: Form and Denominations ................... The Notes will only be issued in fully registered form and will have
Subsubsection Text: minimum denominations of £100,000 and integral multiples of £1,000 in excess thereof. Notes in denominations of less than £100,000 will not be available.

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes .......................... The Notes will:
Subsubsection Text: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer, secured as set forth under “—Collateral”; - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including, any indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the Issuer; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes or that are secured by a first priority fixed charge on property or assets that secure the Notes by way of a floating charge, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Company that do not guarantee the Notes, including obligations to trade creditors; and - be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors, subject to certain guarantee limitations.

Subsection Title: Notes Guarantees ................................ On the Issue Date, the Notes will initially be guaranteed on a senior basis,
Subsubsection Text: by the Company. Within 150 days of the Completion Date (or such later date as may be agreed), the Notes will be guaranteed by each of ----- Keepmoat Limited, Keepmoat Homes Limited and M.C.I. Developments Limited (the “Post-Closing Date Guarantors”). As of, and for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, the Guarantors accounted for 99% of total assets, 100% of revenue and 99% of Adjusted EBITDA of the KM Group. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to contractual and legal limitations and may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—The Notes Guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure.”

Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes Guarantees ..... The Notes Guarantee of each Guarantor will:
Subsubsection Text: - be a general senior obligation of that Guarantor, secured as set forth under “—Collateral”; - rank _pari passu_ in right of payment with all of that Guarantor’s existing and future senior indebtedness that is not subordinated in right of payment to its Notes Guarantee, including, any indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility; - rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the respective Guarantor; - be effectively senior to any existing and future indebtedness of each Guarantor that is not secured by the Collateral owned by such Guarantor, to the extent of the value of such Collateral; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness or other liabilities of each Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes Guarantees or that are secured by a first priority fixed charge on property or assets that secure the Notes by way of a floating charge, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness or liabilities; and - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future obligations of such Guarantor’s subsidiaries that are not Guarantors. The Notes Guarantees will be subject to release under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—The Notes Guarantees.”

Subsection Title: Collateral ............................................. On the Issue Date, to the extent the Acquisition will not complete on or
Subsubsection Text: shortly after the Issue Date, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be secured by the Escrow Charges relating thereto. Upon the definitive release of the Escrowed Property, the first-priority security interests over the Escrowed Property will be released and terminated. In addition, on the Issue Date, the Notes and Issue Date Guarantee will be secured on a first-priority basis by (collectively, the “Issue Date

- a charge over all of the shares in the Company on a third party limited recourse basis granted by Holdco; - an assignment over structural intercompany receivables owing by the Company to Holdco; ----- - a charge over all of the shares in the Issuer granted by the Company; - an English law debenture granted by the Company with respect to its material bank accounts and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets; and - an English law debenture granted by the Issuer with respect to its material bank accounts and any structural intercompany receivables owed to it by the Company and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets Within 10 Business Days of the Completion Date, the Notes or the Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by a charge over all of the shares in the Target granted by the Company and an assignment over any structural intercompany receivables owing by the Target to the Company and, within 150 days of the Completion Date, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by, respectively (collectively, the “Post-Closing Collateral,” and together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”): - a charge over all of the shares in Keepmoat Homes Limited granted by Keepmoat Limited; - a charge over all of the shares in M.C.I. Developments Limited granted by Keepmoat Homes Limited; and - an English law debenture granted by each Post-Closing Guarantor over its material bank accounts and any structural intercompany receivables owed to it and a floating charge over all or substantially all of its assets, in each case, subject to customary limitations and exceptions. Pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of a distressed disposal of, or an enforcement of the security interests over, the Collateral, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from such Collateral only after the obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain other future indebtedness permitted under the Indenture to be secured in priority to the Notes have been repaid in full. See “Description _of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_ The security interests over the Collateral may be released in certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Our _Structure,” “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements— Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Notes—Security— Release of Liens.”_

Subsection Title: Optional Redemption ......................... Prior to          , 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at its option to
Subsubsection Text: redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption, plus the applicable “make-whole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum. On or after          , 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at its option to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the applicable redemption prices set forth under the heading “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption,”_ _plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the_ redemption date. ----- Prior to          , 2023, the Issuer will be entitled at its option on one or more occasions to redeem the Notes in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes (including the original principal amount of any additional notes) with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to      % of the principal amount outstanding in respect of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding the redemption date, provided that at least 50% of the original principal amount of the Notes (including the original principal amount of any additional notes) remains outstanding immediately after each such redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” Prior to          , 2023, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional notes issued) during each twelve month period commencing with the Issue Date at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date. In connection with any tender offer or other offer to purchase all of the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% of the aggregate principal amount of the then outstanding Notes validly tender and do not validly withdraw such Notes in such tender offer or offer to purchase, the Issuer will have the right to redeem all Notes that remain outstanding at a price equivalent to the price offered to each holder of the Notes in such tender offer or offer to purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, thereon. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

Subsection Title: Additional Amounts ........................... All payments made by the Issuer or any Guarantor with respect to the
Subsubsection Text: Notes or the Notes Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for or on account of taxes unless required by law. If the Issuer or any Guarantors are required by law to withhold or deduct amounts for or on account of tax imposed by a relevant taxing jurisdiction from a payment in respect of the Notes, the Issuer or the relevant Guarantor will, subject to certain exceptions, pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by a holder of the Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that such holder would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.”

Subsection Title: Tax Redemption .................................. The Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time,
Subsubsection Text: upon giving prior notice, at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes _plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption, if certain changes in tax law impose certain withholding taxes on amounts payable on the Notes or the Note Guarantee, and, as a result, the Issuer or an applicable Guarantor is required to pay additional amounts with respect to such withholding taxes. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption for _Taxation Reasons.”_

Subsection Title: Change of Control .............................. Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control,
Subsubsection Text: the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof _plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of such repurchase. However, a change of control will be deemed not to have occurred if a specified consolidated net ratio is not exceeded. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control” and “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure—We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt and sustain our operations, which we may not be able to generate or raise.”_ -----

Subsection Title: Escrow Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption ...................... To the extent the Acquisition will not complete on or shortly after the
Subsubsection Text: Issue Date, concurrently with the closing of the Offering, and pending release to consummate of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Account, held in the name of the Issuer. The Escrow Account will be controlled by the Escrow Agent, and charged on a first-priority basis in favor of the Trustee on behalf of the holders of the Notes. The release of the proceeds deposited in the Escrow Account will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within three Business Days). Upon delivery to the Trustee and the Escrow Agent of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release of the proceeds from escrow are satisfied, the Escrowed Property will be released to the Issuer and utilized as described in “Use of _Proceeds,” “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.” If the conditions to the release of the Escrowed_ Property have not been satisfied on or prior to the business day immediately following the Escrow Longstop Date (as defined in “Description of the Notes— _Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption”), or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes_ will be subject to a special mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, such special mandatory redemption date. If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuer will be required to redeem the Notes and, if the Escrow Account alone does not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption and, as such, the Issuer will be required to obtain the necessary funds elsewhere, such as equity investment from shareholders. In addition, the conditions applicable to the special mandatory redemption may be waived by holders of the Notes representing a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding. See “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—_ _If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuer will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Account will not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on an additional equity investment from the shareholders.”_

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants .............................. The Indenture, among other things, restricts the ability of the Issuer, the
Subsubsection Text: Company and its restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends on, or redeem, capital stock and make certain other restricted payments; - make certain investments; - create or incur certain liens; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets; - agree to restrictions on dividends by restricted subsidiaries; ----- - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; - merge or consolidate with other entities; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Each of these covenants is subject to a number of significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants” and the related definitions. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as we achieve certain investment-grade ratings. See “Description of the _Notes—Certain Covenants.”_

Subsection Title: No Established Market for the Notes .................................................... The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
Subsubsection Text: established trading market. Although certain of the Initial Purchasers have advised the Issuer that they intend to make a market for the Notes, they are not obliged to do so and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurances as to the development or liquidity of any market for the Notes.

Subsection Title: Listing ................................................. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority
Subsubsection Text: Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”). There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained.

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds ................................... The gross proceeds of this offering of the Notes sold on the Issue Date
Subsubsection Text: will be used, together with the Equity Contribution, to (i) fund the consideration payable for the Acquisition, (ii) repay Existing Target Indebtedness, (iii) repay Sellers transaction costs, and (iv) pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of _Proceeds.”_

Subsection Title: Governing Law ................................... The Indenture, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be governed by
Subsubsection Text: the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement, the Security Documents and the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are governed by English law provided that certain schedules in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement shall be interpreted in accordance with the laws of the State of New York (without prejudice to the fact that the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement is governed by English law).

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: (A) Exceptional items within cost of sales include development site losses that are included in costs of sales. See note 4 to the financial statements for the seven months ended October 31, 2018. (B) As a result of the acquisition of MCI in January 2017, inventory was acquired which included a fair value adjustment to our book value of £0.9 million. The inventory relating to the fair value adjustment was sold during the financial year ended March 31, 2018. (2) Adjusted EBIT is calculated as operating profit/(loss) before exceptional items, shareholder monitoring fees, amortization of acquisition intangible assets, acquisition fair value adjustments to inventory and impairment losses of investments in associated companies. Adjusted EBITDA is calculated as operating profit/(loss) before exceptional items, shareholder monitoring fees, amortization of acquisition intangible assets, acquisition fair value adjustments to inventory, impairment losses of investments in associated companies, depreciation, depreciation of right-of-use assets and amortisation of computer software. Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted EBITDA are measures not defined under IFRS and should not be considered a substitute to profit or any other measure of performance derived in accordance with IFRS or the accounting measures of other jurisdictions. We present Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted EBITDA for informational purposes only. Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted EBITDA may not provide an accurate or complete picture of the results and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Other Financial _Information” for more information. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” for_ a description of certain significant factors that are expected to have an impact on our Adjusted EBIT and Adjusted EBITDA going forward. Subsubsection Text: (A) October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA and October 2019 Management Adjusted EBITDA have been prepared by, and are the sole responsibility of, the KM Group’s management. PwC has not audited, reviewed, compiled, or applied agreed-upon procedures with respect to this data. Accordingly, PwC does not express an opinion or any other form of assurance with respect thereto. Such information has been derived from KM Group’s accounting records. Our preliminary estimates are based on a number of assumptions and adjustments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. While we believe these results and estimates to be reasonable, our actual results could have varied from these estimates and these differences could be material. As such, you should not place undue reliance on this information. (B) As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and the confinement measures imposed by the Government from March 2020, construction and home sales activity was significantly impacted in the period, which continued during the three months ended October 31, 2020. As a result, our historical results of operations for the three months ended October 31, 2020 do not reflect what the performance of our business would have been had such confinement measures not been implemented. Our operations during the three months ended October 31, 2020 were negatively impacted following the government imposed lockdown and the subsequent delayed ramp up on home construction and sales, before resuming normalized operations during the three month period ended January 31, 2021. In order to assist in the comparability of our results of operations for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 as compared to prior and future periods, we present herein “Normalized EBITDA” for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021. We believe that Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 is a measure that assists in understanding our performance during ----- a period impacted by the market disruption caused by COVID-19 by substituting the October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA with October 2019 Management Adjusted EBITDA, comprising the months of our last calendar equivalent financial quarter prior to the market disruption caused by COVID-19. By the first quarter of our fiscal year 2021 the housing market had rebounded and our operations had normalized. We believe Normalized EBITDA is more representative of our Adjusted EBITDA performance for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 and takes into account, on a highly illustrative basis, the cyclicality of our business. Normalized EBITDA presented herein is for informational purposes only. Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 might not represent what our Adjusted EBITDA would have been for the same period had the confinement measures not been implemented. In particular, Normalized EBITDA does not (i) give effect to any other event or market and economic conditions or factors, favorable or unfavorable, that happened or could have happened during the three months ended October 31, 2020 or (ii) adjust for the positive or negative effect of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic during the nine months ended July 31, 2021. (10) As adjusted total debt is calculated as the total principal amount of debt, as if the as if the Transactions had taken place on July 31, 2021. See “Capitalization.” As adjusted total debt excludes unamortized fees in respect of Existing Senior Term Facility and obligations of the KM Group under the Company PIK Loan. (11) As adjusted net debt represents as adjusted total debt, less the as adjusted cash and cash equivalents set forth in “Capitalization.” As adjusted net debt excludes obligations of the KM Group under the Company PIK Loan. (12) As adjusted cash interest expense represents the cash interest expense on as adjusted total debt as if the Transactions completed as of August 1, 2020. As adjusted cash interest expense excludes obligations of the KM Group under (i) the Company PIK Loan and (ii) all of our lease liabilities. (13) As adjusted total senior secured net debt represents the as adjusted total debt of the Company secured by a first-priority lien on the Collateral less any cash and cash equivalents as set forth in “Capitalization.” As adjusted total senior secured net debt excludes any liabilities secured by a fixed charge or mortgage on Collateral that is subject to a floating charge securing the Notes, which include £10.2 million of development loans as of July 31, 2021. The calculation of as adjusted total senior secured net debt assumes that the Revolving Credit Facility has not been drawn as of the Issue Date.
