Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
SUMMARY HISTORICAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION AND OTHER DATA
Subsubsection Text: The tables below set forth the summary historical consolidated financial information and other data of the KM Group as of and for the dates and for the periods indicated. The Issuer was formed on September 7, 2021, for the purpose of issuing the Notes offered hereby. The Company was incorporated on July 23, 2021 for the purposes of facilitating the Transactions. The Issuer is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Company has no material assets or liabilities, does not have any revenue generating activities of its own, and has not engaged in actions other than those related to its incorporation and in preparation of the Transactions. As a result, no historical information of the Company is included in this Offering Memorandum. The Issuer conducts no business operations of its own and, as of the Issue Date, will have no material assets and its only material liabilities will be its outstanding indebtedness (including its obligations under the Notes) and, as of the Completion Date, its only material assets will be its rights and claims under the Proceeds Loan. The Issuer has not engaged in any activities other than those related to its formation and the issuance of the Notes. The Target has not prepared consolidated financial information and operates its business through Keystone Midco Limited and its subsidiaries. Furthermore, neither the Issuer nor the Company has any material assets or liabilities and neither has engaged in any activities other than those related to their formation in preparation for the Offering and the Transactions. Because of the limited historical financial information available for the Issuer, the Company and the Target, unless otherwise indicated, the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is the historical consolidated financial information of the KM Group, which is generally representative of the financial information of the Group. See “Presentation of Historical and Other Information— _Differences Between the Financial Statements of the Target and the KM Group.”_ In 2018, the KM Group changed its financial year end from March 31 to October 31. As a result, the KM Group’s financial year ended on October 31 for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020, and on March 31 for the financial year ended March 31, 2018. In addition, in connection with the change in financial year, the KM Group presented audited financial statements as of and for the seven months ended October 31, 2018. The summary consolidated income statement, balance sheet and cash flow information for the KM Group set forth below (i) as of and for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020 were derived from the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020; (ii) as of and for the seven months ended October 31, 2018 was derived from the audited consolidated financial statements as of and for the seven months ended October 31, 2018; (iii) as of and for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 was derived from the audited consolidated financial statements for the seven months ended October 31, 2018; (iv) as of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 was derived from the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements as of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2021; and (v) as of and for nine months ended July 31, 2020 was prepared in accordance with IAS 34, Interim Financial Reporting. The financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 has been derived from the restated comparative information contained in the audited financial statements for the year ended October 31, 2018 as restated to give effect to IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with _Customers). See note 26 to the financial statements for the seven months ended October 31, 2018 and_ “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers).” In addition, information below includes certain unaudited condensed consolidated financial information for the KM Group as of and for the twelve-month period ended July 31, 2021. The historical consolidated financial information of the KM Group for the twelve-month period ended July 31, 2021 is unaudited and has been calculated by adding the unaudited results of operations of the KM Group for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 to the audited results of operations of the KM Group for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and then subtracting the unaudited results of operations of the KM Group for the nine months ended July 31, 2020. The unaudited financial information for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 has been prepared solely for the purpose of this Offering Memorandum, is for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of our results of operations for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and the confinement measures imposed by the Government, construction and home sales activity slowed significantly in the period which continued during the three months ----- ended October 31, 2020. As a result, our historical results of operations for the three months ended October 31, 2020 do not reflect what the performance of our business would have been had such confinement measures not been implemented. In order to assist in the comparability of our results of operations for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 as compared to prior and future periods, we present herein “Normalized EBITDA” for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021. We believe that Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 is a measure that assists in understanding our performance during a period impacted by the market disruption caused by COVID-19 by substituting the October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA for the October 2019 Management Adjusted EBITDA, comprising the months of our last calendar equivalent financial quarter prior to the market disruption caused by COVID-19. Our operations during the three months ended October 31, 2020 were negatively impacted following the government imposed lockdown and the subsequent delayed ramp up on home construction and sales, before resuming normalized operations during the three month period ended January 31, 2021. As a result, we believe Normalized EBITDA is more representative of our Adjusted EBITDA performance for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 and takes into account, on a highly illustrative basis, the cyclicality of our business. Normalized EBITDA presented herein is for informational purposes only. Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 might not represent what our Adjusted EBITDA would have been for the same period had the confinement measures not been implemented. In particular, Normalized EBITDA does not (i) give effect to any other event, favorable or unfavorable, that happened or could have happened during the three months ended October 31, 2020, other than the events directly related to the COVID-19 pandemic or (ii) adjust for the positive or negative effect of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic during the nine months ended July 31, 2021. The summary historical financial information presented in this offering memorandum was prepared in accordance with IFRS. The information below is not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for any future periods. The financial data below also includes certain Non-IFRS Measures that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction. The Non-IFRS Measures are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS or the accounting measures of any other jurisdiction and should not be considered substitutes to other indicators of the KM Group’s operating performance, cash flows, or any other measure derived in accordance with IFRS. Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on the UK housing market and subject to deterioration of the UK economy, brought about by uncertainty, loss of consumer confidence, higher interest rates, increasing unemployment or other factors, which could lead to decreased affordability, reduced demand for housing and falling house prices.
Subsubsection Text: We operate and generate our revenue exclusively in the UK. As such, our results are highly dependent on conditions in the UK housing market and general macro-economic conditions in the UK. Historically, the strength of the UK housing market has been linked to that of the UK economy as a whole, which in turn is influenced by both European and global macro-economic conditions, all of which have been cyclical in the past. The following factors (among others) could lead to decreased affordability, reduced demand for housing and fluctuations in house prices, which could have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects: - changes in the economic environment (for example, following Brexit) and macro-economic uncertainty created thereby; - reduction in gross domestic product (“GDP”) growth; - increases in unemployment rates; - reduction in consumer and business confidence; - changes in Government housing support and other regulations; - social and industrial unrest; - adverse changes in the availability and cost of credit; - changes in interest rates; and - tax rates (for example, income tax, value added tax (“VAT”), stamp duty and council tax). Historically, significant changes in the UK economy have had a significant effect on demand for housing. For example, the economic weakness experienced in the UK following the global financial crisis in 2008 caused a significant decline in demand for residential property. The declining demand led to a sharp decrease in the number of residential property transactions in the UK, with the value of new housing construction orders in the UK (in constant prices and seasonally adjusted) falling by approximately 51% between the first quarter of 2008 and the first quarter of 2009, according to the Office for National Statistics (the “ONS”). Furthermore, the average UK house price decreased from £259,699 to £216,000 between 2007 and 2009, according to Nationwide. Adverse changes in the macroeconomic climate of the UK could negatively affect our sales volumes or the prices for which we sell houses. The UK economy has and may continue to be affected by periods of political and market uncertainty in Europe and globally, driven by, for example, weaker manufacturing output, ongoing trade tensions, the US/China trade war and global health pandemics, such as COVID-19. The longer that any such changes or uncertainties continue, the more likely it is that UK economic growth will slow. Global GDP is estimated to have fallen by 3.5% in 2020, due in part to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, with UK GDP ----- declining 9.9% in the same year. There continues to be significant uncertainty with respect to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on UK GDP growth and unemployment rates, particularly as furlough and other support measures wind down over the course of 2021. A deterioration of the UK economy could negatively affect our ability to achieve our targets and could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. While macroeconomic factors broadly affect the UK construction market as a whole, housing trends in the UK have also varied significantly by region due to various other factors including regional employment trends, regional differences in the cost of living, regional differences in population growth and demographic trends, the perceived desirability of living in different areas of the country and differences in land and house prices. In the future, should the UK economy stagnate or contract, the variations between regions in the UK may become more pronounced, and housing projects in any of the areas in which we operate may suffer a greater adverse impact relative to those in other regions. For the financial year ended October 31, 2020, we derived 63% of our revenue from our North Division and 37% of our revenue from our South Division. While decreases in house prices can have an adverse effect on our revenues, increases in house prices can also have an adverse effect on revenues to the extent that they result in a deterioration in affordability, as our operations are primarily focused on serving first-time buyers and building homes on the more affordable end of the housing market. Additionally, the segment of the UK housing market in which we operate and the success of our partnership model is largely dependent on investments undertaken by third parties in both the public and private sectors. The level of investment by the public and private sectors is in part connected to general economic conditions. There can be no guarantee that current investment trends in our industry will continue in the coming years, that market conditions will not stagnate or deteriorate or that future austerity measures will not negatively impact the budgets and spending decisions of our clients. If conditions limit investment by the public and private sectors, they may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A majority of our business is secured or supported either directly or indirectly from various Government sources, and changes in local or Government funds, loans, grants or subsidies, or changes to or the discontinuation of mortgage assistance schemes or equity loan schemes (including in particular Help to Buy) could significantly impact our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our focus is to sell affordable homes, particularly to first-time buyers. We made 76% and 74% of our private sales to first-time buyers in the financial years ended October 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. The firsttime buyer market is aided by a supportive structural and political backdrop for affordable housing outside of London, including through UK central Government funds, loans, grants and subsidies, which assist in the viability of our schemes. Since 2016, the Government has increased its focus on providing additional new homes through a number of policy statements and initiatives, including: - an increase in capital funding for the Affordable Homes Programme; - a £1 billion loan scheme to support small and medium enterprise (“SME”) home builders; - an extension of the Government’s Help to Buy scheme and funding; and - additional capital for various funds, including the Housing Infrastructure Fund, the Land Release Fund and the Planning Delivery Fund. Our sales have been particularly supported by Help to Buy, a Government equity loan scheme designed to encourage home ownership in the UK. The Help to Buy program provides assistance to purchasers of newbuild homes in the UK by reducing the minimum down payment required from the purchaser to 5% of a property’s value and providing an equity loan of up to 20% (or 40% in London) of the property value. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, the Help to Buy scheme provided assistance to approximately 67% of our open market customers to purchase a new home. The Help to Buy scheme has been modified and extended to March 2023. However, as of April 1, 2021, the scheme now only supports first-time buyers and imposes regional price caps ranging from £186,100 in the ----- North East to £600,000 in London. As a result of these reforms, non-first-time buyers who previously would have been able to secure funding through the Help to Buy scheme are no longer eligible to do so, which in turn could have an adverse impact on our home sales. In addition, the Help to Buy scheme remains subject to future regulatory changes, including to applicable eligibility criteria. There can be no assurance that the Help to Buy scheme will be extended after 2023 or, if it is extended, how it may be modified. Similarly, there is no assurance that any other similar Government-backed program will continue at current levels, or at all, or that lenders will participate in them. Any changes to the Help to Buy scheme may reduce the availability of Government funding of mortgages, which in turn may reduce demand within the homes market. We occasionally utilize public sector funding at some of our sites, in the form of grants and loans to support delivery and acceleration of housing outputs. For example, we have accessed a Home Building Fund loan, a Government fund that supports new homes being built in England. This loan arrangement was entered into in March 2019. We occasionally rely on public sector grants from Homes England and Local Authorities. Grants from these sources may make certain sites economically viable to develop, where such development would not otherwise have been economically viable without the support from these authorities. The absence of any such grants in the future could result in a loss of certain development opportunities. Additionally, the Affordable Homes Programme is a program created in 2010 to provide grant funding to support the capital costs of developing affordable housing for rent or shared-ownership sale. In connection with the next round of the Affordable Homes Programme (2021-2026), Homes England will be making available approximately £7.5 billion of funding to deliver up to 130,000 affordable homes outside of London by March 2026. We believe that this funding will be a key source of liquidity for Registered Providers (one of our principal customer bases for the sale of homes), and therefore any changes to or disruption in the provision of grants under the Affordable Homes Programme could have a material adverse effects on our results of operations. This is particularly true of our MCI business, which works exclusively with Registered Providers. The duration and availability of funding for all of the programs referred to above remain subject to change. In the future, governments and/or local bodies may change their priorities and programs. For example, authorities may reduce or amend mortgage assistance or investment support schemes, or may undertake welfare reforms that may impact funding stability for housing associations and Local Authorities. Any reduction or discontinuation of Government investment, Government funding or Government-backed home purchase assistance programs may make it more difficult for our core first-time buyer customers to afford homes, which could in turn make it more difficult for us to sell homes and may force us to either lower prices or source other forms of mortgage support for customers, each of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our operations, including our operational performance and the welfare of our staff, may be impacted by the spread of COVID-19.
Subsubsection Text: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, and measures imposed by the Government to restrict economic and business activity in response, have had and may continue to have a significant impact on our operations. In particular, our business and financial performance in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. We experienced a significant reduction in our delivery volumes and profit margins as a result of program disruption and added costs resulting from compliance with government guidelines on working practices and social-distancing. Although we undertook certain remedial actions to address the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, including temporarily furloughing employees, temporarily reducing the pay of the executive board and senior management and accessing Government support, the COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted and may continue to disrupt our operations. In light of Government guidance, we temporarily closed our UK sites and offices from mid-March to mid-May of 2020, resulting in significantly lower trading when compared to prior and subsequent periods. We delivered total completions of 2,460 homes in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, which represented a 39.0% reduction from the 4,035 homes completed in the prior financial year. Over the same period, our revenue decreased by 37.5%, to £406.0 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020, from £649.8 million for the prior financial year. Government-mandated quarantines, self-quarantines and staff illness may also result in key staff being absent from work going forward. Any renewed suspension of our business operations at our trading sites may affect our overall business and results of operations. A prolonged economic downturn from the negative effects of the COVID-19 pandemic could also result in us reducing our workforce or incurring charges by way of staff long-term sick pay. ----- The extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact our business, financial condition, results of operations, prospects and liquidity will depend on numerous evolving factors that are unpredictable, including the duration and scope of the pandemic, governmental, business and individuals’ actions that have been and continue to be taken in response to the pandemic, and the impact of the pandemic on global economic activity, unemployment levels and financial markets, including the possibility of a global recession and volatility in the global capital markets which, among other things, may increase the cost of capital and adversely impact our access to capital. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. In addition, even as COVID-19 conditions begin to improve and restrictions are reduced or lifted, we may not regain our operational momentum. Suppliers may reduce or suspend their manufacturing operations as a result of the effects of COVID-19, and therefore may be not be able to supply our products or services in a cost effective or timely manner, if at all. Additionally, COVID could have an impact on subcontractors ability and speed to remobilize from the pandemic, potentially restricting the supply of labor required to deliver construction on site. See “—Our customers and suppliers are exposed to risks associated with the current COVID-19 pandemic _and its ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry.”_ Furthermore, there may be future waves of COVID-19 or similar diseases that lead to additional quarantines with limitations on activity and movement. During the first lockdown that began in March 2020, there was limited guidance from the Government as to whether the house building industry could continue operations, which resulted in many housebuilders, including Keepmoat, ceasing building activities altogether for a period of time. The reintroduction of restrictions or a lack of guidance from the Government regarding the activities allowed during the course of a future wave of the pandemic could have a significant adverse impact on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our customers and suppliers are exposed to risks associated with the current COVID-19 pandemic and its ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry.
Subsubsection Text: In addition to the direct impact on our operations, the COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant impact on the home building industry generally, as well as on our customers and suppliers. For example, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK housebuilding industry has experienced certain material and services shortages, including a limited supply of bricks and available subcontractors, which have in turn increased our build costs. If these or any other shortages are sustained in any significant manner, they could result in delays to construction or a further increase in the cost of our materials and services. A broader economic downturn in light of the COVID-19 pandemic could result in reduced construction activity, lower demand for homes and increased incidence of customers’ inability to pay their accounts, even after the COVID-19 pandemic has ended. Moreover, economic hardship for some segments of the population, combined with social distancing and quarantine orders that restrict individuals’ ability to engage in “non-essential” commercial activity (including construction activity in some instances) could result in a reduction in sales. Although construction and sales activity was allowed to resume in the UK in May 2020, the outlook for the national economy remains unclear. House prices in the UK have generally increased following the first national lockdown, however some of our partners may be reluctant to embark on construction projects in the current market due to increased economic uncertainty, the possibility that property values will decrease (including due to lack of availability of debt financing), low investor confidence and concern that any economic downturn could adversely affect occupational demand and rental growth. The long term impacts of the current situation remain unknown and could impact construction and sales through, for example, more restrictive on-site working practices, mortgage availability, increased borrowing rates and reduced levels of government assistance and stimulus. It is not possible to predict accurately the duration of the current market conditions resulting from the pandemic, the extent to which COVID-19 government stimulus programs will remain in place or the timing or strength of any future recovery of the UK economy. Furthermore, we are exposed to the risk of default by customers who have agreed to purchase homes from us, suppliers who have agreed to supply materials and/or pay volume-related rebates to us under framework agreements, and others with whom we have entered into financial and other arrangements. A number of our customers and suppliers have been and may continue to be adversely affected by the worldwide pandemic, quarantine orders, financial uncertainty, disruptions to capital and credit markets and decreased demand for their services. Our exposure to default by counterparties may increase if economic conditions deteriorate. Moreover, we may be unable to procure supplies in a sufficient quantity or timely manner, especially where suppliers have shut down manufacturing sites and furloughed employees. If such supply disruptions were to occur, we may not ----- be able to develop alternative sources quickly on commercially reasonable terms, or at all. In the event that any of our key customers or suppliers, or a significant number of smaller customers and suppliers, are further adversely affected by these risks, we may face further reductions in revenue, loss of customers and disruptions in supply which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. There may also be significant fluctuations in our operating results and the results for any period may not be indicative of results for any future period.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on maintaining strong relationships with Local Authorities, Homes England, Registered Providers and housing associations, and these entities may be subject to reduced funding and other changes to their operations due to economic and political factors outside of their control.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is based primarily on a partnership model, we primarily develop in collaboration with partners that have some form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility) in the relevant development, primarily land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) and Registered Providers. As a result, our success depends on our ability to maintain strong relationships with Local Authorities, Homes England, Registered Providers, housing associations and other public entities in the UK. Approximately 79% of the plots in our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021 were being developed under the partnership model. Our partnership projects are often awarded through competitive public procurement processes and often based on the Local Authority or housing association’s perception of a developer’s expertise, design quality, reputation, price and value. Non-financial criteria, such as planning and design capability, customer service record, track record of delivering high-quality homes with minimal defects, delivery capacity and proposals to address social and economic sustainability issues, typically account for more than 50% of an applicant’s score in public procurement processes. As a result, our reputation and relationships with partner organizations are critical to the success of our business. In addition, Local Authorities often have oversight and authority over multiple potential development sites and previous Local Authority clients are thus an important source of referral and repeat business for our business. We are one of the largest strategic delivery partners of Homes England. As of July 31, 2021, we had directly and indirectly accessed approximately £450 million of funding initiatives to facilitate the delivery and acceleration of housing outputs, secured approximately 9,200 plots on 38 different sites for development through Homes England’s Delivery Partner Panel (“DPP”) and delivered or were in the process of delivering over 3,055 homes in partnership on Homes England land over the last 12 years. As a result, maintaining a strong working relationship with Homes England is important to our operations, as a deterioration of this relationship could result in both reputational and financial consequences for us. Furthermore, if Homes England were to make changes to the way it conducts the DPP or otherwise change the way it disposes of public land, this could have an adverse impact on our ability to access development opportunities through the panel or increase the competition for development opportunities. Homes England is currently preparing to launch its successor to the DPP on September 1, 2021, known as the Delivery Partner Dynamic Purchasing System (“DPDPS”). The DPDPS is designed to modernize the bidding process through the use of a digital system which encourages new entrants to the market, and thereby simplifies the process for housebuilders to join the list of preferred developers and bid for land. With this new system, housebuilders will still have to ‘qualify’ to be able to join the list of preferred developers, but they will be able to apply to join at any time, rather than only upon renewal of the delivery partner panel once every four years, as is currently the case. We have submitted our application and had confirmation we have been appointed to be part of the DPDPS, which is not expected to be used to procure schemes until late 2021. Although DPDPS will not change the way in which schemes are procured and the legal structure under which they will be delivered on sites larger than 70 plots, the new system is likely to increase competition for development opportunities with Homes England. A material decline in opportunities sourced through Homes England could have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Local authorities, Homes England, housing associations and other public entities in the UK can be subject to reduced funding and other changes to their operations and structure as a result of both economic and political factors outside of their control. This could, in turn, lead to such bodies curtailing their development activities, which would reduce the partnership opportunities available to us. Any reduction in development activities by these entities would likely have a relatively greater impact on Keepmoat than on many of our competitors given our partnership-focused business model. In addition, governmental bodies may seek to influence or change the scope or direction of Local Authorities’ activities for political reasons and, even without direct pressure, changes in national Government policy may affect Local Authorities’ decisions on local planning issues. Although all of ----- the three main political parties currently support an expansion of the supply of affordable homes in the UK, this may change in the future. In the event that there is a change of Government or economic and political factors which result in a loss of support for, or a major reorganization of, the public sector bodies with which we work, we may need to rebuild our relationships or risk losing partnership opportunities with these organizations. If we are unable to maintain our relationships with these organizations, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The availability, cost, quality and location of land are fundamental to our business, and failure to identify and secure suitable land could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.
Subsubsection Text: Our business relies upon our ability to acquire land at appropriate prices and in appropriate locations. We do not have any control over the volume and timing of partnership land pipeline opportunities, and if we are unable to continue to secure land through our partnership model with housing associations and Local Authorities, we may be unable to source land at commercially acceptable prices, on favorable terms or at all. Failure to identify suitable land, obstacles in the purchasing process, failure to manage land purchases to meet the demands of the business or increases in the costs of such purchases could mean that we are unable to obtain an adequate supply of land. Consequentially, an inability to source sufficient suitable land that meets the requirements of our business model could affect our volume growth targets. In addition, increased demand for land from our competitors may lead to increases in the prices that we are required to pay for land, which may affect the profitability of our developments. Our development activities are also affected by the planning status of the land we secure, and there may be changes in law or regulation between the time when initial planning permission is given for a particular site and the time at which we begin construction, which could cause delays, increase costs, reduce the expected rate of return or make a proposed development financially unviable. See “—We are subject to local and national _planning policies which have an impact on our operations.”_ The timing of our land acquisitions may also have a material impact on our financial condition, including the returns we are able to generate from our developments. We occasionally source plots through speculative land purchases for certain of our sites, particularly when seeking to increase presence in new regions. These speculative purchases generally involve material upfront investments of our own capital. In such cases, we may pay higher average prices for plots as we compete with other home builders for available land, which may in turn reduce our margins and return on capital employed and increase reliance on our current ongoing projects. Unforeseen events may also have a negative impact on our ability to source land, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. See “—The net realizable value of the _Group’s build work-in-progress (“WIP”) and land may decline.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The UK home building market is competitive.
Subsubsection Text: Although we largely operate a non-traditional home building business model through the use of our partnership model, we compete with traditional home builders for sites, financing, partnership opportunities with Local Authorities and housing associations, materials, skilled labor and home buyers. Within the wider housing market, we also compete for home buyers with second-hand housing sales. Our competitors include other local, regional and national home builders, and new competitors may enter the home building market. Some of these competitors may enjoy greater sales and financial resources, lower funding costs, or lower operational costs than us and their participation or entry into the partnerships market, in particular, could impair our ability to win public procurement processes at economically viable levels or at all. For example, in certain invitations to tender issued by Local Authorities or housing associations, bids that propose payment structures including deposits and/or early up front land price payments attract higher scores. To the extent our competitors are increasingly willing to make such deposits and/or early up front land price payments, we may be required to make bids on the same basis in order to win these public procurement processes, which could in turn increase our up-front costs and reduce our ability to use our preferred capital light operating model. Many of these competitors also have longstanding relationships with housing associations, Local Authorities, subcontractors and suppliers in the markets in which we operate. Furthermore, in an increasingly competitive sales environment, there is increased risk that we may fail to sell houses as quickly as anticipated, may need to increase selling incentives or marketing costs or may be forced to sell at lower than projected prices. Any or all of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The inability of our customers to procure a mortgage or other form of funding, or increased costs of financing, could lead to decreased sales and reservations and the cancellation of sale contracts.
Subsubsection Text: The growth of the housing market depends largely on the ability of customers to secure financing to buy a home, as well as on how confident they are about their ability to make regular payments on their mortgages over multiple subsequent years. During periods of weak economic conditions or strong house price inflation, prospective homebuyers’ purchasing power often depends on their ability to borrow funds and access Government stimulus programs. Our sales are therefore impacted by banks’ and other lenders’ willingness and ability to provide financing to prospective homebuyers, and the terms on which they are willing and able to do so. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 91% of our private sales buyers purchased homes with the assistance of mortgages. Any decrease in the availability of mortgages is likely to have a negative impact on our customers’ ability to purchase new houses. Changes to lending criteria such as increased checks on personal finances or the introduction of more onerous lending restrictions could have a material adverse effect on the ability of home buyers to secure a mortgage. Similarly, changes to mortgage terms, including loan-to-value ratios and other lending criteria, average duration and interest rates are also likely to have a direct impact on demand for the housing. In particular, actual and expected monetary policies of the Bank of England, including both the speed and magnitude of any interest rate increases, are likely to have an impact on the interest rates that banks and other lenders provide. Increases in the base rate have previously had a negative impact on the UK property market because mortgage interest rates have experienced a corresponding increase, thereby making it more expensive for prospective buyers to purchase residential property. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Bank of England base rate was 0.1%. Despite the current low base rate environment, levels of mortgage lending throughout the UK remain low compared to those of certain other developed countries. Prospective buyers who can obtain a mortgage at current interest rates may also be deterred by the possibility of increased mortgage interest rates in the future. Higher interest rates (and, in turn, higher monthly interest payments) may also make mortgages unobtainable or unaffordable for some prospective buyers. Investor buyers also are sensitive to interest rate fluctuations, as higher interest rates negatively affect their investment returns. The Bank of England may raise its base rate at any time, which could have an adverse impact on transaction volumes and prices in the UK’s residential property market, and may in turn reduce the volume and value of property transactions facilitated by Keepmoat and the revenue that we derive from them. In particular, the Bank of England may be compelled to increase the base rate as a result of inflation. Any increase in the costs of mortgage financing in the future may make it more difficult for us to sell homes, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Future changes in Government policy and stimulus programs may also adversely affect the ability of our customers to obtain Government financial assistance and mortgages. See “—A majority of our business is secured _or supported either directly or indirectly from various Government sources, and changes in local or Government funds, loans, grants or subsidies, or changes to or the discontinuation of mortgage assistance schemes or equity loan schemes (including in particular Help to Buy) could significantly impact our business.” Our focus is selling_ affordable homes to first-time buyers, and if it becomes more difficult to secure a mortgage or obtain Government financial assistance, first-time buyers may be particularly impacted, as such customers tend to require loans with higher loan-to-value ratios. Although we review a prospective buyer’s ability to qualify for a mortgage or other form of funding prior to entering into a contract and reporting the transaction as a sale, this initial review is based solely on information provided to us by the buyer, without independent verification. For reference, we do not contract on a house sale to a customer without a formal mortgage offer from a mortgage lender. To the extent there were a significant deterioration in the ability of our customers to obtain mortgage approvals or otherwise finance their home purchases, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations are affected by the cyclical nature of the home building and construction industries as well as fluctuations in the price and supply of materials.
Subsubsection Text: The home building industry tends to be cyclical and is dependent on the level of construction-related expenditures in the residential sector, public investments and public and private spending on infrastructure projects. The home building industry is particularly sensitive to factors such as GDP growth, interest rates, the cost of mortgage financing for residential construction, inflation, consumer confidence, income growth (in real terms), increases in the cost of living and other macroeconomic factors. Political instability or changes in Government policy may also negatively affect the home building industry. Moreover, demand in the home ----- building industry may be affected by demographic trends, such as ageing and declining populations in mature markets, changes in the average number of persons living in one household and domestic and international migration trends. The cyclicality of the construction industry also impacts the supply of materials and labor. During periods of market contraction, labor force participants leave the market, sometimes permanently, to retrain in other professions or move elsewhere in search of work. As markets recover, demand for labor increases and the associated impact on the cost and availability of labor can impact our business. We have several key suppliers, contractors and subcontractors in the various regions in which we operate, with whom we regularly contract to provide construction and various other services for the development of the Group’s sites. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, our top supplier, which is a materials merchant, represented 30.6% of our total expenditure for direct materials. If any of our suppliers fail to provide timely or adequate services, labor, equipment or raw materials, we may be required to source these products and services at a higher price than anticipated and may face delays at our project sites until we are able to identify an appropriate alternative supplier, contractor or subcontractor. Although we attempt to control subcontractor rate increases on our developments by fixing subcontractor prices over a phase, or part-phase, of a development through the use of “all risk” contracts and by matching subcontractor agreements to our agreements with land owners, we cannot eliminate our exposure to cyclical cost increases during development which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. See “—Our customers and suppliers _are exposed to risks associated with the current COVID-19 pandemic and its ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry.”_ Although we endeavor to utilize our group supply chain suppliers across all regions, our materials suppliers vary in each region in which we operate due to the specific requirements of our projects. Although we include materials cost estimates in our tenders, materials are subject to price as well as availability fluctuations, such that even if we include flexibility in our tenders for an increase in costs, we still may not be able to source the necessary materials, which could affect our ability to deliver schemes to program. We are heavily impacted by our ability to source essential materials such as bricks and blocks. The supply of essential materials may be delayed or interrupted due to factors beyond our control, such as materials shortages or disruptions in the supply chain. See “—We could be adversely affected by uncertainty, disruption or other _consequences of Brexit.” In addition, the cyclicality of the construction industry impacts the supply of materials_ so that in times of market contraction, production is scaled back and therefore when markets recover there can be a lag in the supply chain which may lead to increased prices. Bricks, for example, can be difficult to source in the UK during periods of increased building activity and are a necessary material for our operations. A shortage in the supply of bricks in the UK typically results in the need to import bricks from overseas, which in turn may result in an increase in brick prices owing to transport costs and delays in their availability, both of which could result in significant increases in the cost of our construction projects and delay completions of sites. Any disruption to a regular supply of materials could result in project delays and increased costs if alternative suppliers are unable to provide timely replacements at competitive prices. Moreover, we may be unable to pass on any or all of the increased materials costs to our customers. Any price fluctuations or supply interruptions as a result of the foregoing factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We could be adversely affected by the current shortage of HGV drivers in the United Kingdom.
Subsubsection Text: As has been well publicized recently, the UK is currently experiencing a shortage of heavy-goods vehicles (“HGV”) drivers, which has become more visible in the past weeks as the shortage of qualified drivers has resulted in supply chain issues impacting fuel deliveries, forcing some petrol stations to close or limit the supply of fuel available for purchase, and shortages of good deliveries to retailers. The Road Haulage Association has estimated that there could be a shortage in the UK of more than 100,000 drivers, as compared to a pre-COVID total of approximately 600,000 drivers. It has been reported that the current shortage has been partially attributable to Brexit, in which European HGV drivers have opted to work solely within EU countries or have left the UK, in part due to the increase bureaucracy and costs involved in travelling to and from the UK and an estimated 15,000 EU HGV drivers opting to leave the UK given travel restrictions imposed as part of Covid mitigation measures. The shortage has also been blamed on a suspension and delay of an estimated 30,000 HGV qualification tests in 2020 due to the Covid pandemic which resulted in a reduction of an estimated 25,000 potential HGV driver candidates passing the test in 2020 as compared to 2019. With the average age of an HGV driver in the UK of 55 years, the industry has further been vulnerable to relatively high attrition due to retirements as well as changes that have cut earnings of some HGV drivers. The Government has responded by announcing that it is considering ----- measures to recruit and train HGV drivers such as increasing the number of HGV driving tests taking place and providing temporary visas for EU HGV drivers. In addition, many employers have increased salary and have offered bonuses and new driving schemes. However, these measures will most likely take time to have an impact. While we have not yet seen any noticeable impact from the shortfall in HGV drivers, there is a risk that the current shortfall could impact our business in the event that the ongoing HGV driver shortfall results in delays in the supply chain for our raw materials or the inability of our contractors to maintain their workforce necessary to operate the heavy equipment essential for our developments, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. In addition, the shortfall in HGV drivers could increase the cost for raw materials and the costs of our contractors which could be passed on to us, leading to a potential in decreased margins. We will continue to monitor the potential impact of the shortfall in HGV drivers on our business and operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We could be adversely affected by uncertainty, disruption or other consequences of Brexit.
Subsubsection Text: On January 31, 2020, the UK left the EU, entering into a transition period that ended on December 31, 2020. This process is unprecedented in EU history and the effects of Brexit remain uncertain. Uncertainty also exists over the effects of the Trade and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the UK, which provides for the free movement of goods between the UK and the EU and which was entered into on December 24, 2020. In particular, legal uncertainty exists around potentially divergent national laws and regulations in relation to financial laws and regulations, tax and free trade agreements, immigration laws and employment laws which may adversely affect economic or market conditions in the UK, the EU or globally. This uncertainty could contribute to instability in global financial and foreign exchange markets, including volatility in the value of the pound sterling, which could negatively affect our revenues and the broader economic environment on which the home building industry depends. Given that substantially all of our profits are generated from the housing market, a significant negative impact on the UK economy as a result of Brexit could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. In addition, we may face challenges attracting non-British EU workers following Brexit, which could impact our business and growth in the future. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 3.0% of the Group’s employees were non-UK citizens, with the majority being citizens of member states of the EU. However, EU nationals could comprise a part of the Group’s subcontractor workforce and their skillsets are such that, if Brexit materially limits the ability or willingness of those subcontractors to work in the UK, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Brexit may also put pressure on our supply chain. Most of our building supplies are manufactured in the UK and therefore are not directly exposed to future trade arrangements with the EU. However, a portion of the products procured through our network of UK based suppliers are imported from the EU. Additional requirements associated with the importation of goods from the EU could adversely impact our supply chain and increase the costs of imported construction materials. We continue to work closely with those suppliers to monitor the potential impact as the UK adapts to the new trade arrangements with the EU. Any increase in the prices of raw materials as a result of any new trade arrangements may lead to decreased margins.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business depends on the continued availability, viability and cost of subcontractors and other service providers.
Subsubsection Text: Our business model requires us to hire third party subcontractors to provide onsite work. Although our business model has key differences from other traditional home builders, we compete within the same labor pools and changes in the labor market directly impact our costs. When activity in the home building market increases, we tend to face escalating cost pressures associated with shortages of skilled labor, particularly skilled bricklayers. Restrictions on the free movement of people as a result of Brexit and other changes to UK immigration policies could result in tight supply due to reduced availability of skilled labor from outside the UK. Poor availability of labor could significantly impact our ability to operate efficiently and deliver projects on time with high levels of partner and customer satisfaction. See “—We could be adversely affected by uncertainty, disruption or other _consequences of Brexit” and “—Our customers and suppliers are exposed to risks associated with the current COVID-19 pandemic and its ramifications on the wider UK economy and the home building industry.”_ If we are unable to find or hire qualified and reliable third party subcontractors for any of our projects, our ability to successfully complete projects on time or at all could be impaired. Furthermore if any of these third parties fail to provide timely or adequate services, labor, equipment or raw materials, we may be required to source these services and products at a higher price than anticipated and may face delays at our project sites until we are ----- able to identify an appropriate alternative subcontractor. See “—Our results of operations are affected by the _cyclical nature of the home building and construction industries as well as fluctuations in the price and supply of materials.”_ Additionally, as we have experienced from time to time in the past, we are exposed to the risk that the subcontractors that we employ may subsequently become insolvent, causing cost overruns and program delays, thereby increasing the risk that we will be unable to recover costs in relation to any defective work performed by such subcontractors. These risks are compounded during times of economic downturn, as subcontractors or any other third parties that we conduct business with may experience financial difficulties or find it difficult to obtain sufficient financing to fund their deliveries or operations. We are also exposed to the risk of litigation or claims relating to breaches of contract by third party subcontractors. Furthermore, substandard work by subcontractors could result in claims against us for failure to meet required project specifications. If a subcontractor or supplier of goods or services fails financially or is responsible for late or inadequate delivery or poor quality of work on a project, then it could damage our reputation and result in financial losses for us. The insolvency, poor performance or other financial distress of one or more of our subcontractors may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We operate in a highly regulated industry and our businesses are subject to a complex regulatory environment which may change.
Subsubsection Text: We are required to comply with national, local, and other laws and regulations and administrative requirements and policies which relate to, among other matters, planning, developing, building land use, sales, providing or arranging the mortgage market, health and safety, environment, employment, bribery (including under the UK Bribery Act of 2010), competition and money laundering. These laws and regulations and administrative requirements and policies that affect both the housing sector and ancillary sectors, often provide broad discretion to the administering authorities. Any uncertainty or changes in relevant laws, regulations or policies, or the interpretation thereof, may delay or prevent us from being able to achieve our strategic plans, give rise to substantial compliance, remediation and other costs, or could prohibit or severely restrict us from developing and building in certain locations. In addition, following on from incidents such as the Grenfell Tower fire in London in June 2017, regulation has increased around building assessments and fire safety, particularly for tall buildings. In light of such increased regulation, and the fact that we have in the past used combustible paneling material for a limited number of our properties (low-rise dwellings of no more than three stories), there is a risk that properties owned and/or constructed by Keepmoat may in future be considered to have been built with materials that are assessed to be or have the potential to be, the cause of, or a contributing factor to, the spread of fire or other destruction of properties, or compromise residents’ safety. There is also a risk that the Government, regulators or lenders could issue further guidelines in relation to combustible materials, including aluminum composite material cladding, high pressure laminate, and/or wood cladding and/or other external structures including fire safety procedures or otherwise as a result of which it may be necessary for us to remediate our buildings. If such an event occurs, there may be significant costs and expenses to rebuild the property and/or rectify the problem and our returns may decrease. Our brand and reputation may also be harmed. Each aspect of the regulatory environment in which we operate is subject to change. Changes, including (but not limited to) in the following areas could have an adverse impact on our business and operating results: - building regulations; - labor laws; - health and safety regulations; - local and national planning policies (see “—We are subject to local and national planning _policies which have an impact on our operations”);_ - environmental, sustainability and land use requirements; and ----- - regulation regarding provision of mortgages. In particular, we are subject to numerous laws, regulations and policies concerning the protection of health, safety and the environment. For example, in England, changes regarding Part L of the Building Regulations 2010 (“Part L”), are currently in the final stages of consultation, relating to requirements concerning the conservation of fuel and power. The proposed changes are currently anticipated to be released by the end of 2021 and are expected to come into effect from June 2022. The introduction of the changes to Part L as a transitional step towards the proposed ‘Future Homes Standard’ is a direct outcome of the Government’s Energy White Paper commitment to (i) raising the energy performance of buildings by limiting heat losses and excessive solar gains, (ii) ensuring that energy-efficient fixed building services are installed, and (iii) ensuring that the building owner is provided with the information required to maintain the building and its services. Reducing carbon emissions for new build properties remains high on the Government’s and Local Authority partner’s agenda and plays a large part in the design and construction of new build properties. The carbon emission reduction targets set by current Part L standards, alongside the industry’s modern-day good practice standards for air quality, acoustics and overheating, encourage building designers to consider more complex design solutions with bespoke user operational assumptions. If these changes are not reviewed and implemented in a timely manner, there is a risk that we may be non-compliant with the changing building regulations. In addition, changing building regulations are likely to have an impact on our underlying construction costs, with potential additional costs incurred to meet the requirements of increasing standards. The proposed Future Homes Standard is in the early stages of consultation as part of a commitment by the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government to ensure all new homes reduce their carbon dioxide emissions by over 75%, through low carbon heating and “world-leading levels of energy efficiency” by 2025. The Scottish Government is also going through a similar process of reviewing and consulting on proposed changes to current building regulations to significantly reduce the carbon emissions of new homes, so the same risks apply in Scotland as well. Local authorities are already empowered under the Planning and Energy Act 2008 to drive local agendas for sustainability and may ask on this basis for a variety of standards to be applied, including the Zero Carbon Emissions homes standard. This standard is higher than that of the proposed Future Homes Standard and in advance of the current Government roadmap. The above proposed changes could have a significant impact on housebuilder operations and will affect new and, potentially, existing sites (to the extent existing sites are under development at the time the changes take effect), subject to any transitional arrangements and/or accommodations for existing sites that may be put into place. The proposed Future Homes Standard will also include the development of unproven gas free solutions and there is therefore the risk of reputational damage for housebuilders if solutions fail to work as intended and create high levels of energy usage and running costs for customers. Delivery may also be affected as supply chains need to be developed for low carbon energy solutions. In addition, the Government has introduced a set of principles and guidance for the UK construction industry titled ‘Biodiversity Net Gain’. This initiative is designed to encourage developers to incorporate appropriate natural habitat and ecological features to offset the effects of the development in order to stem the loss of biodiversity through development and restore ecological networks. Compliance with these principles and guidance could result in an additional cost to us. Furthermore, the nature of the principles and guidance could result in a disadvantage to the development of brownfield sites, which represent a significant part of our business. See also “—Ownership, leasing or occupation of land as well as home building carries potential environmental _risks and liabilities, including liability under claims for damages as a result of use of hazardous materials, including asbestos.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Difficulties and complications encountered in connection with the construction process and other events that may arise in the course of construction could disrupt our business and could result in substantial increases in total costs or adversely affect our returns.
Subsubsection Text: When securing a development opportunity and agreeing the financial terms of the development with our partners (where relevant) prior to construction, we make cost estimates which are dependent upon assumptions, estimates and judgments which may ultimately prove to be inaccurate. While we attempt to mitigate this risk by taking reasonable steps to ensure that our risk management and financial and operational procedures, controls and systems are appropriate for our businesses, there is no guarantee that significant unanticipated costs will not arise. If we fail to accurately assess expected costs, revenue or risks on a particular contract, then we may fail to achieve our expected returns. Our returns depend on costs being controlled and projects being completed on time. For example, cost overruns, whether due to inefficiency, poor design, faulty estimates, insufficient oversight, omissions, failure to use systems or comply with our processes, unforeseen technical conditions, cost escalation ----- for materials (such as timber framing, bricks, concrete, polymer and steel) (including due to inflation), and/or cost overruns by (or increased rates of) subcontractors or other factors, can result in a lower return on a project. Should significant unanticipated costs arise, they could have a material adverse impact on our operating results, business prospects and financial condition. In addition, failure to follow best practice guidelines could mean that projects are not delivered on time or do not meet agreed quality, appropriate health and safety or environmental standards and therefore do not meet customer expectations and may give rise to contractual or other liabilities. Our most significant costs are our subcontractor and supplier costs, and we rely on local and regional subcontractors from a variety of trades. Our subcontractors generally provide us with services on the basis of fixed-term, fixed-price contracts based on agreed specifications while our suppliers generally agree to make deliveries on the basis of pre-agreed prices. However, although we budget construction costs for each site before construction begins, building and construction costs can increase above anticipated amounts as a result of unforeseen events, which may result in the pre-agreed contractual prices not applying even where such arrangements are in place. We may face additional costs or delays related to, among other things, unexpected technical challenges, changes in development specifications, exceptional weather conditions that delay work, labor shortages, accidents during construction, the insolvency or poor performance of a subcontractor, environmental factors, changes in consumer preferences (leading to the need to change design once construction has already begun) or new regulations or legal requirements. For larger projects, these risks are inherently greater. If circumstances change, a lower profit or a loss on a project may result. In addition, if a subcontractor’s or supplier’s cost estimates or quotes provided to us are incorrect, we may incur additional costs or be required to source products and services at a higher price than anticipated, as well as face delays at our project sites if the estimate is incorrect by a large enough margin that the project is better served by finding an alternative contractor or supplier. These unforeseen events could have a negative impact on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. A number of the contracts we enter into in connection with the development of our sites include certain delivery milestones. If delays to these projects lead to a failure to meet deadlines, it could result in a breach of contract for which we could be liable. The typical approach that we adopt when circumstances arise which may prevent us from meeting delivery milestones is to negotiate with our counterparties to seek to amend the contract as necessary. However, there can be no assurance that such counterparties would be amenable to such changes. Failure to meet delivery milestones could affect our reputation and future prospects, expose us to additional costs and result in contractual penalties or the calling of surety bonds, where applicable, that may impact our profit margins and result in the termination of contracts. Furthermore, any delays or underperformance in our projects may lead to conflicting demands on resources allocated to other projects. Also, for some projects, we may be required to build commercial spaces and mixed-use facilities, areas that are not part of our core business and expertise and therefore pose additional execution risks during construction. The failure to meet project deadlines and targets, in either the construction or sales process, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A major health and safety incident could be costly in terms of potential liabilities and reputational damage.
Subsubsection Text: Health and safety performance is critical to the success of all areas of our business. Worksites are inherently dangerous places and operating in the home building industry poses certain health and safety risks. Some of our operations are conducted at sites in which residents are in occupancy which adds additional risk to the inherently dangerous nature of a worksite. Any significant accident or health and safety failure could result in significant harm to any person present, including any current resident or member of the general public at or near the worksite. There can be no assurance that a major accident or safety incident will not cause significant bodily injury, physical harm or death of any person present or nearby. Any failure in health and safety procedures or performance may result in penalties for non-compliance with relevant regulatory requirements, and a failure which results in a major or significant health and safety incident may be costly in terms of potential liabilities incurred as a result, including significant compensation payments and fines, and may lead to operational failure. Furthermore, such a failure could also generate significant adverse publicity and have a negative impact on our reputation and our ability to win new business (in particular with respect to entering into partnerships with public bodies, which is a key part of our strategy), and may expose management to personal criminal liability, which in turn may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations are affected by seasonal effects.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is, to a certain extent, dependent on weather conditions and is subject to seasonality. Historically, our revenues and levels of working capital vary during the course of the year due to higher volumes of completions taking place in certain months of the year. As a result, our debt profile has grown and contracted over the course of the financial year, consistent with certain seasonal trends. Typically, the majority of our reservations for open market sales are made in January to March and August to October (with the latter correlated to the start of new school years). Our ability to manage the timeline from the engagement and planning phase to the exchange of contract and legal completion is, therefore, one of the factors that affects the timing of completions. Although we generally have a significant degree of flexibility in managing the phasing of completions and typically aim to stagger the timing of our completions to the extent practicable, the impact of weather on building activity and plot delivery has increased the likelihood of a peak in completions in the late summer and early autumn. In addition, prior to the change of the KM Group’s financial year end from March 31 to October 31 in 2018, divisional efforts to achieve targets and maximize sales for the financial year end led to a peak of completions in March. This had an effect on our results of operations for the financial year ended October 31, 2019, as our incentive scheme for that financial year remained tied to an end date of March 31. However, we do not expect this to have an impact on our financial results in any subsequent years. For the financial year ended October 31, 2021 we have amended our incentive targets to include an additional measure tied to half-year targets, in order to achieve a more levelled number of completions throughout the financial year. The above factors may lead to volatility in our quarterly financial results. These factors that affect the phasing of completions through a financial year tend to result in a peak in the number of plot completions, and accordingly revenue and profit, to the last quarter of each financial year. Results of a single fiscal quarter or half year might therefore not be a reliable basis for the expectations of a full financial year and may not be comparable with the results in the other fiscal quarters or half year. Factors that affect our peak selling seasons can have a disproportionate impact on our performance in a particular period.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to local and national planning policies which have an impact on our operations.
Subsubsection Text: Local and national planning policies have an impact on the financial performance of housing development. Our ability to obtain the necessary and timely planning permissions is dependent on our ability to meet the relevant regulatory and planning requirements, including detailed planning consents and technical approvals. Planning policies can restrict the availability of new land for which suitable planning permission is available and closely control how land is developed. For example, planning permissions can prescribe specific conditions on matters including density, types of housing and availability of car parking spaces. The estimated number of plots and the economic feasibility of development represented by our land may also be reduced due to planning considerations. As of July 31, 2021, we did not have planning permissions (detailed or outline) for approximately 21% of our land pipeline of 24,654 plots. Although we have generally been successful in obtaining similar planning consents in the past, there can be no certainty that we will obtain planning permission for schemes which currently lack them on a timely or cost-effective basis, or at all, and the final permission that we obtain may vary significantly from the assumptions made at the time of acquisition. For example, the gross development value of the site may be lower than anticipated, or the costs to complete development of the site may be higher than anticipated, potentially causing significant deterioration in a project’s value. Certain planning authorities continue to be under-resourced, affecting their capacity to manage applications and develop local plans. Additionally, the planning processes for many of our projects involve public consultations, which may result in adjustments to the preferred development plan, adverse planning outcomes or negative publicity. We may also be required to make significant expenditures on community infrastructure and facilities and provide a minimum amount of affordable housing as a condition of receiving planning permission, as well as provide other community benefits and payments due under the Community Infrastructure Levy. Any failure to obtain planning permissions in line with our development plans or at all may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Additionally, we are subject to the risk of non-compliance with planning conditions or planning obligations connected with planning consents. If we are found to have not complied with these planning conditions or planning obligations, our development could be deemed unlawful or subject to service of enforcement notices or, in severe cases, result in an inability to sell affected plots. ----- While the Group has developed policies and procedures to comply with existing requirements, there can be no assurance that these requirements will not change. For example, in 2012, the NPPF was published which was aimed at, among other matters, simplifying planning and ensuring local communities are the keystone of the planning system. The NPPF underwent a substantive revision in July 2018, resulting in more than 80 reforms, and was further updated in January 2021. These changes introduced wide scale updates relating to sustainable development, including references to certain parts of the United Nations’ SDGs, which may impact our operations and strategy in this area. Other amendments to the NPPF that have been proposed relate to plan-makers being required to align growth and infrastructure, improvements in the environment and the mitigation of climate change (including by making effective use of land in urban areas) and adaption to its effects. The proposed changes to the NPPF that concern design quality, new local Design Codes and new timescale policy for larger-scale developments may cause some practical transitional difficulties, as councils, developers and local communities grapple with the creation of new codes and procedures, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Furthermore, the UK has recently completed a ‘Planning for the Future’ consultation, which could lead to significant changes to the planning process. The ultimate aim of this consultation is to simplify the process for obtaining planning permission. However, the introduction of new planning law would be subject to the interpretation and implementation of Local Authorities which could introduce uncertainty into the process. The planning reform is currently being reviewed by the new Secretary of State, which is likely to delay its introduction. Additionally, there has been significant discussion in the media and among certain politicians in the UK relating to “land banking,” a practice whereby a person or entity obtains land but does not develop it or develops it many years after its purchase.
