Detractors of “land banking” argue that the practice contributes to inflated real estate prices by limiting the amount of land available for sale in a given area. The Company can hold real estate for long periods before obtaining planning permission, resolving technical constraints, developing the land and selling it. While we do not believe we are engaged in “land banking,” as we generally seek to develop our sites immediately once detailed planning consent and all conditions are discharged (subject to market conditions and any legal or technical impediments), developing large sites requires an extended period of time and our development plans sometimes include developing on a phased basis. Any change in legislation aimed at forcing land owners to develop or sell their real estate holdings within certain prescribed periods (e.g. “use it or lose it” policies) or which impose additional requirements or taxes on outline planning consents could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. In June 2021, the UK Government launched a new initiative called “First Homes” aimed at making home ownership attainable for local people and key workers who are first-time buyers. This new tenure of home ownership is expected to be incorporated into planning law in the near future and will become part of a local authority’s affordable housing policy. This tenure of home ownership will allow people to purchase a home at a minimum 30% discount to market value in perpetuity, subject to eligibility criteria. This requirement will be part of the affordable housing obligations of a planning permission (Section 106 agreement) for a site and the costs associated with it will be deducted from the land value. The same percentage discount must then be passed on with the sale of the property to future buyers (who must also be first-time buyers). The initial sale must be at a price no higher than £250,000 (or £420,000 in Greater London) after the discount has been applied. Changes made to the planning system to support this initiative now require that First Homes properties should account for at least 25% of all affordable housing units delivered by developers through planning obligations. However, as this initiative is in the early stages of implementation, the longer term impact of the initiative and any additional changes made to the planning system in relation to it are not yet known.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Failure in our procedures, systems and internal controls, including with respect to due diligence and design, could expose us to operational losses, contract and execution risk or violations of law and regulation.
Subsubsection Text: We develop a large number of sites simultaneously in different regions, which requires us to conduct a large number of operations efficiently and accurately. These operations include, among other things, evaluating the purchase of the site, conducting environmental, title and other due diligence investigations, designing the layout and technical aspects of the development, sourcing consultants, materials and subcontractors and managing subcontractors, contractual and statutory commitments. While we seek to take reasonable steps to ensure that our procedures, systems and controls are appropriate for our businesses, errors by employees, consultants or subcontractors, failure to comply with statutory and regulatory requirements, failings or inadequacies in internal control processes, material or equipment failures or natural disasters or the failure of external systems including those of our suppliers or counterparties or statutory bodies, could result in operational losses that could adversely impact our business, results of operations, financial condition, prospects and relationships with customers. ----- In addition, our existing compliance processes and controls may not be sufficient to prevent or detect non-compliance, wrongful practices, fraud and violations of law by our employees, contractors, customers, intermediaries, consultants, joint venture partners or sales agents. We may have limited control over such parties’ actions due to the nature of the business relationship. If any such parties receive or grant inappropriate benefits or engage in corrupt, fraudulent or other unfair or illegal business practices (including, without limitation, tax evasion, fraudulent tax schemes, anticompetitive conduct, bribery, corruption, money laundering, modern slavery or breaches of consumer protection laws), we could incur or become subject to significant financial losses, legal sanctions, penalties, or reputational damage. In addition, we could lose relationships with public sector entities, our partners (including public sector partners) and customers, and those parties may therefore be entitled to terminate their contracts with us. In particular, as much of our business involves tendering for Government contracts that are awarded on the basis of both financial and non-financial criteria (including compliance), compliance issues may prejudice our ability to participate in or win such competitive bidding processes for a significant period of time. See “—Our business depends in part on a strong image and reputation, and any _negative impact on our image and reputation could adversely affect our business.” For example, in 2019/2020 we_ conducted a record keeping audit and review of the types of our development projects that qualify as “Estate Agency Work” pursuant to the Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information on the Payer) Regulations 2017 (the “Regulations”) and as a result require us to conduct Know Your Customer (“KYC”) procedures for these activities in compliance with the Regulations. We reviewed our internal anti-money laundering processes and procedures with the assistance of an outside adviser, and found that application of the Regulations affected a wider range of development projects than originally envisaged and approximately a quarter of developments projects at that time. Following the review, we made a series of changes to our internal policies and procedures which included going beyond the requirements of the Regulations and expanding our KYC procedures to all customers, of which we notified the HMRC in June 2020. As we expand, we may also be exposed to new clients, suppliers and subcontractors. Although we have longstanding relationships with many of our partners, there can be no guarantee that our systems and procedures will insulate us from errors in site valuations, failure to identify material issues in the due diligence process or errors in the design process (including those that result in failure to comply with statutory or regulatory requirements). Additionally, any delay in responding to changes in these laws and regulations, particularly in light of evolving standards and potential new implementing legislation, may result in penalties for non-compliance with relevant regulatory requirements. Monitoring and ensuring best practices for our risk management and internal controls may become increasingly expensive for us in the future, and such risks may be more acute when we undertake larger-scale projects or during periods of intense activity. Our internal controls and procedures, policies and our risk management systems may be unable to adequately address all such risks of non-compliance, which could have a material negative impact on our reputation, business activities, financial position and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our rights in the plots of land that comprise our land pipeline may be limited and we may be subject to uncertainties associated with the land contracts we enter into as part of our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our rights in the plots comprising our land pipeline are generally split into three categories: (i) those sites and plots for which we have legally completed the deal, (ii) sites and plots that are held under contract (often a conditional contract), and (iii) those for which we have been appointed preferred developer by the land vendor, but which have not yet progressed to contract. Our legal interest in the sites in our land pipeline can take the form of a freehold interest in the land or alternatively take the form of a development lease or license (which provides us with development rights and exclusivity). On sites where our legal interest takes the form of a development lease or license and we have defaulted on that site, we could be forced to forfeit our development rights and exclusivity over that site, retaining no residual interest in the land. Conversely, traditional housebuilders that buy their sites and plots with an upfront land payment typically receive the freehold interest in a site, which they retain until the individual homes are sold. Through our partnership-focused business model, we enter into a variety of arrangements in order to access plots for development, including conditional land purchase contracts, development agreements, overarching framework agreements, leases and building licenses. Under conditional land purchase contracts, our obligation to purchase the land is generally subject to the receipt of planning consent that is acceptable to us. As there is uncertainty regarding whether the conditions in such contracts will be satisfied, and the timing thereof, these commitments are not recognized as liabilities on our balance sheet unless or until the applicable conditionality is removed or it becomes reasonably likely (in our estimate) that we may receive the requisite ----- planning consents and satisfy the necessary conditions. To the extent such contracts become unconditional, we will need to commit funds to complete such purchases. Additionally, the plots in our land pipeline over which we hold title are often the subject of security, including legal charges or parent company guarantees granted in favor of the vendor to secure the performance of our obligations under a development agreement. Similarly, for the majority of plots in our land pipeline, our only rights in such plots are those granted pursuant to comprehensive development/framework agreements that we enter into with vendors (which do not confer rights to proceed with development without a separate development agreement). Accordingly, in the event that we fail to deliver a scheme or otherwise breach our obligations under our development agreements, our vendors may enforce their security or terminate our rights under such agreements. Any extinguishment of rights in the plots in our land pipeline may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in privacy laws could adversely affect our ability to interact effectively with third parties.
Subsubsection Text: We currently hold, and have previously held, personal data on a variety of parties, including suppliers, employees, future employees, building users, subcontractors or potential subcontractors and customers or potential customers who acquire or seek to acquire houses from us. We have engaged, and expect to continue engaging, in various direct marketing activities to source customers to buy our housing units. As a result, we are subject to data protection legislation (including the General Data Protection Regulation (EU 2016/679), as it forms part of the law of the United Kingdom by virtue of the EUWA (the “GDPR”)) and the UK Data Protection Act 2018 (the “UK Data Protection Act”). Non-compliance with the GDPR or UK Data Protection Act, or technical defects resulting in a leak or the misuse of such data, could result in damage to our reputation and otherwise harm our business. The GDPR, which came into effect on May 25, 2018, and was immediately binding across all Member States of the EU, is a privacy regime regarding the protection of natural persons in relation to the processing of personal data and the free movement of such data. The GDPR requires companies that process personal data about EU subjects (either as “data controllers” or as “data processors”) to comply with a large number of obligations related to, for example, (i) the processing of personal data including transparency, data minimization, accuracy, storage limitation, security and confidentiality; (ii) the ability of the controller to demonstrate compliance with such principles (accountability); (iii) the obligation to identify a legal basis before the processing; and (iv) the rights of data subjects, such as, among others, transparency, a right of access, the right to rectification and the right to erasure. The GDPR requires companies to implement a number of formal processes and policies to review and document the privacy implications of the development, acquisition, or use of all new products, technologies or types of data. Although we have implemented measures to comply with the GDPR, we cannot ensure that we remain fully compliant with its obligations under the GDPR. Non-compliance may be met with significant penalties including fines of up to 4% of total annual worldwide turnover or €20 million (whichever is higher), depending on the type and severity of the breach. The fine may be imposed instead of, or in addition to, measures that may be ordered by supervisory authorities (such as the request to cease processing). Compliance with the GDPR is a rigorous and time-intensive process that may increase our cost of doing business and the failure to comply with these laws could subject us to significant fines and sanctions. In addition, we do not currently have specific data security insurance coverage and cannot guarantee that our general liability insurance coverage will be sufficient to cover all or any liabilities in the event of a breach of our data security systems. Should one or more of these risks materialize, they could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Adverse consequences could occur as a result of changes in tax law or uncertainties in the interpretation and application thereof or as a result of Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs (“HMRC”) challenging our tax treatment of certain matters.
Subsubsection Text: Tax rules, including stamp duty land tax provisions and their interpretation, may change, and new taxes may be introduced, such as the additional stamp duty recently imposed on second homes. Furthermore, uncertainties can arise as a result of differences in interpretation or application of existing tax law. Any change in our tax status, in taxation legislation or its interpretation, or in HMRC practice, could affect the value of property we hold, the average selling price of homes, potential sales and post-tax returns. References in this Offering Memorandum concerning taxation are based upon current tax law and practice that are subject to change, possibly with retrospective effect. Any such change could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. ----- Due to the size and scope of our business, there are a number of matters that HMRC might examine in detail for any given year. Our potential exposure and the likelihood of HMRC raising a challenge in connection with any matters is difficult to assess. If HMRC successfully challenges any matters or if other potential tax matters result in unfavorable outcomes, additional tax liabilities and adverse publicity may follow, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any inability to obtain additional surety bonds could limit our future growth.
Subsubsection Text: We are often required to provide surety bonds to secure our performance under construction contracts, development agreements and other arrangements. As of July 31, 2021, we had £18.2 million in surety bonds and £74.9 million of infrastructure bonds outstanding. We have obtained facilities to provide the requisite volume of surety bonds to meet our current needs, and currently have substantial headroom under those facilities. However, further growth may require that we obtain additional surety facilities. Our ability to obtain additional surety bonds, whether from the NHBC or other providers of bond lines, primarily depends upon our financial rating, past performance, management expertise and the capacity of the surety market. For example, when negotiating additional surety bonds with the NHBC, consideration is given to the number of plot registrations completed over the prior four-year period, the group’s rating with the NHBC and the ability to demonstrate how existing bonds are being managed and released in a timely way (for example, bonds covering roads and sewers works on site are released when they are progressed towards adoption by the Local Authority highways department and water utility companies). A number of factors could limit our ability to obtain appropriate levels of performance bond coverage, including (i) our ability to maintain our current “premium” NHBC rating (ii) changes to our claims record (iii) any changes to surety providers’ requirements or policies (iv) the failure of a surety company, particularly where we cannot get the necessary consent from the issuer’s lenders, and (v) the market’s capacity to provide bonds sufficient for our growth, which was restricted from 2008 to 2011, when surety bonds in the UK became difficult to obtain and their costs increased as a result of the financial crisis. The occurrence of any of these events could affect our ability to compete effectively for new work and may have an adverse impact on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have in the past sold, and in the future may sell, certain of our homes to customers with a leasehold instead of a freehold interest, and any potential changes to our current legal regime regarding leasehold properties, including any retrospective application of new laws or regulations, could have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.
Subsubsection Text: We usually sell our homes as freeholds. However, we have in the past sold, and in the future may sell, certain homes as leaseholds. With a freehold property, the buyer acquires the building and the land on which it stands. With a leasehold property, the buyer only acquires the lease from the freeholder for a fixed period of time, often between 90 and 999 years. After the lease expires, the buyer has no further legal interest in the property. Leaseholders are typically required to pay annual ground rent to the freeholder of the land on which the property sits. Additionally, with the sale of apartments customers will also have to pay a service charge for maintenance of common areas. Dependent on how much of the communal space (green areas) on a development site is adopted for maintenance by a local authority, a customer may also have to contribute to an estate service charge on maintained parts of the overall development. In addition, leaseholders may face restrictions in relation to, or need to receive permission before, making certain changes to the property over and above estate restrictions, with permission fees being payable as a result. Furthermore, the leaseholder may be required to pay fees upon the occurrence of certain events. We sold 4% and 5% of our homes as leaseholds in the financial years ended October 31, 2020 and 2019, respectively. As a result of Government’s changes to the current Help to Buy scheme, for a customer to be eligible to use the scheme all houses must be sold freehold and only apartments can be sold leasehold, with the lease terms being customer and not freeholder focused. We are now selling houses freehold on all of our sites, with the small number of apartments we sell being leasehold. Following concerns about the fairness, clarity and presentation of some leasehold contract terms in the consumer sector (which could lead to people incurring unanticipated costly fees over a long period or having to abide by onerous terms), the Competition and Markets Authority (the “CMA”) launched an investigation in June 2019 to determine whether purchasers are being treated fairly when buying a leasehold home. The investigation examined two key areas: (1) potential mis-selling, which examines whether individuals who have bought a leasehold property are given the information they need to fully understand the obligations they are taking on (including, for example, the requirement to pay ground rent over a certain period of time, or whether they have an accurate understanding of their ability to buy their freehold); and (2) potential unfair terms, which examines ----- whether individuals are having to pay excessive fees due to unfair contract terms (including, for example, administration, service and “permission” charges and ground rents that double after a certain period of time). In connection with this investigation, the CMA wrote to certain companies across the UK home building sector (including certain developers, lenders and freeholders – but not Keepmoat) asking for information to better understand about how leaseholds are sold and managed, and the terms their contracts contain. Following the CMA’s review of the material provided by market participants, the CMA issued an updated report in February 2020, highlighting their key areas of concern in relation to leasehold sales. These areas included: (1) ground rent, both in terms of the method of increase (in particular doubling ground rents but also increases by reference to the retail price index); (2) the impact that ground rent increases might have by virtue of the 1988 Housing Act (as arrear of ground rent could become grounds for a mandatory possession order); (3) the mis-selling of leasehold houses (in particular in relation to a lack of information or the stage at which that information was provided); (4) the level of permission and consent fees; and (5) deficiencies in checks and balances in the sales process to protect customers. On September 4, 2020, the CMA opened cases against certain companies in the UK housebuilding sector (which did not include Keepmoat) in respect of possible breaches of consumer protection law in the residential leasehold sector. These cases were based on possible instances of mis-selling and potential unfairness of certain leasehold contract terms. On March 19, 2021, the CMA issued consultation letters to two of those companies in relation to possible breaches of consumer protection law in the residential leasehold sector. The letters outlined the CMA’s specific concerns regarding the potential unfairness of terms that double ground rent every 10 or 15 years and asked the developers to take steps to address this point. The Leasehold Reform (Ground Rent) Bill, which was introduced by the Government on May 12, 2021, will eliminate the charging of ground rents on new long residential leases and introduce civil penalties for freeholders that do not comply with this legislation. Under the bill, the Government will reform the process of enfranchisement valuation leaseholders must follow to calculate the cost of extending their lease or buying their freehold. The Government will abolish marriage value (being the increase in the value of the property following the completion of the lease extension, reflecting the additional market value of the longer lease), cap the treatment of ground rents at 0.1% of the freehold value and prescribe rates for the calculations at market value. The Government will also introduce an online calculator, further simplifying the process for leaseholds and ensuring standardization and fairness for all those looking to enfranchise. The Government’s leasehold reform proposals, when implemented, will only apply in England, although existing legislation does currently apply in both Wales and England. Scotland operates a separate regime for interdependent units as there are very few leasehold properties in Scotland. Any potential changes to the current regime regarding leasehold properties, including any retrospective application or any breach of consumer protection laws by the business in respect of leasehold properties, could have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The net realizable value of our build work-in-progress (“WIP”) and land may decline.
Subsubsection Text: There is an inherent risk that the net realizable value of our build WIP and land, which constitute part of our inventory and secured land pipeline, respectively, may decline. As a result of our partnership model, we typically do not hold large land banks for long periods of time awaiting development, and instead have invested significantly in relatively lower value brownfield sites (which represented 73% and 72% of our legal completions in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and the nine months ended July 31, 2021, respectively). However, we, like other home builders, are nevertheless subject to the risk of declining values. The valuation of a property development project or land is inherently subjective due to the individual nature of each property and is influenced by a number of factors. Changes in regulatory requirements and applicable laws (including in relation to building regulations, taxation, mortgage availability and planning), political and economic conditions, the condition of financial markets, the financial condition of customers, tax regimes and interest and inflation rate fluctuations all mean that valuations are subject to uncertainty and adverse macroeconomic events and other unforeseen events could result in write-downs of our build WIP and land. There can be no assurance that the net realizable value of land in our financial statements, including the historical financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, will reflect the actual sale prices achieved of either the land itself or any developments built thereon. Land parcels, building lots and housing inventories are illiquid assets, meaning that they may not be easily sold and converted into cash and that any sale may not be capable of being completed quickly without ----- accepting a lower price than may be otherwise offered, and we may not be able to dispose of them efficiently or at all if the Group or the housing market and general economy are in financial distress. If any of the risks described above were to materialize, they could adversely affect the value of our land or developments, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Ownership, leasing or occupation of land as well as home building carries potential environmental risks and liabilities, including liability under claims for damages as a result of use of hazardous materials, including asbestos.
Subsubsection Text: Environmental legislation imposes strict and retrospective liability for cleaning up contaminated land, watercourses or groundwater on the person causing or knowingly permitting the contamination in circumstances where such contamination is causing, or where there is a significant possibility of it causing, significant harm to people or the environment. As a result, we may be liable for the costs of investigation, remediation or removal of hazardous or toxic substances located on, under or in a property that we currently or formerly owned, leased or occupied, irrespective of whether we caused or knew of the pollution. The impact of such laws, regulations and policies can vary greatly from site to site, depending on, among other things, the scope of work undertaken, the site’s environmental condition and the present and former uses of the site. Environmental laws, regulations and policies may give rise to substantial compliance or remediation costs and requirements, and delay, prohibit or severely restrict development at our sites. We also could incur substantial costs, including clean-up costs, fines, penalties and third party claims for personal injury or property damage as a result of violations of, or liabilities under, such laws, regulations and policies. We routinely acquire properties on the basis that we accept all contamination risk associated with the property, and often provide vendors with indemnities covering any liabilities which the vendor may face under environmental laws following the sale. The costs associated with the management of such substances, or the costs of defending against environmental claims may be substantial, and our recourse to the contractors that perform our remediation work may be restricted by contractual limitations, the lapse of time or the insolvency of such contractors, among other factors. The presence of such substances, or the failure to remediate such substances properly, may also adversely affect our ability to sell the land or, where relevant, borrow using the land as security. As a substantial proportion of the Group’s developments are on brownfield sites, we are subject to an increased risk that some of our development projects are located on land that may have been contaminated or rendered geologically unstable by previous use. For example, at our Nightingale Road site, where we plan to build 372 homes in partnership with the Derby Council, a report prepared for councilors warned that land contamination could affect the project’s financial viability and completion date. The report classified the risk as “moderate risk (remediation works to be completed).” We are currently in the process of remediating the site under license with independent competent consultants monitoring the work being undertaken. It is expected that following completion and verification of the remediation in accordance with the planning permission (including remediation strategy), the site will be classed as having been remediated to the high standard required for the sale of residential homes. However, if the site is not classed as having been remediated to such standard, we would be obliged to undertake remedial work to address any defective work. Although we aim to carry out appropriate due diligence before acquiring properties, any deficiencies in our due diligence process could result in our failure to identify all major constraints and risks. In addition, following legal transfer of the land to us, we bear public liability risk as well as associated maintenance and health, safety and environmental risks. Contaminants resulting from historical operations have been detected at some of our development sites, one of which was the Nightingale Road site. This is not unusual for brownfield sites and as such, our business approach is to acquire these sites and remediate them to the standard required for residential development. Although we do not currently expect any remedial obligations to have a material effect on our financial condition, we could incur substantial additional costs as a result of additional contamination that is identified or additional obligations that are imposed at these or other sites in the future. We are particularly susceptible to this risk where historical off-site migration of contamination has occurred prior to our acquisition of a site, which has not otherwise been identified as part of the legal or technical due diligence process. Laws and regulations may also impose liability for the release of certain materials from land into the air or water, including asbestos, and such release can form the basis for liability to third persons for personal injury or other damages. It is unlikely that such claims would be fully or partially covered by our present or future insurance. See “—We may _be subject to increases in insurance premiums or fail to secure or maintain adequate insurance coverage.”_ ----- As a home building business with a wide variety of development related activities, we could be liable for future claims for damages as a result of our past or present use of hazardous or potentially unsafe materials (including materials that are not currently deemed unsafe but in the future may become known to be hazardous or unsafe). When beginning work at a site, we are exposed to the risk of various liabilities, including negligent and non-negligent damage to third party assets, local planning violations and health, safety and environmental incidents. For example, when we enter a site, we may inadvertently damage third party assets such as underground cables, sewers or pipes on a negligent or non-negligent basis. For example, certain work site vibrations may affect properties nearby and certain excavation procedures may cause collapses on third party land. We have also been subject to claims in which our former employees, employees of our subcontractors and third parties have successfully claimed damages in relation to hazardous materials and other environmental and health and safety matters. Although we carry third party liability insurance where we are responsible for policy excess only on covered claims, and to date no claims have been declined by insurers, there can be no guarantee that additional claims will not result in significant costs or that they will be covered by insurance in the future. Historically, asbestos was used as a building material by the construction industry and exposure to asbestos and inhalation of asbestos fibers can lead to a number of diseases. Although we have not been subject to any claims of this nature to date, if claims related to exposure to asbestos arise at any of our sites, such claims could give rise to material liabilities. The occurrence of any of these risks may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we fail to successfully implement our business strategy or engage in future activities where we have limited expertise, our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects may be adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: Our business strategy is based on a series of projections and estimates predicated on the occurrence of future events, which may or may not take place, including the execution of certain operational and organizational initiatives by our management team. Our ability to successfully implement our strategy is dependent upon a number of business, economic and competitive uncertainties and other factors that are outside our control. Accordingly, our strategy is based upon a number of assumptions that may prove to be inaccurate. We cannot provide assurance that the assumptions underlying our business strategy are correct, and any inaccurate assumption may result in variations of our strategy that may limit our ability to achieve our envisaged goals. In addition, we are unable to provide any assurance that: (i) our actions will generate the expected positive economic results; (ii) our business strategy can be successfully implemented by management; and (iii) we will be able to achieve the revenue, ROCE, ASP and cash targets set out in our strategy within the expected time frame. If our results differ significantly from those expected based on our strategies and our business plan, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. We may undertake activities outside of the current scope of our expertise or regional operations. If we expand the scope of our business activities pursuant to our regional expansion program and general business plan, we may have insufficient knowledge of the appropriate processes, systems and controls to deliver appropriate returns. In addition, to the extent that we expand or invest in areas that are outside of our existing lines of business, we will face new challenges, which may include: - our ability to develop the expertise required to successfully engage in such businesses and to make such businesses successful; - our ability to develop a reputation in industries into which we may expand; - our ability to attract and retain customers, suppliers and managers for new businesses; - our ability to control costs across a more complex regional or operational footprint; and - competition from companies engaged in similar businesses in the markets we have targeted for entry. Furthermore, to the extent such investments are undertaken as joint ventures, there can be no assurance that our public and private partners will meet their joint venture obligations in a timely manner or at all. Any of these risks may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business plan relies on our ability to attract, develop and retain highly-skilled, competent people at all levels.
Subsubsection Text: Our future success depends in large part upon the continued service of our Executive Directors and senior management team (and in particular, our Land and Partnerships Team), who have significant experience in the home building and regeneration industries and have developed strong reputations and relationships among those with whom we do business. The overall management of our business and the development of our projects, culture and strategic direction depend in large part on our ability to retain these key personnel. We do not maintain key man insurance, and if we are unable to attract and retain key personnel or develop a succession plan for senior management, we may not be able to maintain our standards of service or continue to grow as anticipated. Additionally, skilled employees working in the home building industry are highly sought after and there may sometimes be shortages of skilled employees, particularly in periods of increased market activity. Failure to attract and retain such personnel in sufficient capacities and capabilities, or to ensure that their experience and knowledge is not lost when they leave the business through resignation or retirement, may have a material adverse effect on standards of service and our ability to meet our key strategic targets. See “—Our business depends on _the continued availability, viability and cost of subcontractors and other service providers.”_ The loss of any member of our senior management team or the inability to attract and retain skilled employees generally may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business depends in part on our strong image and reputation, and any negative impact on our image and reputation could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our image and reputation represent an important part of our business, especially given the nature of our partnership business model and our target customer base. We often partner with Local Authorities and other public bodies, including Homes England, which require us to participate in public procurement processes. Non-financial criteria, such as planning and design capability, customer service records, past delivery of high-quality homes with minimal defects, delivery capacity and proposals to address social and economic sustainability issues, typically account for more than 50% of an applicant’s score in public procurement processes. As a result, maintaining the reputation of our business is central to our success. Our local management teams can, to some extent, independently organize their own advertising campaigns and marketing initiatives to supplement our national campaigns. Our local teams could therefore project an image that is not aligned with our Group strategy, which could dilute the Group’s image and have a material adverse effect on its business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. We may also unknowingly source materials from suppliers that have produced or procured such materials in an illegal or unethical manner, which may adversely affect our reputation and financial position. We may also be the subject of adverse publicity, for example, if home purchasers were to generate negative publicity related to the quality of the homes that we build. Such adverse publicity could be disseminated more widely through the use of the internet and social media platforms. Additionally, we could be the subject of adverse publicity from local communities who object to our developments. There can be no assurance that our efforts to liaise with local communities regarding building plans and to maintain our reputation for being a trusted partner will be successful, and a decline in our public perception may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Home building is subject to the risk of construction defects, which may give rise to contractual or other liabilities or legal disputes.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the risk of construction defects and are currently, and may in the future become, involved in litigation, claims and disputes arising in connection with poor materials and manufactured items provided by suppliers, inadequate designs by consultants, actual or alleged defects in the work we or our subcontractors perform, failure to comply with applicable legal or regulatory requirements (including safety and environmental laws and regulations), and other types of claims, including challenges relating to planning permissions and other Local Authority approvals. In the ordinary course of business, we are also exposed to National House Building Council (“NHBC”) and other warranty and indemnity claims (which may not be subject to monetary caps or other contractual limitations) during applicable defects liability periods (which can exceed ten years in some cases). We may be required to incur substantial expenditures to defend such claims and, in the case of successful claims, to rectify the defects, and may have to forego payments to which we would otherwise be entitled. ----- For a period of time following the legal completion of a sale, we are generally obliged to rectify any defects found in the home to bring it up to the standards required under the technical specifications set out in the home warranty deed. These defects are typically small and take a short time to resolve. However, in some cases, there may be a significant number of defects due to poor design, workmanship or materials which may require a longer period of time to resolve. In some cases, the presence of these defects may require the customer to move out of their new home and into temporary accommodation while work is being carried out by our employees or subcontractors. Any significant increase in such cases could increase our costs and damage our reputation, and we may face liability for defective work. Construction defects may arise sometime after the completion of a particular project or contract, and, although we seek to obtain contractual warranty, guarantee or indemnity protection in our contracts with designers, contractors, subcontractors and suppliers, we may not be able to obtain this protection in all cases. We have professional indemnity insurance which covers claims made against us and third party losses incurred due to our negligence or the negligence of our professional designers. As is typical in the new-build industry, our homes come with either a ten-year NHBC comprehensive warranty and insurance policy or a ten-year Local Authority Building Control (“LABC”) insurance policy for the benefit of the customer covering structural defects, improper environmental remediation and waterproofing. In both cases, we pay the premiums for these policies. Customers may access NHBC or LABC new home warranties if construction defects are discovered in their home. The NHBC and/or LABC, as applicable, may seek to recover from us any losses paid to such customers through the indemnity in the Homes Warranty Deed and our insurance may not cover such defects or losses or cover them fully or at all. We have a premium rating with both the NHBC and LABC. If we were to deliver homes of a substandard quality over a period of time, or if multiple customers were to make claims against our warranties or policies, our rating could be affected and premiums increased. When we are liable to pay fines or damages as a result of work or materials provided by our suppliers or subcontractors, we may seek to recoup those amounts. However, our suppliers or subcontractors may be unable to fund these amounts or may have gone out of business in the period since construction. In such cases, we could be liable for the full statutory limitation period. Significant liabilities for which we are responsible may not be identified or may only come to light after the expiry of contractual warranty, guarantee or indemnity periods. Any claims relating to defects arising on a development attributable to us may give rise to contractual or other liabilities which can extend, depending on the relevant contractual or statutory provisions, for a number of years following the completion of the project or contract. Unexpected levels of expenditure attributable to defects (including those caused by third parties) arising on a project may have a material adverse effect on the return generated by a particular project or contract and our overall performance. Furthermore, widespread or significant defects could generate significant adverse publicity and have a negative impact on our reputation and key relationships, as well as on our ability to sell housing and acquire new land, and divert financial and management resources from more beneficial uses.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business in Scotland may be adversely impacted in the event that a Scottish referendum votes for independence.
Subsubsection Text: In the event that Scotland declares independence from the UK in any future referendum on the subject, the uncertainties and impact of Scottish independence could significantly impact our Scottish business and operations. Although a majority of voters in the Scottish independence referendum in September 2014 voted against independence, it is possible that a new referendum in the future would lead to a different voting outcome. The pursuit of a further referendum on Scottish independence is the stated policy of the current Scottish government. The details of any changes as a result of Scottish independence are impossible to predict, and are likely to depend on post-referendum negotiations and agreements between the Scottish Government and other organizations at UK and EU level. If there were a vote in favor of independence, it could lead to a range of effects which could be negative to our business in Scotland including increased costs and taxation rates in Scotland, a decrease in investment in the housing sector in Scotland and a decrease in the demand for housing. In addition, as a result of Scottish independence, our operations in Scotland could be subject to changes in the monetary system, currency, and other regulatory and legal frameworks. For the financial year ended October 31, 2020, we derived less than 10% of our revenues from our Scotland region. In the event that any of these effects materialize, they could have an adverse effect on our overall business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have in the past engaged in acquisitions and as part of our growth strategy expect to consider further strategic opportunities from time to time that may involve acquisitions, dispositions, investments in joint ventures, partnerships, and other strategic alternatives, any of which may result in the use of a significant amount of our management resources or significant costs, and we may not be able to fully realize the potential benefit of such transactions.
Subsubsection Text: In connection with our regional expansion program and general business plan, we have made, and may continue to make, acquisitions, dispositions, investments in joint ventures, partnerships, and other strategic alternatives. For example, in 2017, we acquired MCI, a developer of social housing projects for Local Authorities and other Registered Providers. Our management may from time to time be engaged in evaluating such potential transactions, investments and other strategic alternatives. Although these activities or discussions may not result in definitive agreements or the completion of any transaction, we may incur significant costs or devote a significant amount of management resources to analyzing and pursuing such transactions, which could negatively impact our operations. In cases where acquisitions are completed, there can be no assurance that we will be able to generate expected margins or cash flows, or to realize the anticipated benefits of such acquisitions, including growth or expected synergies. There can be no assurance that our assessment of and assumptions regarding acquisition targets will prove to be correct, and actual developments may differ significantly from our expectations. In addition, we may not be able to integrate acquisitions successfully. The integration of acquired businesses and assets may require more investment than we expect, and we could incur or assume unknown or unanticipated liabilities or contingencies with respect to customers, employees, suppliers, Government authorities or other parties, which may impact our operating results. See also “—Ownership, leasing or occupation of land as well as _home building carries potential environmental risks and liabilities, including liability under claims for damages as a result of use of hazardous materials, including asbestos.” The process of integrating businesses may be_ disruptive to our operations and may cause an interruption of, or a loss of momentum in, such operations or a decrease in our results of operations as a result of difficulties or risks, including: - unforeseen legal, regulatory, contractual and other issues; - difficulty in standardizing information and other systems; - difficulty in realizing operating synergies; - diversion of management’s attention from our day-to-day business; - failure to maintain the quality of services that we have historically provided; and - potential loss of key employees and cultural challenges associated with integrating employees. Moreover, any acquisition may result in the incurrence of additional debt, which would increase our leverage and could reduce our profitability and harm our business. While we may seek protection (for example, through warranties and indemnities in the case of acquisitions), significant liabilities may not be identified in due diligence or may come to light after the expiry of warranty or indemnity periods. Additionally, while we may seek to limit our ongoing exposure (for example, through liability caps and period limits on warranties and indemnities in the case of disposals), such warranties and indemnities may be insufficient and we may incur unexpected and significant liabilities. See “—If we fail to successfully implement our business strategy or engage in future _activities where we have limited expertise, our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects may be adversely affected.” Any claims arising in the future may have a material adverse effect on our_ business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. If any of our acquisitions fail to perform in accordance with our assumptions, any goodwill or other intangible assets associated with the acquisition could be subject to impairment and reduce our profitability and net assets accordingly. It is also possible that we may, from time to time, seek to divest certain businesses. For example, in 2017, pursuant to our strategy to focus exclusively on housing development, we sold our contracting arm, Keepmoat Regeneration Limited, to ENGIE, a French multinational group. In connection with any proposed divestments, we may fail to find a buyer at an acceptable price and/or may divert management’s attention from other matters. Furthermore, there is no guarantee that the anticipated benefits of a proposed disposal will be realized and there may be other unanticipated or unintended effects. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Interruption or failure of, or cyber-attacks on, our IT systems and data protection systems may result in a significant loss of control of our business information functions and operations.
Subsubsection Text: The efficient operation and management of our business depends in part on the proper operation, performance and development of our IT systems and processes, in particular those relating to customer and employee information, confidential business and financial information, surveying and valuation. We routinely transmit and receive personal, confidential and proprietary information by email and other electronic means and therefore rely on the secure processing, storage and transmission of such information. Our financial, accounting, data processing, IT, communications or other systems and facilities, and/or third party infrastructure on which the we rely may: (i) fail to operate properly or become disabled as a result of events that are wholly or partially beyond our control; and (ii) be vulnerable to unauthorized access and data loss (from within the organization or by third parties), computer viruses, malicious code, ransomware attacks, cyber threats that have a security impact, and the interception or misuse of information transmitted or received by them. Where the collation of data has been centralized within a business function, it is more likely that a data protection breach would result in the loss of a large amount of data. See “—Changes in privacy laws could adversely affect the Group’s ability to interact _effectively with third parties.”_ Although we have implemented data security provisions that we believe are appropriate, particularly in respect of our centralized IT function, breaches may nonetheless occur, resulting in the loss of our customers’ confidential and other information, or otherwise cause interruptions or malfunctions in our operations or the operations of our customers or third parties. Any such breaches could lead to a loss of control over critical business information and/or systems (such as contract costs, invoicing, payroll management and/or internal reporting), resulting in an adverse impact on our ability to operate effectively or to fulfil our contractual or regulatory obligations. We may be required to expend significant additional resources to modify these protective measures or to investigate and remedy vulnerabilities or other exposures, and we may be subject to litigation, reputational harm and financial losses that are either not insured against or not fully covered through any insurance that we maintain. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. Additionally, from time to time, we may implement new or upgraded IT systems. The implementation of new IT systems could distract management from other critical business operations. Issues may be experienced during the implementation of new IT systems, which may lead to increased costs and may result in errors in operations, including the planning of projects. Our failure to properly implement new IT systems may also impact our ability to properly report our financial performance or comply with other regulatory requirements. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be subject to increases in insurance premiums or fail to secure or maintain adequate insurance coverage.
Subsubsection Text: We retain insurance policies that provide coverage at a level that we believe is appropriate against risks commonly insured in our industry. Our insurance policies cover contract works, professional indemnity, property, employer liability, directors and officers, pension trustee, public liability, business interruption and money, terrorism, motor vehicles, engineering and computer liability. We also obtain title defect insurance if considered appropriate following the carrying out of due diligence on a development site. As only a limited number of insurers offer coverage of this type, we may not be able to avoid increases in premiums. Furthermore, as insurance providers review the terms and conditions of our insurance policies on a periodic basis, we may not be able to obtain the same or similar coverage in the future and certain types of risks may be, or may become, either uninsurable or not economically insurable. This could increase our exposure to various risks and related costs, which in turn could have an adverse impact on our business, profitability and growth. We have not retained insurance policies for certain types of risks, including risks associated with criminal liability and radioactive contamination. Our financial condition and profitability could be adversely affected if we suffer damages or losses or if we are exposed to liability over risks for which we have no insurance coverage or insufficient insurance coverage. See “—We may suffer losses from natural disasters, terrorist attacks, war, _sabotage, social unrest, corruption and other unforeseen events outside our control, and such losses may be uninsured or in excess of insurance proceeds.”_ -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may suffer losses from natural disasters, terrorist attacks, war, sabotage, social unrest, corruption and other unforeseen events outside our control, and such losses may be uninsured or in excess of insurance proceeds.
Subsubsection Text: Our assets and projects are subject to risks associated with natural disasters and other catastrophic events outside our control, including ice and wind storms, tornadoes, floods, hurricanes, earthquakes, power loss, telecommunications failures, network software flaws, social unrest, sabotage, war, acts of vandalism, arson, terrorism, theft and fuel shortages. The occurrence of any such events could directly affect our project sites or, more broadly, the UK economy or housing market. Any damage or destruction to our assets (including our land pipeline, development projects and major office or administrative facilities) as a result of these or other events could impact our ability to sell homes to our customers or continue our business plans. In addition, if we are unable to sell homes to our customers or continue our property development projects as a result of these or other events, we could lose our current customers, contracts or projects. Such events may increase costs, decrease demand for our homes and result in other losses that may not be insured and, as a result, may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects. We could suffer physical damage to property or liabilities as a result of the foregoing risks, resulting in losses that may not be fully or partially covered by our insurance. In addition, certain types of risks may be, or may become in the future, either uninsurable or not economically insurable, or may not be currently or in the future covered by our insurance policies. Should an uninsured loss or a loss in excess of insured limits occur, we could sustain financial loss or lose capital invested in affected property as well as anticipated future income from that property. In addition, we could be liable to repair damage or meet liabilities caused by uninsured risks. We would likely also remain liable for any debt or other financial obligation related to the affected property. No assurance can be given that material losses or liabilities in excess of insurance proceeds will not occur in the future.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks in connection with corporate and contractual joint ventures, other associated companies and special purpose vehicles where we do not have sole operational control.
Subsubsection Text: Although joint ventures are not one of our key areas of focus, in certain cases our partners require that we set up joint ventures to facilitate delivery of specific schemes. These requirements are most common when working with Local Authorities on large-scale projects that involve multiple phases. For the financial year ended October 31, 2020, our consolidated revenue from joint venture companies amounted to £1.0 million. As of July 31, 2021, we had also provided loans totaling £9.8 million to joint ventures and associated companies in which we held less than 100% of the shares. Parent company guarantees have also been provided in some cases in respect of the obligations of joint ventures, with prior consideration given to our level of control over compliance with such obligations. In the future, we may also enter into further joint ventures or make investments or acquire participations in associated companies or special purpose vehicles. Joint ventures often require that we and our partners obtain or procure financing in furtherance of the joint venture’s operations. If one of our joint ventures or partners are unable to obtain financing when required, we may be forced to make up the financial shortfall from our own resources, which could result in additional costs or delays to the development. Conversely, if we are unable to meet our obligations under our joint venture agreements, our partners may be able to terminate our involvement in the relevant joint venture. To finance the activities of our joint ventures, our joint ventures, associated companies and special purpose vehicles may obtain loans from third party lenders, or issue bonds or other debt instruments, that are secured by the joint venture’s assets. In certain instances, we and our other partners in a joint venture may also provide guarantees and indemnities to lenders with respect to the joint venture’s debt, which may be triggered under certain conditions when the joint venture fails to fulfil its obligations under its loan agreements and debt instruments. Our ability to fully extract the strategic potential in markets where we operate through joint ventures, associated companies and special purpose vehicles may be impaired if we are unable to agree with our joint venture partners or joint shareholders on a strategy or its implementation. The interests of our joint venture partners or joint shareholders could conflict with our interests or the interests of the holders of the Notes. Minority shareholders in certain joint ventures and associated companies may also have approval or other rights under applicable corporate law or the applicable joint venture agreement, shareholder agreement or other organizational document. The interests of these minority shareholders may differ from our economic interests and may prevent ----- us from pursuing our preferred business strategy with the relevant subsidiary. Our ability to implement organizational measures and pursue our preferred financial policies (in particular, dividend policies, capital expenditure plans and allocation of company assets) may also be impeded. Where we hold non-controlling interests in companies and joint ventures, we may not be able to influence the decision making process on certain key matters or may need to obtain the consent of other shareholders or joint venture participants. We may therefore depend on the cooperation of other shareholders or participants to carry out the business and affairs of those companies or joint ventures and ensure that the company or joint venture, as well as the shareholders or participants, fulfil their respective obligations to us and to third parties. If the other shareholders or participants do not provide such cooperation or fulfil these obligations due to their financial condition, strategic business interests (which may be contrary to ours) or other reasons, we may be required to spend additional resources (including payments under the guarantees we have provided to the joint ventures’ lenders) and suffer losses, each of which could be significant. For example, under the terms of certain of our joint development agreements, we may be jointly and severally liable for the obligations of our joint venture partners in the event they become insolvent or otherwise fail to perform their obligations. Moreover, our ability to recoup such expenditures and losses by exercising remedies against our partners may be limited due to potential legal defenses they may have, their respective financial condition and other circumstances. We may have disputes with our joint venture partners and may not be able to resolve all the issues that arise with respect to such disputes, despite procedures dictated by the joint venture agreement. Such disputes may lead to delays in the development and completion of the project, or the project being developed in such a way that will not achieve its highest potential rate of return. In addition, we may accept risks or responsibilities in the course of our joint venture operations that exceed those which we would typically be prepared to accept. In addition, under certain conditions our joint venture partners or joint shareholders could (i) terminate or refuse to extend contractual relationships, (ii) exercise option rights to acquire or sell interests in our joint ventures (especially through the exercise of “deadlock” provisions to the extent contained in the underlying joint venture or shareholder agreement), or (iii) otherwise influence the day-to-day business of our joint ventures or other associated companies or special purpose vehicles. Upon dissolution or termination of a joint venture we may be required to make payments to our partners in the joint venture, and such payments could be significant. Furthermore, we could be subject to fiduciary or contractual obligations to our joint venture partners or joint shareholders, which could prevent or impede our ability to unilaterally expand in the business area in which that joint venture or associated company operates. We may also be required to carry out joint venture activities in compliance with applicable competition laws, which may limit the scope of such joint venture activity or cooperation. Each of these factors may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects, and may also adversely affect our relationships with housing associations and Local Authorities that deal with or are party to our joint ventures, associated companies and special purpose vehicles.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our assets and projects can be impacted by the weather and the effects of climate change.
Subsubsection Text: Our assets and projects can be impacted by both short-term and longer-term weather events and longerterm changes to weather patterns. At a local level, changes to coastlines, river levels and directions, flood plains and other geographic features can impact our ability to conduct our operations and impact the value of our assets. In addition, the markets that we operate in could experience changes in weather patterns or weather intensity compared to historical norms, which may make the timetable for planning, developing and constructing properties more unpredictable and result in higher costs. Our exposure to events and changes of this type may be exacerbated by the fact that we operate solely in the UK. In addition statutory and regulatory responses to climate change and other environmental issues could have an impact on our business. These could include changes to building regulation, the use of materials, higher energy costs, the availability of insurance, carbon offsets, the location and structure of developments, closer monitoring of resource depletion and air and water quality, as well as the allocation of public expenditure. Such weather and climate change risks may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on the strength of our brands, trademarks and other intellectual property rights.
Subsubsection Text: Our brands, trademarks and other intellectual property (“IP”), particularly the “Keepmoat Homes” brand, logo and trademark, are part of our business and success. Although we believe that our IP is adequately supported ----- by applications for registrations, existing registrations and other legal protections in the UK, these protections may be challenged by others. A successful challenge to these protections, or any other damage to our IP (including, for example, the loss of a brand’s strength), could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and/or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be required to make up shortfalls to unfunded contractual promises which sit outside of pension legislation.
Subsubsection Text: We provide retirement benefits for our former and current employees through defined contribution pension schemes. We contribute to the Keepmoat Limited Group Pension Plan (“KPP”), which is an occupational defined contribution pension scheme in which the assets are held in independently administered funds. Pension costs (included within operating profit) were £1.8 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. We also maintain a separate contractual agreement (the “Underpin”) for less than 15 members which is an unfunded contractual promise outside of pension legislation. To comply with the terms of the Underpin, we may be required to contribute to individual members’ accounts where the market value of the individual members account at retirement is less than the Underpin promise. This amount payable is dependent on the market value of the individual members’ account at the time of retirement. The KPP is currently in surplus in the amount of £1.14 million as of April 30, 2021 (representing the value of the plan’s assets in excess of the combined value of members’ accounts) and held in a contingency fund which may be used to fund the Underpin.

Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition is subject to certain conditions and risks and, if it is not consummated, the Issuer will redeem the Notes at 100% of the issue price, plus accrued and unpaid interest.
Subsubsection Text: On August 4, 2021, Aermont entered into the Acquisition Agreement to acquire, directly or indirectly, from the Sellers all of the issued and outstanding share capital of the Company. The Acquisition is subject to the satisfaction of certain closing conditions, including, customary antitrust and regulatory approvals and the performance of certain closing actions. To the extent the Acquisition will not complete on or shortly after the Issue Date, concurrently with the closing of the Offering, and pending release to consummate of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow Account, held in the name of the Issuer. The release of the Escrowed Property is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within three Business Days). As of the date of the Offering Memorandum, we do not yet know whether the Acquisition will be successful. If the conditions precedent to the Acquisition are not satisfied or waived, as applicable, by the Escrow Longstop Date, then the Acquisition will not be consummated. If the conditions to the release of the Escrowed Property, as more fully described under “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption” have not been satisfied on or prior to the Escrow Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain_ other events, the Notes will be subject to a Special Mandatory Redemption as described in “Description of the _Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and you may not obtain the return you expect to_ receive on the Notes.

Subsubsection Title: If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuer will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Account will not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on an additional equity investment from the shareholders
Subsubsection Text: The Escrowed Property will be limited initially to the gross proceeds of the Offering and will not be sufficient to pay the Special Mandatory Redemption Price (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Escrow of _Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption”), which is equal to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes,_ plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the Special Mandatory Redemption Date (as defined in “Description of the Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory _Redemption”). If the conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuer will_ be required to redeem the Notes and, if the Escrow Account alone does not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption and, as such, the Issuer will be required to obtain the necessary funds elsewhere, such as equity investment from shareholders. ----- The Issuer has no revenue generating activities of its own and no independent business operations and there can be no assurance that the Issuer will have sufficient funds to make this payment, and the Issuer may not have access to the funds necessary to allow it to pay the full amount of the required redemption price in the event of a Special Mandatory Redemption. Your decision to invest in the Notes is made at the time of purchase. Changes in the business or financial position of the Group, or the terms of the Acquisition, between the Issue Date and the Escrow Release Date, may have an impact on our creditworthiness, and you will not be able to rescind your decision to invest in the Notes as a result thereof.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Normalized EBITDA presented in this Offering Memorandum should be treated with caution when making an investment decision.
Subsubsection Text: In this Offering Memorandum, we present Normalized EBITDA, which is derived using various assumptions related to the impact of COVID-19 pandemic on our EBITDA. See “Summary Historical _Consolidated Financial Information and Other Data—Other Financial Information” for additional details_ regarding these adjustments to our Normalized EBITDA and their underlying assumptions. We believe that Normalized EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 is a measure that assists in understanding our performance during a period impacted by the market disruption caused by COVID-19 by substituting the October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA for the October 2019 Management Adjusted EBITDA, comprising the months of our last calendar equivalent financial quarter prior to the market disruption caused by COVID-19. Our operations during the three months ended October 31, 2020 were negatively impacted following the government imposed lockdown and the subsequent delayed ramp up on home construction and sales, before resuming normalized operations during the three month period ended January 31, 2021. As a result, we believe Normalized EBITDA to be more representative of our Adjusted EBITDA performance for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 and takes into account, on a highly illustrative basis, the cyclicality of our business. The assumptions we have made with respect to the Normalized EBITDA that we present in this Offering Memorandum are based on our current estimates and they involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements to be materially different from any anticipated future results, performance or achievements implied by such adjusted financial information. Specifically, to derive the Normalized EBITDA, we have replaced the last fiscal quarter of our October 31, 2020 financial year spanning a period where construction activity in the United Kingdom was still slowed due to confinement measures. In addition, Normalized EBITDA does not (i) give effect to any other event, favorable or unfavorable, that happened or could have happened during the three months ended October 31, 2020, other than the events directly related to the COVID-19 pandemic or (ii) adjust for the positive or negative effect of the ongoing COVID19 pandemic during the nine months ended July 31, 2021. As a result, we cannot assure you that the difference between the October 2020 Management Adjusted EBITDA and the October 2019 Management Adjusted EBITDA may not be partly due to factors other than the COVID-19 pandemic, such as overall market trends and conditions or competitive pressures we are facing, and there is no guarantee that any such difference is recoverable or will be recovered by our business in future periods. You should exercise caution when evaluating the adjustments reflected in the Normalized EBITDA and whether you consider these to be appropriate, as this information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. Normalized EBITDA is derived from management accounts and not from accounts or financial statements that are complaint with IFRS, and is materially different from Adjusted EBITDA as a result of various adjustments. Normalized EBITDA is not derived from accounts that have been audited or independently reviewed by our auditors. It should not be considered as an alternative to net income or operating income as indicators of our performance, nor as an alternative to cash flows as a measure of our liquidity. While we use Normalized EBITDA to assess our operating performance, and we believe that similar measures are commonly used by investors, we cannot guarantee that Normalized EBITDA, as presented in this Offering Memorandum, is comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies, due to, among other things, differences in the way such measures are calculated. -----
