Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (2) Sales mix of open market and Registered Provider sales based on percentage of total homes delivered for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Registered Provider sales comprises all sales to Registered Providers that are contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section 106 obligations. Open market sales include private sales, elective sales to Registered Providers agreed during the development of a site, Affordable Homes Programme sales and private rental sector sales. See “—Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income—Revenue.” (3) Private sales customer mix based on statistics from a survey of 1,053 private sales customers in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Sustainability is also a key driver of our operations, with a particular focus on community-building and place making. In July 2020, following stakeholder consultation, we published our Sustainability Strategy in which we identified our material issues and aligned our strategy to eight United Nations Sustainable Development Goals SDGs. Through our Sustainability Strategy, we have committed to minimizing our impact on the environment and biodiversity. In particular, we have announced that we intend to achieve a net zero carbon position by the mid-2040s (having formally committed to Race to Zero) and that we intend to publicly disclose our carbon performance from 2022 onwards. We were active on 94 sites as of July 31, 2021. In addition, as of July 31, 2021, the number of plots within our land pipeline was 24,654, with approximately 81% of our land pipeline, or 19,933 plots, being legally secured (meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract). As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline, or 4,721 plots, were those on which we had been appointed ----- preferred developer (meaning that we had been chosen by the land vendor as the final candidate to progress to contract for the development of the site). Together, these plots are equivalent to a six-year supply of homes, based on our pre-pandemic annual completion levels. As of July 31, 2021, we had a forward order book of approximately £503 million (representing 3,151 plots) with an open market sales rate of 0.77 for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021. As of September 19, 2021, we had reserved, exchanged or legally completed almost all of our planned sales for the financial year ending October 31, 2021. Furthermore, as of September 19, 2021, we had secured approximately 40% of our planned sales for the year ended October 31, 2022, 85% of our planned sales for the three months ended January 31, 2022, and 45% of our planned sales for the three months ended April 30, 2022. As of September 19, 2021, we had an eight-week rolling average rate of 0.93, demonstrating continued strong demand from our customers. Our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 were £628.5 million and £73.8 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.” Over the same period, we generated Free Cash Flow of £44.1 million (and free cash flow conversion of 59.8%). The resilience of our business model was demonstrated through the COVID-19 pandemic. Working with our partners, we were able to agree a deferral of 89% of committed and uncommitted land spend, without losing any site investment opportunities as a result. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrate the resiliency and strength of our business model. Our focus on partnerships provides us with an attractive financial model, benefitting from typically lower land values, attractive (and often deferred) payment terms, the potential for additional elective deals with Registered Providers (beyond sales in connection with Section 106 affordable housing obligations) and access to grant funding to optimize returns. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the UK’s oldest and most experienced partnership housebuilders, with “5-Star Homebuilder” status awarded in 2021. We are focused on creating sustainable communities in places where people want to live, and we specialize in the delivery of affordable and high quality homes, principally targeted at first-time buyers. Headquartered in Doncaster, England, we operate across England and Scotland through nine operating regions. We are a top ten UK housebuilder, measured by the number of homes sold, including delivering 4,035 homes in our financial year ended October 31, 2019. Unlike traditional housebuilders, our business model is based on partnerships with entities interested in seeing an increase in supply of homes as well as those with demand for our product. These partners are primarily land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) or Registered Providers, which include the traditional not-for-profit and the newer for-profit entities that are registered with the Regulator of Social Housing to provide affordable housing. We engage each of our key stakeholders in residential projects by establishing, aligning and prioritizing their needs and successfully delivering their objectives. We have built our reputation by aligning our approach to our partners’ objectives regarding the sourcing, procurement, planning and delivery of successful, affordable housing developments that create significant social value. We believe that we are the original partnership-focused housebuilder in the United Kingdom, having worked with over 200 partners to date, with many of these relationships enduring for over 20 years. Our partnership model allows us to have a high degree of certainty over our land pipeline, with sufficient land secured for six years of development based on our future development plans and on 2019 home deliveries, while also typically allowing us to defer payment until milestones are met. We are also able to minimize development and planning risks by partnering with land owners through the early stages of a development project. Coupled with the relatively low land costs for the affordable homes that we target, we are able to operate a capitallight business model relative to traditional housebuilders, and generate relatively strong cash conversion and ROCE. In the financial year ended October 31, 2019, the last full financial year prior to the start of the COVID19 pandemic, our ROCE was 32.8%. ----- We focus on developing urban and suburban locations where there is an inherent demand and supply imbalance for new homes. We aim to meet this demand through our five core standard house type ranges. This standardization allows efficiency in procuring materials and construction, increased certainty of cost and timing of delivery, and assists in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and our partners’ preferences. We are continually working with new technologies that underpin and refine our designs. We are committed to deliver a range of affordable housing, predominantly for open market sale, social housing and shared ownership – which provides us with a higher degree of market resilience over the long term due to generally consistent demand from first-time buyers and well-funded Registered Providers. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site), with the remaining approximately 26% of our sales comprising sales to Registered Providers that are contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section 106 obligations. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 were to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (first-time buyers accounted for 76% during the financial year ended October 31, 2019). In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 45% of our total sales, including 67% of sales to first time buyers, involved the use of the Government HTB scheme. We believe that first-time buyers provide more resilient structural demand than the typically discretionary and cyclical home-mover segment. The following charts show our sales mix (by percentage of total homes delivered) and our private sales customer mix for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Strength of the UK Housing Market and General Macro-economic Conditions in the UK
Subsubsection Text: As we operate and generate our revenue exclusively in the UK, our results are dependent on conditions in the UK housing market and general macro-economic conditions in the UK — in particular, the demand for housing and the average selling prices of houses in the regions where we operate. Demand for housing is driven by a combination of factors, such as the rate of economic growth (both nationally and regionally), the rate of population growth, the average age and life expectancy of the population, the rate of household formation, the availability and affordability of mortgages, consumer confidence, the unemployment rate and governmental tax and incentive schemes (such as the stamp duty rates, holidays and the HTB scheme). Historically, the strength of the UK housing market and of the housebuilding sector has been linked to that of the UK economy as a whole, which in turn is influenced by both European and global macro-economic conditions, all of which have been cyclical in the past. Periods of economic downturn in the UK have generally been correlated with decreases in demand for homes and in house prices, while favorable economic conditions have generally been correlated with higher demand and increases in house prices. Since 2013, the UK housing market has benefitted from an improved economic backdrop, as well as from increased Government support (including from the HTB scheme that started in 2013). This has contributed to a rise in housebuilding completions to 178,310 in the year ended December 31, 2019, the highest level since 2007. Nevertheless, the housing market is subject to its own independent dynamics and demand for housing may sometimes not correlate directly with the broader macro-economic climate. For example, although the COVID-19 pandemic had a significant effect on UK housebuilders (including Keepmoat) during 2020 as a result of curtailed construction during the first national lockdown — with the MHCLG estimating that completions and starts of new homes in England fell 17% and 16%, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 — in general the UK housing market has seen robust demand during the pandemic, notwithstanding macro-economic uncertainty. Nationwide and Halifax reported house price increases of 7.3% and 6.0%, respectively, in the year ended December 31, 2020 — the strongest annual growth since 2016. Mortgage lending has also been resurgent with an average of 95,806 monthly mortgage approvals for house purchases in the seven months ended February 28, 2021, the strongest level since 2007. More recent indicators suggest this momentum has continued, with the number of UK residential purchases in March 2021 being 102.3% higher than March 2020 and 32.2% higher than ----- February 2021. This momentum has been supported by the tapered extension to September 30, 2021 of the stamp duty holiday first announced in July 2020. While macroeconomic factors broadly affect the UK residential property market as a whole, property trends in the UK historically have varied significantly by region, particularly as between London and the South East on the one hand and the rest of the UK on the other hand. We operate primarily in lower cost regions (with all of our nine regions based outside of the greater London area, primarily in the Midlands and the North) where homes are generally more affordable and where prices tend not to fluctuate as much as in higher cost regions. As a result, our homes are generally priced at the more affordable end of the market (with an ASP of £174,000 in the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and £165,000 in the financial year ended October 31, 2020), providing us with a degree of resilience against macroeconomic downturns. Additionally, in many of these lower cost regions, mortgages are typically more affordable than rents, which provides additional impetus for first-time buyers to buy in lieu of renting. We sell the majority of our homes into the private market, but we are committed to a strategy of delivering homes of mixed tenure – predominantly for open market sale, affordable rent and shared ownership – helping to provide a degree of resilience in the longer term through diversification. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site), with the remaining 26% of sales to Registered Providers for affordable housing pursuant to Section 106 obligations or otherwise agreed with Registered Providers at the outset of development, where we believe demand is less subject to changing macroeconomic conditions. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 were to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (74% in the financial year ended October 31, 2019). The ASP of our homes sold through open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was £165,000. Each of our regions develops and markets its homes according to local conditions and competes with both new build housing providers who sell houses at a price point similar to us and the secondary housing market. As a result, local market valuations of both new and secondary homes can impact prices and our revenues. Our results are also affected to a certain extent by the supply of housing in the second hand-market, as increased stock in the second-hand market typically leads to lower demand for, and fewer opportunities to construct, new homes. However, in general, the supply of housing in the UK market has lagged behind demand, and the regions where we operate in particular are characterized by a supply-demand imbalance. This shortfall has created favorable trends for housing developers and has encouraged the UK and devolved Scottish governments to take various stimulus measures, which have been beneficial for us. The Government has announced their target to build 300,000 homes per year by the mid-2020s (as announced in the Autumn Budget 2017), and we expect there to be continued support for the housebuilding sector as the Government seeks to achieve this target.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our Land Pipeline and Land Creditor Profile
Subsubsection Text: Our business and financial returns are highly dependent on acquiring land suitable for new homes on acceptable commercial terms and developing such projects without significant delay. A significant portion of our cost of sales relate to the costs of purchasing land. In general, lower land prices help us to sustain a capital light business model and is one of the components of achieving favorable returns. The costs of securing land in our consolidated income statement from period to period will be influenced by the terms on which the land is secured — in particular, whether payment is made up front, in phases or on deferred payment terms. Therefore, our results of operations are significantly affected by the price of land, and the terms on which it is acquired or secured for development. As of July 31, 2021, the number of plots within our land pipeline was 24,654, with approximately 81% of our land pipeline, or 19,933 plots, being legally secured (meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract). As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline, or 4,721 plots, were those on which we had been appointed preferred developer (meaning that we had been chosen by the land vendor as the final candidate to progress to contract for the development of the site). Together, these plots are equivalent to a six-year supply of homes, based on our pre-pandemic annual completion levels. Our land pipeline provides us with a significant degree of visibility with respect to expected home completions and, as a result, our revenues in the near to medium term. Our partnership-focused business model differentiates us from most traditional UK housebuilders in the type of land we focus on and the way we source and deliver the land. We source land through both public and ----- private sector partners. We believe that by understanding the bid brief and being agile and resourceful in delivering on land vendors’ requirements, we make ourselves an attractive partner. Land sourced through our partnership model constituted 79% of our total land pipeline as of July 31, 2021, with the remainder being sourced through speculative land deals (where we believe we can achieve attractive financial returns). Our largest source of land is the public sector, typically Homes England and Local Authorities, with whom we achieve a high proportion of repeat business. These projects are usually brought to market through a competitive tender process, determined by the FTS (previously OJEU) process, which governs how the public sector disposes of its land assets and procures development services. In the case of Homes England, this is effected through DPP3, of which we are a member. As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our secured land pipeline was secured through the Homes England DPP process. Historically, being a member of DPP3 has reduced the number of competitors that we compete against to secure large scale public land opportunities, providing us access to development sites typically unavailable to housebuilders who are not members of DPP3. Homes England launched its successor to the DPP, the DPDPS, on September 1, 2021, which is designed to modernize the bidding process through the use of a digital system and encourage new entrants to the market, simplifying the process for housebuilders to join the list of preferred developers and bid for land. We have submitted our application and received confirmation that we have been appointed member of the DPDPS. The DPDPS is not expected to be used to procure schemes until late 2021. With this new system, housebuilders will still have to qualify to be able to join the list of preferred developers, but they will be able to apply to join at any time, rather than only upon renewal of the delivery partner panel once every four years, as is currently the case. However, we believe that the depth of our experience working with Homes England and other public sector partners on large scale development projects provide us with a distinct competitive advantage. We also source land from the private sector, through relationships with a small number of national land owners and regionally with land owners and land agents. Public bodies often focus on disposing of brownfield land, which typically has a lower land value and can therefore provide a greater potential upside upon development (depending on regeneration costs). This contributes to our relatively low average land cost (approximately £20,000 per plot (equating to approximately 12.1% of our average ASP of £165,000) in the financial year ended October 31, 2020). Brownfield sites represented 73% of our legal completions in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Our participation in a partnership development may be structured in a number of ways, which are intended to provide a blend of risk and return appropriate to the land being acquired. Arrangements may involve that we acquire the land being developed (sometimes in phases) or otherwise we may be granted with development rights while the original land owner retains ownership of the site and ultimately transfers completed units directly to the home purchaser. In the case of phased drawdowns, the price is generally finalized at the time the Group is ready to draw the particular phase of the site down for development. In such arrangements, we have sufficient time to complete all of our technical due-diligence to be able to appraise the phase based on the prevailing conditions, utilizing all the experience gained from developing the previous phase. Phased drawdowns provide us with increased visibility of the end-market and associated cost implications, which thereby reduces our market risk associated with pre-bought land. Additionally, where possible, we use deferred payment terms. As of July 31, 2021, approximately 86% of our current land pipeline included some form of deferred land payment terms. In these arrangements, rather than paying for the land up front, payments are typically structured with deferred payments to be made either on fixed dates, on a “pay per plot” sold basis or in instalments tied to milestones such as the sale of a defined cumulative number of plots or similar development milestones. In addition, some of our arrangements with development partners include overage mechanisms, whereby we make additional payments to the development partner following completion of the land sale contingent upon exceeding agreed financial thresholds, with such payments often deferred to the end of the development of a site or a significant phase of the development. Together, these deferred payment obligations and overage obligations comprise our land creditor commitments. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Commitments and Contingent Liabilities—Land Creditor _Commitments” below for further details of our land creditor commitments as of July 31, 2021._ We believe that our land creditor profile provides us with an element of risk mitigation, as the majority of our payments are linked to development delivery milestones rather than needing to be made up front. Our land creditor commitments are unwound as the relevant payments for these deferred land costs fall due and are made from period to period. Our results of operations during each period will therefore be affected by a variety of factors related to land procurement, including the number of developments, the number of completions and the structure of the ----- partnership arrangement (in particular, whether we are acquiring the land, whether the drawdown is in phases and whether there are deferred payment terms).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The development of land is partly driven by the timing of the planning approval process, including the receipt of those consents which are required to deliver proposed schemes. The overall timeframe for completing the planning approval process affects how quickly we are able to realize revenue from our developments, and any complications that arise during the planning process can increase our costs, including those related to third party planning experts. The planning approval process typically takes from six to twelve months, depending on the complexity of the application and may take a longer or shorter amount of time. We are required to comply with national, local and other laws and regulations and administrative requirements and policies relating to, among other things, planning, developing, building and land use. In addition, we are required to obtain numerous permits and approvals from local authorities and other regulatory bodies regarding, among other things, remediation, roads, drainage, utilities, including gas, electricity and water, and waste removal as well as UK Town & Country Planning Act obligations. These requirements are more complex when we are developing brownfield sites. Of the 24,654 plots in our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021, approximately 19,400, or 79%, benefit from a planning permission, of which 66% have a detailed planning consent and 13% have an outline planning consent. The remaining 21% currently do not benefit from a planning consent. Of our estimated completions for the financial year ending October 31, 2021, 100% have planning permission in place.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Relationships with Homes England, Local Authorities, other Public and Private Land Owners and Registered Providers
Subsubsection Text: Due to our partnership model, our success depends substantially on our reputation and ability to maintain strong relationships with public and private land owners as well as Registered Providers. In particular, we benefit from strong, long-standing relationships with both public bodies (including Homes England, Local Authorities and charitable organizations, and Registered Providers) and private land owners, and 79% of the plots in our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021 were being developed under the partnership model. These relationships are built through a successful track-record of delivering projects, a reputation for aligning our approach with our partners’ objectives and a deep understanding of the motivations beyond financial returns that are key to these partners, including social value, sustainability, accelerated delivery and design quality. Working with public sector partners also provides us with the potential to access grant funding and investment support (particularly from Homes England and Local Authority partners) to facilitate the development of land that would otherwise be unviable to develop. Partnership projects are typically awarded by public bodies through competitive public procurement processes, often based on the Local Authority’s or housing association’s perception of a developer’s expertise, track record and experience with regeneration projects, design quality, reputation, price and value. Our largest delivery partner is Homes England, we have been a member of all successive DPPs to date (DPP 1, 2 and 3) and we are one of the most active developers on DPP3. As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline was secured through the Homes England DPP process. In each of these public procurement processes, we tailor our bids in accordance with the bidding criteria released by the authority, and we believe that we enjoy a significant advantage against many competing bidders by virtue of our deep understanding of the public procurement process, combined with our experience and track record of delivering notable regeneration and development projects aligning with the social goals of public sector partners. Our partnership model and our focus on working with partners in the affordable end of the housing market allow us to achieve capital light land sourcing and site development, with typically lower land prices and favorable (often deferred) payment terms, as well as the ability to access grant funding. We also experience a number of benefits from our work with Registered Providers, including (i) the use of multi-tenure housing (such as share ownership homes), which provide a natural complement to our open market sales; (ii) resilience through the economic cycle as Registered Providers are well funded by the UK Government; (iii) a capital efficient workstream, with Registered Providers often paying incrementally, but in advance for homes as they are built, often with a significant upfront deposit which thereby strengthens our project ROCE; (iv) the potential for additional elective sales during the development of a site on attractive financial terms which provide additional revenue visibility; and (v) strong appetite for homes from Registered Providers who then in ----- turn generate strong commercial offers typically close to full open market value (outside of the sales pursuant to Section 106 obligations, which are often at a significant discount to open market value). As a result of our use of the partnership model, our relationships with Homes England, other public and private land owners and Registered Providers have a significant impact on the development opportunities available to us and, therefore, the number of homes that we sell and our revenues from period to period. As a result, our reputation and relationships with Homes England and key Local Authorities are critical to our success.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: The Availability and Affordability of UK Residential Mortgages
Subsubsection Text: Home purchases in the UK are often facilitated through mortgage lending, and 89% and 91% of our homes that were sold through private sales were purchased by customers with the assistance of mortgages in the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively. A large proportion of buyers of our homes are first-time buyers, who are especially dependent upon the availability of mortgages. As a result, the UK mortgage market and the availability of financing options directly impact our customers’ ability to secure long-term financing to purchase our homes. Our revenue is therefore directly influenced by the willingness of banks to lend to customers at affordable rates and any change in available mortgage products can have a significant impact on our revenue. Reduced availability of affordable mortgage financing and factors that increase the upfront or monthly cost of financing the purchase of a home, including increases in interest rates, insurance premiums or taxes or other charges associated with the purchase or ownership of a home, all impact the affordability of, and therefore the level of demand for, the homes that we build. The general UK economy significantly influences interest rates and, subsequently, mortgage rates. The continuing availability of a wide range of mortgage financing options and low interest rates has in recent years ensured that funding remains affordable in the markets where we are focused. During the period under review, the Bank of England base rate has ranged from 0.75% to 0.1%. However, increases in the base rate have previously had a negative impact on the UK property market because interest rates charged on mortgages increased correspondingly, thereby making home purchases less affordable for prospective buyers. Prospective buyers who can obtain a mortgage at current interest rates may be deterred by the possibility of increased rates (and, in turn, higher monthly interest payments) in the future and instead elect to remain in their current property or to continue renting. Higher mortgage interest rates would likely have an adverse impact on our transaction volumes and the revenue derived from them. Against the backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK Finance estimated that UK gross mortgage lending would fall by an estimated 13% in 2020, to £233 billion, and that it would fall to £215 billion in 2021 before recovering to £230 billion by 2022. However, recent mortgage approval data suggests that mortgage lending in 2021 could be stronger than those estimates indicate, as approvals in the seven months ended July 31, 2021 averaged 84,735 (78% ahead of the comparative period a year prior, which was undisturbed by the COVID19 pandemic). In terms of affordability, Nationwide estimate that first-time buyers in the UK spent an average of 31.7% of mean take-home pay on mortgage payments in the fourth quarter of 2020. This compares to the average since 1983 of 33.1%, a low of 17.5% in 1996 and a high of 55.8% in the fourth quarter of 1989. This demonstrates that while first-time buyer house price-to-earnings multiples are close to an all-time high (5.2x at the end of 2020) mortgage rates are low in a historic context, reflecting low base rates. The price-to-earnings multiple is also highly dependent upon region, with average multiples of 5.2x for the North East and 5.7x for the North West, compared to 12.4x for London and the surrounding areas. Lower price-to-earnings multiples indicate greater affordability, and our business is focused principally upon the more affordable regions which are characterized by lower priceto-earnings ratios. We believe that our business is less sensitive to these spreads given our relatively low ASP and, currently, the support of the HTB scheme for first-time buyers, with rates on offer under the scheme trending at approximately 1.7% for three- and five-year fixed rate periods in 2021. However, the HTB scheme is currently scheduled to expire in 2023 and it remains unclear whether the scheme will be extended (and, if it is extended, whether it will be modified) and what impact an expiry or modification would have on the affordability of mortgages for the first-time buyer market. The housebuilding sector and lenders are currently exploring new low-deposit mortgage products to provide additional alternatives for buyers, including a product backed by a mortgage indemnity scheme developed by the Home Builders Federation and other market participants that will offer 95% LTV mortgages for new homes. Upon completion of home purchases offered as part of the scheme, the developer pays a percentage of the purchase price into an insurance policy, which reduces risk for the lender. This scheme is currently being piloted in the ----- North East of the UK but is expected to be rolled out more widely across the UK in 2021 should the trial prove to be successful. Any changes in the availability of mortgage financing, interest rates or lending guidelines or other factors that increase the upfront or monthly cost of financing a home could impact both the demand for our homes and their pricing, which will, in turn, affect our revenue and profitability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: As a UK housebuilder with a particular focus on the affordable end of the UK housing market and firsttime buyers, our results of operations are significantly affected by the level and nature of Government purchase assistance schemes. Since 2016, the UK Government has focused its approach on providing additional new homes through a number of policy statements and initiatives including an increase in its capital funding for its Affordable Homes Programme, a £1 billion loan scheme to support SME housebuilders, confirmation of HTB funding and additional capital for various funds, including the “Housing Infrastructure Fund,” the “Land Release Fund” and the “Planning Delivery Fund.” In addition, the UK government is currently targeting to build 300,000 new homes a year by the mid-2020s, a goal that has significant cross-party support. In June 2021, the UK Government launched a new initiative called “First Homes” will extend the tenures being offered through local authorities planning policy for affordable housing. The First Homes initiative offers first-time buyers the opportunity to buy a home at a discount (minimum 30%) in perpetuity subject to meeting local and key work eligibility criteria. These stimulus measures make it easier for us to sell homes and hence have an impact on our revenue and margins. These government programs are particularly important when traditional mortgage lenders do not have suitable products available for, or are unwilling to provide based on their lending criteria, the full loan amount required by home buyers. A significant number of our customers have used HTB, a UK government equity loan scheme designed to encourage home ownership in the UK. The HTB program provides assistance to purchasers of new-build homes in the UK by reducing the minimum down payment required from the purchaser to 5% of a property’s value and providing an equity loan of up to 20%, or 40% in London, of the property value (originally available up to a value of £600,000). HTB sales represented approximately 68% of our private sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. The HTB scheme has been modified and extended to March 2023, but with reforms restricting the scheme to support only first-time buyers from April 1, 2021 onwards and with regional price caps ranging from £186,100 in the North East to £600,000 in London. As a result of these reforms, non-first-time buyers who previously would have been able to secure funding through the HTB scheme are no longer eligible to do so, which in turn could have an adverse impact on our home sales. In addition, the HTB scheme remains subject to future regulatory changes, including to applicable eligibility criteria, and such changes may affect the availability of government funding of mortgages, which in turn may affect public demand in the homes market. It is not currently known whether the HTB scheme will be extended after 2023 or, if it is extended, how it may be modified, or whether any other similar UK Government-backed program will continue at current levels, or at all, or that lenders will participate in them. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business— A majority of our business is secured _or supported either directly or indirectly from various Government sources, and changes in local or Government funds, loans, grants or subsidies, or changes to or the discontinuation of mortgage assistance schemes or equity loan schemes (including in particular Help to Buy) could significantly impact our business.”_ Scotland has a separate program (Help to Buy (Scotland)), and its “Affordable New Build Scheme” available to larger housebuilders (including Keepmoat) stopped accepting new applications on February 5, 2021. However, we believe that this has not had a material effect on demand for our homes in Scotland. The availability of funding for these programs remains subject to governmental decisions. In the future, governments and/or local bodies may change their priorities and programs, for example, by reducing or amending mortgage assistance schemes, or undertaking welfare reforms that may impact funding stability for housing associations and local authorities. Any reduction or discontinuation of UK Government-backed home purchase assistance programs in the future may make it more difficult for our core first-time buyer customers to afford homes, which would make it more difficult for us to sell homes and may force us to either lower prices or increase purchase incentives. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our profitability is influenced by the number of legal completions we achieve and the margin we earn on those completions. The margins we earn can vary significantly and depend on the underlying profitability of the projects, the types of homes sold and the location of the sites. Therefore, our results can be significantly affected by product mix and regional mix. In terms of product mix, our results are affected in particular by the split between open market sales and sales to Registered Providers. We pursue a strategy that blends the potential of margin enhancement through higher-margin open-market sales with the certainty, risk mitigation and cash generation of selling to Registered Providers for affordable rent and shared ownership housing. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, we sold 74% of our plots on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site), with 26% to Registered Providers as part of Section 106 affordable housing obligations in connection with planning consents or otherwise agreed with Registered Providers at the outset of development. In comparison, in the financial year ended October 31, 2019, we sold 78% of our plots in the open market and 22% to Registered Providers. Although the sales prices of homes sold to Registered Providers pursuant to Section 106 affordable housing obligations are typically lower than open market sales, and involve lower margins, the sales often involve the Registered Providers forward funding these, both providing revenue visibility and reducing the working capital needs of sites. In addition, this enables us to use the cash proceeds from such sales to accelerate delivery of site outputs, ultimately generating an enhanced ROCE. In addition to the sales in connection with Section 106 obligations, we are able to agree additional sales to Registered Providers either at the outset of a development (in which case we categorize these as Registered Provider sales, alongside the sales pursuant to Section 106 obligations) or as elective sales during the development of a site (in which case we categorize these as open market sales). In either case, for sales outside of Section 106 obligations the Registered Providers are able to utilize Affordable Homes Programme funding, which helps to generate attractive commercial offers. In particular, elective sales agreed during the development of a site are benchmarked against other open market sale opportunities and are often at only a small discount to the open market price. Our results are also affected by the regional mix of sales among our nine regions, with some of our regions having higher ASPs than other regions. For example, in the nine months ended July 31, 2021, our regional ASPs ranged from £138,000 in our North West MCI region to £221,000 in our South Midlands region. Our results may therefore vary from period to period as we expand our operations in certain regions and based on the location of the development opportunities available to us in each period. While our product mix and regional mix is largely within our control, we are impacted by external factors, in particular the availability of planning consents and government policy. In the near term, our margins are also affected by site mix, reflecting the fact that current management has implemented an enhanced land sourcing process that we believe has resulted in a progressively increasing mix of higher quality, better procured sites. For example, for sites under development that were approved between 2017 and 2019 (excluding the North West MCI region), average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval range from approximately 22% to 23% by year, whereas for sites either approved since 2020 or within our secured pipeline and to be approved, average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval or for the “to be approved” category, range from approximately 24% to 25% by year or category. This is an increase from the average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for sites under development that were approved in 2016 and pre-2016, for which average forecasted fullsite-life Gross Development Margins are approximately 21% and 18%, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our Cost Base, including the Supply and Cost of Sub-contractors and Materials
Subsubsection Text: A significant portion of our cost of sales relate to the costs of building our housing developments, including the costs of raw materials and labor. Factors outside our control, including raw materials prices and wage costs, can have a material impact on these costs and, accordingly, our financial results. We sub-contract a large proportion of the actual construction of our developments to third-party providers and therefore our ability to source sub-contractors that meet our strict quality requirements and rate/price expectations are important to our business. We compete for labor with our competitors in the housebuilding sector and with housebuilders in other sectors and, therefore, changes in the labor market directly impact our costs. The concentration of our sub-contractors is low. This diversification reduces our exposure to individual subcontractor ----- risk. In addition, in order to reduce risks of subcontractor rate increases on developments, we typically aim to lock in subcontractor prices over a phase, or part-phase, of a development through “all risk” contracts. We are directly exposed to the cyclicality of the construction industry, which impacts the labor market. During periods of market contraction, pools of labor leave the market, sometimes permanently, for example to retrain in other professions or move abroad in search of work. During periods of increased construction activity, competition among housebuilders for qualified labor increases and the associated impact on labor rates and availability can impact us, and result in materially higher labor costs. This has been demonstrated during the current financial year, with high levels of construction activity in the UK housebuilding sector giving rise to increasing competition for skilled labor and a consequential increase in labor costs. We are also affected by our ability to source sufficient materials at competitive prices. The cyclicality of the construction industry also impacts the supply of materials so that in times of market contraction, production is scaled back and therefore when markets recover there can be a lag on supply which pushes prices upwards. More generally, periods of increased construction activity can give rise to demand and supply imbalances which tend to increase construction costs. For example, a significant increase in UK housebuilding activity during the current financial year has resulted in a significant increase in demand for construction materials and a lengthening of supplier delivery times. Data released by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy indicated that the overall cost of materials for new housing was 6.7% higher in January 2021 than in January 2020. An IHS Markit/Cips UK survey published in May 2021 indicated that input-cost inflation had increased for the seventh month in a row to its highest level since the survey began in April 1997, with steel and timber experiencing particularly sharp price rises. We seek to mitigate any supply shortages and cost inflation risk by having strong supplier relationships that can meet our demands. Our material supply-chain strategy is underpinned by annual, Group-wide deals with suppliers with national coverage. This enables us to negotiate better commercial terms through consolidated volume and enables the utilization of volume-related rebates. We operate a series of group-wide, long-term strategic frameworks providing preferential commercial terms and service levels nationally and regionally for supply of materials, site equipment and business consumables. Our supply chain team manage over 96 arrangements which are made up of framework agreements, commercial arrangements and formal price lists. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88% of our direct spend was channeled through these frameworks. Our use of standardized designs helps to reduce and improve the predictability of costs, improves construction build times and quality and continues to provide us with the flexibility to utilize our skills and experience in design and place-making by tailoring aspects of our standardized designs to each particular development. Although the amount of homes built using our standardized type varies from year to year, in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88% of our homes were build using a standardized house type. We believe that our shift to increased construction standardization can help reduce costs and build times while continuing to allow us to utilize our skills and experience in design and place-making. We also seek to mitigate the risk of price rises through the use of phased viability in developments where possible, allowing increased build costs to be included in future phases following updated viability assessments, facilitating the delivery of our required financial returns if the cost base increases on subsequent phases. This mechanism mitigates the impact of cost increases on future phases, but does not affect cost increases during the construction of a particular phase. Our supply chain and costs could also be affected by political events, such as the ongoing effects of Brexit. We have worked closely with our supply chain since the Brexit vote to ensure that we understand the changes arising from Brexit. We have continued with this close engagement since the confirmation of the new trade arrangements to understand their challenges and contingency strategies. These include careful monitoring, increasing UK stock holding and diverting imports to alternative UK ports where bottlenecks are predicted. At this stage, we have not experienced any significant supply chain issues associated with Brexit. Central overhead costs (including central administrative personnel as well as non-personnel overhead costs for central office rental and rates as well as IT costs, insurance, audit, legal, tax and other consultancy services and other expenses) represented 3% and 4% of our revenue in the years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively, while regional overhead costs (including regional administrative personnel as well as nonpersonnel overhead costs for regional office rental and rates and other expenses) represented 6% and 8% of our revenue. ----- Our overhead has risen in recent years as a result of our expansion into new regions. However, as our operations in these regions mature, we expect to capture greater operational efficiencies and reduce overhead costs as a percentage of revenue, enhancing our profit margins. We expect this decrease in overhead costs as a percentage of revenue will be driven principally by efficiencies of scale in growth regions and central overheads. We have also made significant investments in personnel at both the regional and head office level to support our growth and build a national platform for future expansion in our target geographies. Margins have remained stable over this period and we have proven our ability to invest and grow scale.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Historically, our revenues and levels of working capital have varied during the year due to peaks of completions in certain months of the year. As a consequence, our debt profile has exhibited peaks and troughs over the course of the financial year consistent with seasonal trends. The timing of completions within a financial year is influenced by a number of factors. Typically, the majority of our reservations for open market sales are made in January to March and August to October (with the latter correlated to the start of the new school year). Our ability to manage the timeline from the engagement and planning phase to the exchange of contract and legal completion is, therefore, one of the factors that affects the timing of completions. Although we generally have a significant degree of flexibility in managing the phasing of completions and typically aim to stagger the timing of our completions to the extent practicable, the impact of weather on building activity and plot delivery has also tended to favor a peak in completions in the late summer and early autumn. In addition, prior to the change of the KM Group’s financial year end from March 31 to October 31 in 2018, divisional efforts to achieve targets and maximize sales for the financial year end led to a peak of completions in March. This had an effect on our results of operations for the financial year ended October 31, 2019, as our incentive scheme for that financial year remained tied to an end date of March 31. However, we do not expect this to have an impact on our financial results in any subsequent years. For the financial year ended October 31, 2021 we have amended our incentive targets to include an additional measure tied to half-year targets, in order to achieve a more levelled number of completions throughout the financial year. The above factors may lead to volatility in our quarterly financial results. These factors that affect the phasing of completions through a financial year tend to result in a weighting of plot completions, and accordingly revenue and profit, to the last quarter of financial years. Results of a single fiscal quarter or half year might therefore not be a reliable basis for the expectations of a full financial year and may not be comparable with the results in the other fiscal quarters or half year. Factors that affect our peak selling seasons can have a disproportionate impact on our performance in a particular period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Significant Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations have been, and will continue to be, affected by many factors, some of which are beyond our control. This section sets out certain key factors that we believe have affected our results of operations in the period under review or could affect its results of operations in the future.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Future Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: On August 4, 2021, the Company entered into the Acquisition Agreement with the Sellers pursuant to which, among other things, the Company agreed to indirectly acquire 100% of the share capital of the Target. The Acquisition will be consummated on or about October 27, 2021. The Group is incurring £275.0 million of new debt to (i) fund the consideration payable for the Acquisition, (ii) repay Existing Target Indebtedness, (iii) repay Sellers transaction costs, and (iv) pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. As of July 31, 2021, after giving _pro forma effect to the Transactions as if they had occurred on that date, the Group’s total third party borrowings would have been the £292.6 million in debt represented by the Notes, certain lease liabilities and amounts drawn under the Existing Senior Term Facility. As a result of this increase in third party borrowings, the Company’s interest expense will increase for future periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Change of Financial Year End from March 31 to October 31
Subsubsection Text: In 2018, the KM Group changed its financial year end from March 31 to October 31. As a consequence, the financial year ended October 31, 2018 consists of the seven month period from April 1, 2018 to October 31, ----- 2018 and therefore is not directly comparable with the prior and subsequent financial years of the KM Group, which cover twelve month periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers)_ IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) was issued in 2014 and was endorsed by the EU in 2016. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) establishes a comprehensive framework for determining whether, how much and when revenue is recognized. It replaces existing revenue recognition guidance, including IAS 18 (Revenue). IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) is effective for annual periods beginning on or after January 1, 2018, with early adoption permitted. We adopted IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) from April 1, 2018 in accordance with the fully retrospective transitional approach without using the practical expedients for completed contracts or for modified contracts. We have applied the expedient allowing both non-disclosure of the amount of the transaction price allocated to the remaining performance obligations, and an explanation of when it expects to recognize that amount as revenue for all reporting periods presented before the date of initial application. Under IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers), revenue is recognized based on indicators of control, rather than solely when risks and rewards are transferred. This can lead to differences in revenue recognition on certain sites, based on the specific contractual arrangements in place. The majority of our revenue and profit, including revenue from open market sales, continues to be recognized on legal completion. For those sites in respect of which stage payments are received from Registered Providers, revenue is recognized based on stage of completion rather than on legal completion. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) also sets out the requirements for recognition of noncash consideration as revenue. Previously, where we entered into arrangements to provide housing to Registered Providers at below open market value in exchange for discounted land from partners, the associated housing unit revenue was recorded at open market value. IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) does not permit this, as the exchange transaction (land discount from partner) is not received directly from the customer (the Registered Provider) and so does not meet the criteria of non-cash consideration. This change has the impact of reducing reported revenue. Accordingly, the revenue recognized in respect of these housing units will be equal to the cash consideration received from Registered Providers, with no open market value adjustment. There are a limited number of developments where the eventual buyer of the affordable units is the same entity as the land vendor. In these instances, the discount received represents non-cash consideration, which continues to be recognized as revenue. _IFRS 16 (Leases)_ On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), and the European Union adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on November 9, 2017. IFRS 16 (Leases) replaced IAS 17 (Leases) and the related International Financial Reporting Interpretations Committee’s and the Standards Interpretation Committee’s interpretations, and results in almost all leases being recognized on the balance sheet, as the distinction between operating and finance leases is eliminated. Under the new standard, the lessee recognizes an asset (the right to use the leased asset) and a financial liability to pay lease payments. The only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases. IFRS 16 (Leases) is effective for fiscal years commencing on or after January 1, 2019, with early adoption permitted if IFRS 15 (Revenue from Contracts with Customers) has also been applied. We adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) from November 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective approach. Under this approach, comparative information is not restated and the cumulative effect of initially applying IFRS 16 (Leases) is recognized in retained earnings at the date of initial application. In particular, as a consequence of IFRS 16 (Leases) our total assets and liabilities increased as the right of use asset associated with leases and the corresponding liability, which were previously treated as operating leases, are recognized on the balance sheet. In addition, operating lease expenditure has been reclassified and split between depreciation and finance cost, and as a result, our EBITDA increased. IFRS 16 (Leases) was effective for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. The impact of adopting IFRS 16 (Leases) for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was the recognition of right of use assets of £8.0 million and lease liabilities of £8.6 million on transition in respect of offices, company vehicles, site plant equipment and show homes. The impact on Adjusted EBITDA for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was ----- £0.6 million. This information may not be indicative of the impact of the adoption of IFRS 16 (Leases) on our total assets, total liabilities and EBITDA for the next financial year or any future period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance during the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was affected significantly by the COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of program disruption and the costs of operating with COVID-19 working practices and social-distancing measures, our delivery volumes declined significantly given construction activity was significantly stalled from April through August 2020, our margins declined slightly compared to the financial year ended October 31, 2019 and our EBIT and ROCE performance eroded significantly. However, as demonstrated by our performance for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and our forward order book, we have recovered strongly from the COVID-19 pandemic and we believe that we are well positioned to deliver on our planned growth in the medium term. We have benefitted from a robust UK housing market, with a favorable mortgage environment, ongoing government support and strong demand, against the resilient economic backdrop during the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite the strict lockdown measures that were imposed through April 2021, for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, our Adjusted EBIT and ROCE increased 12.8% and 150 basis points, respectively, as compared to the financial year ended October 31, 2019. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrates the resiliency and strength of our business model. The COVID-19 lockdown restrictions imposed in March 2020 caused our financial performance to decline but did not stress our overall financial profile given the lower risk inherent in our partnership model. In addition, during the financial year ended October 31, 2020, £24.4 million in partner payments were deferred, representing approximately 80% of our total commitments, which illustrates the flexible land creditor profile we maintain.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue is recognized based on indicators of control, rather than solely when risks and rewards are transferred. This can lead to differences in revenue recognition on certain sites, based on the specific contractual arrangements in place. The majority of our revenue and profit, including revenue from open market sales, is recognized at legal completion. For those sites in respect of which stage payments are received from Registered Providers (which are government approved organizations that provides Affordable Housing, including Housing Associations, Local Authorities and private companies) for the provision of housing or where we undertake development contracts, revenue is recognized based on stage of completion rather than on legal completion. We consider the provision of land and residential properties to represent a single performance obligation which represents a judgement taken in the application of IFRS 15. _Sale of Housing to Open Market Customers_ Revenue and profits associated with these activities are recognized in the statement of comprehensive income on legal completion. Revenue in respect of the sale of residential properties is recognized at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable upon legal completion. Open market sale plots are recognized at the agreed sales price which is deemed to be fair value. _Sale of Housing to Registered Provider Customers and Associated Development Contracts (with Stage Payments)_ We construct and sell residential properties and undertake associated development activities under longterm contracts with customers. Such contracts are entered into before construction of residential properties or associated development activities begin. Under the terms of the contracts, we are restricted from redirecting the properties or development works to another customer and have an enforceable right to payment for work done. Revenue from construction of residential properties and associated development activities is therefore recognized over time based on a certified monthly valuation of work performed or the assessed physical stage of completion at the balance sheet date. We consider that this method is an appropriate measure of the progress towards complete satisfaction of these performance obligations under IFRS 15. ----- _Sale of Housing to Registered Provider Customers (without Stage Payments)_ Revenue and profits associated with these activities are included in the statement of comprehensive income on legal completion, at which point control is passed from us to the purchaser.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales consists of: - costs associated with the investment in land (land purchase costs) which are recognized as WIP (included as inventories in our financial statements) as they are incurred and allocated to plot sales based on remaining plots to be sold at each site; - architectural and engineering fees associated with the design of each site; - build costs, including direct labor, sub-contractors and materials, which are also recognized as WIP (included as inventories in our financial statements) as they are incurred and allocated to plot sales based on remaining plots to be sold at each site; and - sales and marketing costs related to the sales of our homes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Our administrative expenses include both cash and non-cash items and are made up of personnel costs (including wages, salaries, bonuses and national insurance costs) and non-personnel overhead costs for office rentals and rates as well as IT costs and other expenses.

Subsubsection Text: Other operating income includes part exchange property sales.

Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Other operating expenses include associated expenses with part exchange property sales.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Title: Share of Results of Equity Accounted JVs and Associates
Subsubsection Text: Joint ventures and associates are accounted for using the equity method. The share of results of equity accounted JVs and associates represents our share of the entities’ profits or losses for the period. Where the share of losses exceeds our equity accounted investment in a joint venture, the carrying value of the equity interest is reduced to nil and the recognition of further losses is discontinued.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Adjusted operating profit represents gross profit for the applicable period less administrative expenses plus other operating income for such period plus the share of results of equity accounted as part of our joint ventures and associates and excludes exceptional items and amortization of acquisition related intangibles.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Exceptional items are material items of income or expense that have been shown separately in our income statement due to the significance of their nature or amount. Exceptional items for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 amounted to an expense of £38.5 million and related to a share-based payment charge of £19.5 million and advisory fees incurred in relation to the sale of the Group of £19.0 million. Exceptional items for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 amounted to an expense of £1.8 million and related to £1.3 million in respect of a restructuring exercise and £0.5 million in respect of professional advisor costs relating to refinancing and corporate finance matters. Exceptional items for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 amounted to income of £1.3 million and related to the release of an onerous lease provision. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Title: Amortisation of Acquisition Related Intangible Assets
Subsubsection Text: Amortisation of acquisition related intangible assets represents amortization of goodwill arising on acquisition of subsidiary entities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Operating profit represents adjusted operating profit for the applicable period after giving effect to any exceptional items and amortization of acquisition related intangibles during the applicable period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance income is recognized in the income statement in the year or period to which it relates using the effective interest rate method. Finance income comprises interest receivable on loans to joint venture partners; and other interest receivable.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance expense is recognized in the income statement in the year or period in which it occurs. Finance expense comprises: (i) interest payable on term loans and debt securities; (ii) the unwinding of discounts on deferred land payments; (iii) interest payable on bank loans and overdrafts; (iv) finance charges on senior secured notes; (v) interest payable on subordinated shareholder loan notes; (vi) interest payable on other loans; and (vii) interest payable on leases.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income Items
Subsubsection Text: Income tax credit / (charge) includes all current and deferred taxes, as calculated in accordance with the relevant tax laws in force. Income tax is recognized in the income statement except to the extent that it relates to items recognized directly in equity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Group Revenue_ Revenue increased by £222.5 million, or 85.5%, from £260.1 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £482.6 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the prior year impact of lockdown and other restrictions on the ability to complete on sales. ----- _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales increased by £157.0 million, or 70.5%, from £222.7 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £379.7 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the impact on activity levels as a result of COVID-19 restrictions. _Gross Profit_ For the reasons set out above, gross profit increased by £65.6 million, or 175.9%, from £37.3 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £102.9 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. _Administrative Expenses_ Administrative expenses increased by £45.8 million, or 104.1%, from £44.0 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £89.8 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to exceptional expenses of £38.5 million in the nine months ended July 31, 2021, as further explained below in “— _Exceptional Items.” Share of Results of Equity Accounted joint Ventures and Associates_ Share of results of equity accounted joint ventures and associates decreased by £0.3 million, or 50.0%, from £0.6 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £0.3 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to a reduction in the profit share from Sheffield Housing Company Limited. _Adjusted Operating Profit/(Loss)_ For the reasons set out above, adjusted operating profit/(loss) increased by £57.7 million, from a loss of £5.5 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to a profit of £52.2 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. _Exceptional Items_ Exceptional items decreased by £38.0 million, from £0.5 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to a loss of £38.5 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to a sharebased payment charge of £19.5 million and advisory fees incurred in relation to the sale of the Group of £19.0 million. _Amortisation of Acquisition Related Intangible Assets_ Amortisation of acquisition related intangible assets increased by £0.2 million, or 200.0%, from £0.1 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £0.3 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to amortization associated with acquired intangibles. _Operating Profit/(Loss)_ For the reasons set out above, operating profit/(loss) increased by £19.9 million, from a loss of £6.0 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to a profit of £13.9 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. _Finance Income_ Finance income decreased by £0.3 million, or 37.5%, from £0.8 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £0.5 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to lower interest income from a loan to a joint venture. _Finance Expense_ Finance expense increased by £0.7 million, or 3.7%, from £18.9 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £19.6 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the deferred land payment charge of £2.3 million offset by a reduction in the term loan interest charge of £1.4 million. ----- _(Loss)/Profit Before Tax_ For the reasons set out above, (loss)/profit before tax increased by £18.4 million, from a loss of £24.2 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to a loss of £5.8 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. _Income tax credit/(charge)_ Income tax credit/(charge) decreased by £6.0 million, or 96.8%, from £6.2 million, for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to £0.2 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to the reduction in loss before tax when compared to the previous period. _(Loss)/Profit for the Period_ For the reasons set out above, (loss)/profit for the period increased by £12.5 million, from a loss of £18.0 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 to a loss of £5.6 million for the nine months ended July 31, 2021.
