Subsubsection Text: _Group Revenue_ Revenue decreased by £243.8 million, or 37.5%, from £649.8 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £406.0 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the impact of the lockdown and other restrictions on the ability to complete sales. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales decreased by £189.2 million, or 35.7%, from £530.6 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £341.4 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to lower activity levels due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Gross margin also decreased due to loss of plot sales from slower build rates during the COVID-19 pandemic. _Gross Profit_ For the reasons set out above, gross profit decreased by £54.6 million, or 45.8%, from £119.2 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £64.6 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. ----- _Administrative Expenses_ Administrative expenses decreased by £1.6 million, or 2.7%, from £59.8 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £58.2 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily driven by the impact of COVID-19. _Share of Results of Equity Accounted Joint Ventures and Associates_ Share of results of equity accounted joint ventures and associates increased by £1.0 million, from nil for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £1.0 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by our investment in ilke Homes being almost fully written down in the financial year ended October 31, 2019. _Adjusted Operating Profit/(Loss)_ For the reasons set out above, adjusted operating profit/(loss) decreased by £49.1 million, or 83.9%, from £58.5 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £9.4 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. _Exceptional Items_ Exceptional items increased by £3.1 million, from a £1.3 million benefit for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to a £1.8 million charge for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by a lease provision writeback of £1.3 million in the financial year ended October 31, 2019 and restructuring and professional advisor fees incurred in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. _Amortisation of Acquisition Related Intangible Assets_ Amortisation of acquisition related intangible assets decreased by £0.3 million, or 75.0%, from £(0.4) million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £(0.1) million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily driven by amortization associated with acquired intangibles. _Operating Profit_ For the reasons set out above, operating profit decreased by £52.0 million, or 87.5%, from £59.4 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £7.4 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. _Finance Income_ Finance income increased by £0.4 million, or 133.3%, from £0.3 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £0.7 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by higher interest income from a loan to a joint venture. _Finance Expense_ Finance expense increased by £3.7 million, or 16.4%, from £22.5 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to £26.2 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by a full year of interest paid on the new financing facility implemented in the previous year, as well as an increase in our deferred land payment charge of £1.5 million and additional interest charge of £0.5 million as a result of the implementation of IFRS 16. _(Loss)/Profit Before Tax_ For the reasons set out above, (loss)/profit before tax decreased by £55.2 million, from a profit of £37.2 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to a loss of £18.0 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. _Income Tax Credit/(Charge)_ Income tax credit/(charge) increased by £11.6 million, from a charge of £6.9 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to a credit of £4.7 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. This increase was primarily driven by a loss before tax that was incurred in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 as compared to a profit before tax in the prior year. ----- _(Loss)/Profit for the Period_ For the reasons set out above, (loss)/profit for the period decreased by £43.6 million, from a profit of £30.3 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 to a loss of £13.3 million for the financial year ended October 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes the ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs, capital expenditures, debt service obligations, other commitments, contractual obligations and acquisitions. Liquidity risk is the risk that we would be unable to meet our current and future financial obligations as they fall due or can do so only at excessive cost. During the period under review, our primary sources of liquidity were cash flows generated from our operations, along with short- and long-term borrowings. Following the completion of this Offering, our primary sources of liquidity will be our cash from operating activities and the Revolving Credit Facility. Our principal liquidity requirements arise from the need to fund land acquisitions, capital expenditure, labor and raw materials costs and operating expenses for projects and debt service obligations. As of July 31, 2021, we had cash and cash equivalent balances of £45.2 million.

Subsubsection Text: We define changes in working capital as the sum of changes in accrued/deferred income, changes in receivables, changes in subcontractor and supplier payables and other creditors, accruals, provisions, debtors and prepayments, and changes in land and build WIP resulting from the cash flows statement. Our working capital requirements are driven by timing of land payments, plot completions, build WIP and supplier and subcontractor terms. Accrued and deferred income consists of stage payments from Registered Providers, Local Authorities and other housing associations. Payables mainly include invoices from sub-contractors and suppliers. Our contract provisions typically provide for accruals for subcontractor work completed and materials supplied that have not been invoiced. The amount of working capital required to service our operations is closely monitored and controlled and forms a key part of the management information reviewed on a daily, weekly and monthly basis. Current assets mainly comprise trade receivables, WIP and land held for the development of private housing and affordable housing through partnership schemes. As our trade receivables relate mainly to public sector and housing association clients, there is no significant history of bad or doubtful debts.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Cash and cash equivalents at the end of the period .......** **35.2** **56.8** **53.9** **37.9
Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditure requirements are relatively low and primarily comprise investments in IT and computer equipment. Capital expenditure for the nine months ended July 31, 2021 and 2020 was £1.7 million and £1.0 million, respectively. Capital expenditure for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 was £1.3 million and for the financial year ended October 31, 2019 was £0.8 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (1) Operating leases refers to the leasing of show home properties, office space, cars and plant hire used in construction and development. Operating leases are presented on the basis of gross cash commitments as they become due, which differs from the presentation of operating leases on our consolidated balance sheet, which is prepared on a discounted basis. (2) Non-cancellable contracts for purchase of land is presented on the basis of gross cash commitments as they become due, which differs from the presentation of non-cancellable contracts for purchase of land on our consolidated balance sheet, which is prepared on a discounted basis. (3) Payments are not tied to specific dates but rather the performance of certain milestones. Maturity is forecasted based on expected plot completions and other performance obligations. Our obligations to land creditors were £217.9 million as of July 31, 2021, and are recorded as “development land payables” within “trade and other payables” on our balance sheet. Development land payables includes (i) lease liabilities where we have acquired the right to develop land under a build lease, (ii) contractual obligations to pay for land on deferred payment terms and (iii) accrued overage agreements in relation to our profit agreements with land vendors, which will only become payable if agreed financial thresholds are met. Overage payable is estimated based on expected future cash flows in relation to relevant developments and, where payment will take place in more than one year, is discounted. Development land payables are recorded at their fair value on the date of acquisition of the asset to which they relate and subsequently held at amortized cost. The discount to the nominal value is amortized over the period of the credit term and charged to finance costs using the effective interest rate. Changes in estimates of the final payment due are taken to inventory (land held for and under development) and in due course, to cost of sales in the income statement. Changes to the timing of any deferred payments are taken to finance costs. The table below sets forth a breakdown of the timing of our current and non-current development land payables by year:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet our financial obligations as and when they fall due. Our objective is to manage liquidity by ensuring that we will always have sufficient liquidity to meet our ----- liabilities as they become due. This is assessed under normal and stress conditions, without incurring losses or risking damage to our reputation. In connection with the Transactions, we will establish the Revolving Credit Facility in the amount of £70 million. We believe we have a rigorous cash management processes. Cash balances are reported daily with detailed analysis of variances to short term cash forecasts. Short term cash forecasts are updated monthly and for a period of 26 weeks, with the first eight weeks on a daily basis and the remaining 18 weeks on a weekly basis. These complement our minimum of four long term quarterly cash forecasts each year which are compared to the annual cash flow budget and to previous quarterly forecasts. These facilitate management’s assessments of our expected cash performance and to compare to the facilities available and our covenants. Key risks to liquidity and cash balances are a decrease in the value of open market sales, a downturn in the UK housing market, deterioration in credit terms obtainable in the market from suppliers and subcontractors, a downturn in the profitability of work, delayed receipt of cash from customers and a general decline in the ability of local authorities to fund urban regeneration projects. In order to mitigate this risk we continually monitor open market house sales volumes and prices; continuous monitoring of working capital levels and contract profitability and the review of client and supplier credit references and credit terms with clients and suppliers to ensure they continue to be appropriate. We do not have any derivative financial liabilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate risk relates to the impact of interest rate increases on our floating rate borrowing. We hold facilities at floating interest rates at a margin over LIBOR. Our floating rate financing has increased our liquidity but has also increased our exposure to interest rate fluctuations. While the risk of increased interest rates are beyond our control, we continually keep our exposure under review.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are affected by price fluctuations of the UK housing market. The market is impacted by consumer demand and employment levels and is dependent on the availability of mortgage finance. Furthermore, Government incentives, including the Help to Buy scheme, have helped to stimulate consumer demand. While these risks are beyond our ultimate control, we have mitigated certain elements of this risk by diversifying across differing business activities and geographical regions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk relates to our risk of financial loss if a customer fails to meet their contractual obligations. The risk mainly arises on our trade receivables and amounts due from construction contract customers. IFRS 9 requires an expected credit loss model, rather than an incurred credit loss model to be applied. This requires the assessment of the expected credit loss on each class of financial asset at each reporting date. This assessment takes into consideration changes in credit risk since initial recognition of the financial asset. Our exposure to credit risk is limited for open market housebuilding activities as we typically receive cash at the point of legal completion of our sales. The credit risk on Registered Provider sales depends on the individual characteristics of the counterparty, many of whom are in the public sector or are funded by the public sector (e.g., housing associations). We believe the credit rating of these customers to be good and the credit risk on outstanding balances to be low. A highly immaterial provision is present in all periods. We do not have any concentration of risk in respect of amounts due from construction contract receivables or trade receivable balances, with receivables spread across a wide range of customers. We apply the simplified approach under IFRS 9 to measure expected credit losses associated with trade and other receivables. The carrying value of receivables is reduced at each reporting date for any increase in the lifetime expected credit losses with an impairment loss recognized in the statement of comprehensive income. We ----- are of the opinion that there is a significant concentration of credit risk for those balances past due greater than one year. As of July 31, 2021, trade receivables with a carrying amount of £2.7 million are past due (October 31, 2020: £1.8 million; October 31, 2019: £10.5 million) and £0.2 million are impaired (October 31, 2020: £0.2 million; October 31, 2019: £0.8 million).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We do not hedge against foreign currency exposure due to our minimal exposure to foreign currency movements, as our business is conducted entirely in the UK and primarily in pound sterling.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices such as interest rates, house prices and foreign exchange rates will affect our income or the value of our financial instruments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The gross profit from revenue generated on each of our developments in a specific period is based on our latest forecast for the gross profit expected to be generated over the life of that development or phase. The expected gross profit is calculated as an output of development valuations completed using the latest selling prices and forecasts of all land and construction costs associated with the development. These calculations of expected gross profit require a degree of estimation due to their long-term nature and are sensitive to future movements in both the estimated cost to complete and expected selling prices. Our management has established internal controls to regularly review and ensure the appropriateness of the forecasts and estimates made on an individual development basis. However, a change in estimated gross profits over a number of developments (due, for example, to changes in estimates of costs remaining or a reduction in average selling prices in the private market) could materially affect profitability. As an illustration, a reasonably possible change in profits of 1% across all developments in the period to July 31, 2021 would have reduced gross profit and net assets by an estimated £4.8 million (October 31, 2020: £4.1 million; October 31, 2019: £6.5 million).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Judgement Over the Right to Develop Land Under a Build Lease
Subsubsection Text: We enter into arrangements with land owners under which we acquire an interest in land under a build lease with the benefit of a right to develop. The directors judge these arrangements as in-substance purchases and not leases under the scope of IFRS 16. This is on the basis that: (i) we have physical possession of the land and have accepted the asset; (ii) the land owner has an enforceable right to payment; (iii) the freehold is passed to the end customer; and (iv) we take on any risks associated with the land and ultimately benefit from the reward on sale of the developed plots. On this basis, land rights acquired under these arrangements are treated as inventories and are held at the lower of cost or net realizable value as per our accounting policy for inventories.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of historical financial information under IFRS requires that our management make judgements, estimates and assumptions that affect the application of policies and reported amounts of assets and liabilities, income and expenses. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and various other factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis of making judgements about the carrying value of assets and liabilities which are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis and any revisions to them are recognized in the period in which they are revised. The estimates and judgements that have a risk of causing a material adjustment to the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities within the next financial year are addressed below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: INDUSTRY OVERVIEW History and Overview of United Kingdom Housing Market
Subsubsection Text: Housing output in the United Kingdom has ranged between approximately 130,000 and 250,000 completions per annum since 1980, a level much lower than in the 1960s and 1970s when direct local authority build programs pushed housing completions toward 400,000 per annum. Against this backdrop, private sector housing completions have trended between 150,000 and 210,000 per annum since the 1960s – except for the periods immediately following the 1970s’ recession and the global financial crisis that started in 2008 (the “GFC”) when completions fell below this level. This is in contrast to many European countries where housebuilding rates per person have exceeded that of the UK. In 2004, the Government commissioned the Barker Report to conduct a review of the underlying supply issues and responsiveness of housing in the UK, with due consideration given to the role of competition, capacity, technology, and finances of the housebuilding industry. In addition, the report sought to explore the interplay between these factors and the wider UK planning system in order to distinguish where shortfalls were presenting themselves. More specifically, the review stated its key objectives as achieving: (1) improvements in housing affordability in the market sector; (2) a more stable housing market; (3) a location of housing supply which supports patterns of economic data; and (4) an adequate supply of publicly-funded housing for those who need it. As the report highlighted, the aforementioned level of housebuilding fell short of the growth in household formations and resulted in the recommendation that the UK should be building 240,000 houses per annum to reduce the growth in house prices to zero real growth. The report also highlighted the greatest shortfall of housing provision was within the affordable housing marketplace and recommended that greater Government subsidy in this area was required. While UK housebuilding rates improved post the Barker Report to 223,590 homes in 2007, the impact of the GFC resulted in housing completions falling to a record low of 135,980 in 2010. This was compounded by the stress in the banking sector and led to mortgage approvals for house purchases falling to approximately 26,000 in November 2008, compared to pre-GFC mortgage volumes which did not fall below 100,000 per month. These trends in housing completions have been against the backdrop of a growing housing shortage, as demonstrated by the following graph displaying the cumulative housing shortage in England between 2007 and 2020: This backdrop has led to the Government taking a more active role in the UK housing market, to promote home ownership and higher levels of housing completions. Arguably the most effective program has been the Help to Buy equity loan scheme, which was announced in April 2013 and provides buyers who contribute deposits of at least 5% with an interest free equity loan of up to 20% (London 40%) to help support the purchase of a new build home. The scheme was originally intended to run until 2017, but it has been extended several times and is now scheduled to run until March 2023 (with certain variations, including that it is available only to first-time buyers from April 1, 2021). The improved macroeconomic backdrop from 2013, alongside Government support, enabled housebuilding completions to rise to 214,190 in the year to December 31, 2019, the highest level since 2007. ----- 172,010 of these were built by the private sector, 38,390 by housing associations and only 3,800 by local authorities (compared to 415,460 total completions in 1967, 204,210 of which were built by the private sector). This level of build still fell well short of the Government’s target to build 300,000 homes per year by the mid2020s (as announced in the Autumn Budget 2017). The following chart shows the level of public sector and private sector new housing completions from 1969 to 2020, as compared against the Government’s current target of 300,000 homes per year: In keeping with other industries, the COVID-19 pandemic has presented major challenges for the UK housing market and the construction of new homes. While data for the UK is not yet available, the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government (“MHCLG”) estimates that completions and starts of new homes in England fell 17% and 16% in the year to December 31, 2020, respectively. This reflected the substantial closure of the UK housing market between March and May 2020 (alongside the national lockdown) and the practical effects social distancing had upon the rate of build. Since restrictions were eased following the first national lockdown in May 2020, housing market activity has been strong. Total housing completions in 2020 for England totaled 148,630, a decrease of 17% compared to the year ending December 31, 2019, despite the widespread disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic early in the year. Nationwide and Halifax reported house price increases of 7.3% and 6.0%, respectively, in the year ending December 31, 2020 – the strongest annual growth since 2016, demonstrating a continued momentum in UK house prices. The following chart shows the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on the nationwide house price growth, as well as on the amount of newly agreed sales and completed transactions for the periods indicated: The following graph shows UK nominal and real house price growth from 2000 to the first quarter of 2021, according to Nationwide. Nominal house prices include all UK properties, without taking into account ----- seasonal adjustments. Real house price are adjusted for retail prices, using the Office for National Statistics Retail Price Index (“RPI”) to convert nominal prices to current prices. Source: Savills Residential Property Forecast, March 2021 Mortgage lending has also been resurgent with an average of 95,341 monthly mortgage approvals for house purchases in the seven months up to and including February 2021, the strongest level since 2007. More recent indicators suggest this momentum has continued, with the number of UK residential purchases in March 2021 being 102.3% higher than March 2020 and 32.2% higher than February 2021. Rightmove announced that it had recorded its busiest ever day on April 7, 2021, with 9.3 million visits to its website, and attributed this strength to growing optimism in the UK’s economic outlook (in light of the positive vaccine roll-out), the return of low deposit mortgages and the benefit of the stamp duty holiday extension to the end of September 2021. The extension will see no tax levied on the first £500,000 of property purchases until June 20, 2021, with this nil-rate band reducing to £250,000 until September 30, 2021, after which it will revert to £125,000. The provision of affordable housing remains a priority for the Government, with a pledge to invest approximately £12 billion in the construction of affordable homes (as defined by the NPPF as housing for sale or rent for those whose needs are not met by the market) in England between 2021 and 2026 – the largest investment into affordable housing in over a decade. The 2021-2026 program is expected to support the construction of 180,000 homes over five years from 2021 to 2026 and is expected to unlock an additional £38 billion of public/private investment in affordable housing.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Historically, the strength of the UK housing market and of the housebuilding sector has been linked to that of the UK economy as a whole, which in turn is influenced by both European and global macro-economic conditions. Demand for housing is driven by a combination of factors, such as the rate of economic growth (both nationally and regionally), the rate of population growth and the increasing number of first-time buyers, the average age and life expectancy of the population, the rate of household formation, the availability and affordability of mortgages, consumer confidence (discussed further below) and the unemployment rate. In addition, the outlook in prices remain strong across different region, representing an increasing opportunity for Keepmoat. ----- The following graph illustrates projected estimates of ASP growth across regions from 2021 to 2025: Source: Savills Residential Property Forecast, March 2021 Due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, global GDP is estimated to have fallen 3.5%, with UK GDP declining 9.9%. While current data remains volatile due to the phasing of Government restrictions (UK GDP rose 1.2% in December 2020, fell 2.2% in January 2021, and rose 0.4% in February 2021), the UK economy appears to be recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, in part due to a successful vaccine roll-out. Recent forecasts from the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) estimate GDP growth at 4.0% in 2021 and envisage that the economy will return to its pre-pandemic levels by Q2 2022. Elsewhere, the labor market continues to be distorted by the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (“CJRS”) (with an estimated 4.7 million workers furloughed at the end of February 2021 versus 8.9 million in May 2020), with the ONS estimating the employment rate at 75.1% in February 2021 (1.4% down year-on-year) and the unemployment rate at 4.9% (0.9% higher year-onyear). Despite this, the OBR estimates that the unemployment rate will peak at 6.5% in Q4 2021 as furlough winds down and improve thereafter. Notably, for the period from January 2021 to March 2021, London had the highest level of unemployment at 6.8%, compared to 5.4% in the North East, 5.0% in the North West, 5.7% and 4.9% for the West and East Midland regions respectively, and a low of 3.4% in the South-East. The following graph sets forth the estimated growth in UK GDP and estimated unemployment rate through 2025: Source: Statista, 2021 ----- There have also been early signs of recovery in wage growth since the end of lockdown. In contrast to past periods of economic stress, the housing market has seen renewed momentum since May 2020, with many commentators attributing this to the release of pent-up demand and changing household preferences instigated by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Consumer confidence is an economic indicator that measures the degree of optimism that consumers have regarding the overall state of the economy and their own financial situations, and provides an indication of future developments of households’ consumption and savings. Generally, when consumer confidence is high, this will have a positive effect on demand for housing. The Bank of England is predicting increased consumer confidence with the easing of restrictions on economic activity and households expected to spend around 10% of their additional accumulated savings over the next three years. The GFK Consumer Confidence Index rose to a 13-month high in April 2021, its highest level since the start of the pandemic. Consumer confidence was -8 in August 2021 (-7 in July 2021), which compares to a lockdown low of -34 in April 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Demand for housing is also affected by the ability of prospective buyers to secure financing to buy a home, which is in turn affected by banks’ and other lenders’ willingness and ability to provide mortgages to prospective buyers. UK Finance, a trade association for the UK banking and financial services sector, estimates that UK gross mortgage lending to £233 billion in 2020, representing a 13% decline from the prior year, and forecasts that it will fall to £215 billion in 2021 before recovering to £230 billion by 2022. However, recent mortgage approval data points to a stronger situation, with approvals in the seven months up to and including February 2021 averaging 95,053. This is 41% ahead of the comparative period a year earlier, which was undisturbed by the COVID-19 pandemic. The Bank of England’s Q2 2021 Credit Conditions Survey showed that lenders expected the availability of credit to improve further in the three months ended August 31, 2021, as well as expecting demand to improve and for mortgage spreads to narrow further.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Demand for homes is affected not only by the availability of mortgages, but by the affordability of the mortgage products that are available, relative to earnings. Nationwide estimates that first-time buyers spent an average of 31.7% of mean take-home pay on mortgage payments in Q4 2020. This compares to the average since 1984 of 33.1%, a low of 17.5% in 1996 and a high of 56% in 1989, as demonstrated by the following graph showing UK mortgage rates between 1995 and 2021: (1) Monthly interest rate of UK monetary financial institutions (excluding Central Bank) sterling 75% LTV fixed rate mortgage to households, not seasonally adjusted. This demonstrates that while first-time buyer house price-to-earnings multiples are close to an all-time high (5.3x for Q1 2021), mortgage rates are low in a historic context, reflecting low base rates. The following charts show mortgage payments as a proportion of first-time buyers’ take home pay from 1984 to 2020, Mortgage ----- payment as percentage of mean take home income per region, and rent versus mortgage payments for first-time buyers in England:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We believe the following key factors drive the demand for housing in the UK:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Rent vs. Mortgage payments for FTB in England (£ in thousands)
Subsubsection Text: Demand for housing is also affected by overall land supply levels. Housebuilders have reported a seismic shift in the UK land market since the introduction of the NPPF in 2012 (subsequently revised in 2018), which put forward a notion in favor of sustainable development built upon economic, social, and environmental objectives. This has resulted in planning approvals for residential development in England rising toward 400,000 per annum, which compares to just over 200,000 completions across the entirety of the United Kingdom in 2019 and an average of 164,301 per annum in the five years up to and including 2012. This shift in the supply/demand dynamic has led to much more moderate land prices. Whilst UK house prices are approximately 30% higher than their pre2008 peak, UK greenfield and urban land values are only back to 90% and 80% respectively of their peak 2007 values. This more moderate profile in the land market can also be seen from the disclosed land input costs of the quoted housebuilders.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Rent vs. Mortgage payments for FTB in England (£ in thousands)
Subsubsection Text: Notably, the key geographical drivers behind the rise in the UK house price-to-earnings ratio through recent quarters have been London and the surrounding areas, with an average multiple of 12.7x since 2015 (compared to 5.2x for the North East, and 5.7x for the North West). The more Northern regions typically display better affordability ratios, given their lower house prices. The average UK mortgage rate secured in February 2021 was 1.92% (compared to 1.82% in February 2020), which while up from a low of 1.73% in August 2020, compares to 3.85% in May 2011 (the highest point since the start of 2011).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: With new housing highlighted as a fundamental party value, the Conservative Party reiterated its pledge to increase the number of new homes built per annum, with the goal of delivering at least one million additional homes through this parliamentary cycle. A target of delivering 300,000 homes a year by the mid-2020s provides scope for significant upside from current levels of approximately 200,000, with optimism reinforced by a proposed £10 billion Single Housing Infrastructure Fund (a capital grant program to fund the provision of strategic infrastructure, such as roads, schools and healthcare facilities, needed to support new homes) to help deliver on targets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Government announced in April 19, 2021 a new mortgage guarantee scheme which will increase the availability of 95% loan-to-value mortgage products, enabling more households to access mortgages without the need for prohibitively large deposits. Further, in an attempt to increase the ability of young people to take the first step onto the housing ladder, the Government will seek to encourage a new market in long-term fixed rate mortgages with slashed deposit values, improving entry-potential for first-time buyers across the UK.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The voluntary Right to Buy scheme with housing associations is expected to continue, with the scheme granting eligible housing association tenants the opportunity to purchase their homes at Right to Buy level discounts. This comes following the successful pilot voluntary scheme adopted by five housing associations (L&Q, Riverside, Saffron, Sovereign, and Thames Valley Housing) in 2016, and the subsequently launched Midlands pilot scheme in August 2018. The latter saw 44 housing associations take part and a total of 1,892 home sales or homes in the final stage of the sales process by 30 April 2020. All large housing associations (over 1,000 dwellings) in the Midlands took part, with four guiding principles acting as the basis for the scheme: - Right to Buy level discounts for eligible housing association tenants: eligible housing association tenants have the right to the same level of discounts, funded by the Government, as local authority tenants have under the statutory Right to Buy scheme. - Board control over which homes to sell: housing associations have the final decision over whether or not to sell a property with the Government compensating the housing association should the discount be applied to an alternative housing association property purchased by the same tenant. - Full compensation: housing associations to receive the full market value of the property sold, with the discount value funded by the Government. - Flexible one for one replacement through new supply nationally: for every home sold, a new affordable property would be built in England to increase overall supply. In February 2021, a full evaluation of the scheme was published by the Government, with a subsequent indication they were committed to the evaluation of new pilot areas, with further details to be provided in due course.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Right to Acquire scheme is similar to the Right to Buy scheme, but is available to eligible housing association tenants across England with homes built or acquired after April 1, 1997 who have had a public sector landlord for at least three years. It provides a smaller level of discount compared to the Right to Buy scheme.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: An extension of the Help to Buy scheme from 2021 to 2023 has been confirmed, providing buyers with deposits of at least 5% an interest free equity loan of up to 20% (London 40%) to help support the purchase of a new build home. The scheme additionally incorporates regional maximum property price caps, ranging from ----- £186,100 in the North East to £600,000 in London, denoting the maximum value of a home to which the scheme applies. From April 1, 2021 onwards, the scheme is restricted to first-time buyers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: This scheme enables anyone in England with household income of less than £80,000 outside London and £90,000 inside London to buy a home through shared ownership. Under the new model of this scheme, buyers acquire a stake between 10% (previously 25%, but to be reduced to 10% from 2022) and 75% of the home’s value and pay rent on the remaining share. This scheme is also expected to run until 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The impact of the Coronavirus pandemic put the housebuilding sector largely on hold between March and May 2020, with this followed by a period of reduced activity given the stop-start nature of the easing of lockdown restrictions. In an attempt to both kick-start the housebuilding sector and reinvigorate the wider economy, on July 8, 2020 the Chancellor announced a temporary increase in the amount a purchaser could pay for residential property before Stamp Duty Land Tax (“SDLT”) would apply, from £125,000 to £500,000, for the period July 8, 2020 to March 31, 2021. This holiday was extended until June 30, 2021, from which point the threshold reduced to £250,000 until September 30, 2021, after which it will revert to £125,000.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Right to Buy and Right to Acquire schemes will seek to assist tenants in local communities who wish to establish ownership of their council/housing association homes. Additionally, the Government has also announced £2.1 million in funding to help communities have a greater say in how their local area is developed. The fund will boost neighborhood planning by giving additional support to local authorities in under-represented areas.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Government announced new plans in April 2021, supported by over £150 million in new funding, to lower the required deposit for mortgages in order to make it easier and more affordable for people to build their own homes. The Government estimate the Help to Build scheme could deliver 30,000 to 40,000 new homes per year, with an equity loan provided with a low-level deposit similar to that of the Help to Buy scheme.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Affordable Homes Programme was set up in 2010 to provide grant funding to support the capital costs of developing affordable housing for rent or sale. The first iteration of the program from 2011 to 2015 aimed to fund the creation of 150,000 affordable homes through a combination of new builds and the conversion of existing housing assets. A subsequent program was introduced for 2016 to 2021, in which the Government made £4.7 billion of capital grants available to deliver starts on site for at least 135,000 homes for Help to Buy: Shared Ownership; 10,000 homes for Rent to Buy; and 8,000 homes for supported and older people’s rental accommodation. The provision of affordable housing was reaffirmed as a priority for the Government in the 2021 budget, with a pledge to invest £11.5 billion in the construction of affordable homes in England between 2021 and 2026, providing up to 180,000 new homes across the country. Approximately £7.5 billion of funding will be provided to deliver up to 130,000 homes outside of London, and a further £4 billion to deliver homes in London.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In June 2021, the UK Government launched a new initiative called “First Homes,” which offers firsttime buyers a minimum discount of 30% on the purchase of a new home through developer contributions. The same percentage discount must then be passed on with the sale of the property to future buyers (who must also be first-time buyers), meaning that homes will always be sold at a discount to market value in perpetuity, with the aim of benefitting local communities, local workers and key workers and families. After the discount has been applied, the first sale must be at a price no higher than £250,000 (or £420,000 in Greater London). Changes proposed to the planning system to support this initiative may require that First Homes properties should account for at least 25% of all affordable housing units secured through developer contributions. The Group partnered ----- with Homes England and Bolsover District Council on the first phase of an early delivery project of First Homes in the Bolsover district, East Midlands.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Global support for green considerations and carbon reduction continues to grow, with the Government echoing this in looking to support the creation of new homes with advanced energy saving capabilities in its proposed changes to the building regulations governing the specification of the homes the sector builds. A vision for ‘Homes of the future’ was laid out within the Conservative Party pledges, with an intended incorporation of innovative design and technology noted as methods to address environmental considerations. The proposed Part L and Future Homes standard in the building regulations will reduce the carbon dioxide emissions of running a home, but will be more expensive to build. A primary focus remains to further prioritize brownfield site developments and protect the Green belt through enhanced biodiversity and improvements to poor land quality. The proposed 10% ‘Bio Diversity Net Gain’ element of the Environment Bill could inadvertently increase the cost of developing brownfield land due to it becoming dense, self-seeded vegetation over the decades it has been left vacant. This land is regarded as having a higher bio diversity value, than greenfield land and therefore achieving the proposed net gain is potentially more costly. The following table illustrates a summary of UK government initiatives, and the subsequent chart shows the number of new constructions approved for the periods indicated: -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The introduction of the NPPF in 2012 and Help to Buy in 2013, the 2015 Spending Review and Autumn Statement and the subsequent Housing and Planning Bill in November 2015 all stand as key milestones in a recent historical context to evidence growing governmental support for the housebuilding sector. The December 2019 ----- Conservative Party majority win (the largest governmental majority since 2005) reinforced this, and the Conservative Party reiterated its support for the sector in its 2021 annual budget.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Facilitating approval of new construction Housebuilder and Lender Collaboration
Subsubsection Text: In recognition of the need for low deposit, high loan to value mortgages to support aspiring house buyers become homeowners, the housebuilding sector and lenders are exploring new low-deposit mortgage products, including a product backed by a mortgage indemnity scheme developed by the Home Builders Federation and other market participants that will offer 95% loan to value mortgages for new homes. Upon completion of home purchases offered as part of the scheme, the developer pays a percentage of the purchase price into an insurance policy, which reduces risk for the lender. This scheme is currently being piloted in the North East of the UK but is expected to be rolled out more widely across the UK should the trial prove to be successful.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: One of the key regulatory regimes that UK housebuilders must adhere to are those that concern planning permissions for residential developments. In England and Wales, the majority of spatial planning is regulated by the Town and Country Planning Act 1990. All developments, except for those which are permitted pursuant to permitted development rights, require planning consent by the relevant local planning authority. Planning consent is obtained through the preparation and submission of a planning application, which in some circumstances may include an environmental statement prepared as part of the Environmental Impact Assessment process. The planning application is considered by the local planning authority following consultation with relevant stakeholders, having regard to national and local planning policies, environmental impacts and other material considerations. There are two types of planning consent that can be obtained. The first, known as outline planning consent, is typically sought for the development of greenfield sites or larger sites requiring development in phases. An application for outline planning permission allows for a decision on the general principles of how a site can be developed. Outline planning permission is granted subject to conditions requiring the subsequent approval of one or more “reserved matters.” Reserved matters are those aspects of the development which an application can choose not to submit details of with an outline planning permission. These include aspects such as appearances and layout. The second, known as full planning consent, grants detailed consent for the development. Planning consents are granted subject to various conditions which must be complied with at certain points throughout the delivery of a development. Some planning conditions require certain information to be provided to and approved by the local planning authority prior to certain works being undertaken. In addition, all planning permissions are granted subject to the development commencing within a certain period of time, failure of which results in the lapsing of the planning consent. In the case of most developments, local planning authorities require that housebuilders enter into Section 106 agreements prior to the grant of planning consent in order to make such developments acceptable in planning ----- terms. These agreements govern a developer’s commitments to build affordable housing and infrastructure, in addition to providing other community benefits. Obligations under these agreements could include financial contributions towards local infrastructure (including schools, roads and healthcare facilities) that are needed as a result of increased demand brought about by the development. Additional obligations could include affordable housing contributions, which may take place either through an on-site requirement for the housebuilder to build an agreed amount of affordable housing or payment of a commuted sum. The level of affordable housing contributions is often set within local authority planning policy but can be renegotiated on specific grounds. Section 106 agreements must be entered into by the owner of the land for which the related planning permission relates. As the obligations contained within such agreements run with the land and (subject to any exclusions agreed with the local planning authority), they are enforceable against subsequent owners of the land. In England and Wales, housebuilders may also be required to pay a Community Infrastructure Levy charge typically intended to contribute to the wider infrastructure of an area in which a site is located. Given the complexity and localized nature of the land planning system, the overall process is usually considered risky, time consuming and expensive. Following a consultation process launched in August 2020 which was aimed at reforming the planning system, the Government is expected to bring a new planning bill before the UK Parliament in Autumn 2021. Some of the key areas under consideration are: - consulting local communities from the beginning of the planning process; - harnessing the latest technology through online maps and data in order to ensure the planning system is more accessible; - ensuring local plans are developed and agreed in 30 months – down from the current average of seven years – so that homes may be built more quickly; - overhauling the current planning process with a clearer, rules-based system. Under the current system, approximately one third of planning cases that go to appeal are overturned at appeal; and - replacing the existing systems for funding affordable housing and infrastructure with a new, more predictable, and more transparent levy. In July 2021, the Government introduced its long anticipated Building Safety Bill (which is applicable in England, although some of the changes will also apply to Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland). The Building Safety Bill has not yet made its way through the UK Parliament, and it is anticipated that this will take at least nine months from the introduction of the bill and possibly longer. Thereafter, the changes will come into force incrementally. The Building Safety Bill has been introduced to strengthen the regulatory system for building safety, change industry culture to foster a greater emphasis on safety and accountability, implement rigorous safety standards for construction products, and provide a clearer path to redress for homeowners. The main elements of the Building Safety Bill include: - overhauling the regulatory landscape for the design and construction of high risk residential buildings that are 18 meters or have at least seven stories and two residential units and their subsequent occupation, management and operation; - establishing a building safety regulator and updating existing building safety regulations; - establishing a new framework to provide national oversight of construction products and strengthening the powers of the Office for Product Safety and Standards in this area; - establishing a new homes ombudsman and simplifying the process to log complaints to the Housing Ombudsman Service for social housing tenants; - making financial provisions to support the removal of unsafe cladding, including through a levy on developers seeking permission to develop certain high rise buildings in England; and - strengthening the enforcement action that can be taken in the event of breach including in relation to criminal offences for non-compliance. ----- Impact assessments undertaken by the Government indicate that the reforms will cost the industry more than £1 billion in their first three years. This is not inclusive of the levy referred to above, nor is it inclusive of the proposed new tax for the UK residential property development sector (which also serves to meet cladding remediation costs). The proposed new tax will apply to residential developers’ profits over £25 million and the Government anticipates raising at least £2 billion over a decade. The Government is currently in consultations to determine the structure of the tax scheme ahead of its inclusion in Finance Bill 2021-22. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: (4) Sales mix of open market and Registered Provider sales based on percentage of total homes delivered for the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Registered Provider sales comprises all sales to Registered Providers that are contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section 106 obligations. Open market sales include private sales, elective sales to Registered Providers agreed during the development of a site, Affordable Homes Programme sales and private rental sector sales. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations— _Description of Statement of Comprehensive Income—Revenue.”_ (5) Private sales customer mix based on statistics from a survey of 1,053 private sales customers in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Sustainability is also a key driver of our operations, with a particular focus on community-building and place making. In July 2020, following stakeholder consultation, we published our Sustainability Strategy in which we identified our material issues and aligned our strategy to eight SDGs. Through our Sustainability Strategy, we have committed to minimizing our impact on the environment and biodiversity. In particular, we have announced that we intend to achieve a net zero carbon position by the mid-2040s (having formally committed to Race to Zero) and that we intend to publicly disclose our carbon performance from 2022 onwards. We were active on 94 sites as of July 31, 2021. In addition, as of July 31, 2021, the number of plots within our land pipeline was 24,654, with approximately 81% of our land pipeline, or 19,933 plots, being legally secured (meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract). As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline, or 4,721 plots, were those on which we had been appointed preferred developer (meaning that we had been chosen by the land vendor as the final candidate to progress to contract for the development of the site). Together, these plots are equivalent to a six-year supply of homes, based on our pre-pandemic annual completion levels. As of July 31, 2021, we had a forward order book of approximately £503 million (representing 3,151 plots) with an open market sales rate of 0.77 for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021. As of September 19, 2021, we had reserved, exchanged or legally completed almost all of our planned sales for the financial year ending October 31, 2021. Furthermore, as of September 19, 2021, we had secured approximately 40% of our planned sales for the year ended October 31, 2022, 85% of our planned sales for the three months ended January 31, 2022, and 45% of our planned sales for the three months ended April 30, 2022. As of September 19, 2021, we had an eight-week rolling average rate of 0.93, demonstrating continued strong demand from our customers. Our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021 were £628.5 million and £73.8 million, respectively. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.” Over the same period, we generated Free Cash Flow of £44.1 million (and free cash flow conversion of 59.8%). The resilience of our business model was demonstrated through the COVID-19 pandemic. Working with our partners, we were able to agree a deferral of 89% of committed and uncommitted land spend, without losing any site investment opportunities as a result. We believe our financial results in recent quarters demonstrate the resiliency and strength of our business model. ----- Our focus on partnerships provides us with an attractive financial model, benefitting from typically lower land values, attractive (and often deferred) payment terms, the potential for additional elective deals with Registered Providers (beyond sales in connection with Section 106 affordable housing obligations) and access to grant funding to optimize returns. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the UK’s oldest and most experienced partnership housebuilders, with “5-Star Homebuilder” status awarded in 2021. We are focused on creating sustainable communities in places where people want to live, and we specialize in the delivery of affordable and high quality homes, principally targeted at first-time buyers. Headquartered in Doncaster, England, we operate across England and Scotland through nine operating regions. We are a top ten UK housebuilder, measured by the number of homes sold, including delivering 4,035 homes in our financial year ended October 31, 2019. Unlike traditional housebuilders, our business model is based on partnerships with entities interested in seeing an increase in supply of homes as well as those with demand for our product. These partners are primarily land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) or Registered Providers, which include the traditional not-for-profit and the newer for-profit entities that are registered with the Regulator of Social Housing to provide affordable housing. We engage each of our key stakeholders in residential projects by establishing, aligning and prioritizing their needs and successfully delivering their objectives. We have built our reputation by aligning our approach to our partners’ objectives regarding the sourcing, procurement, planning and delivery of successful, affordable housing developments that create significant social value. We believe that we are the original partnership-focused housebuilder in the United Kingdom, having worked with over 200 partners to date, with many of these relationships enduring for over 20 years. Our partnership model allows us to have a high degree of certainty over our land pipeline, with sufficient land secured for six years of development based on our future development plans and on 2019 home deliveries, while also typically allowing us to defer payment until milestones are met. We are also able to minimize development and planning risks by partnering with land owners through the early stages of a development project. Coupled with the relatively low land costs for the affordable homes that we target, we are able to operate a capitallight business model relative to traditional housebuilders, and generate relatively strong cash conversion and ROCE. In the financial year ended October 31, 2019, the last full financial year prior to the start of the COVID19 pandemic, our ROCE was 32.8%. We focus on developing urban and suburban locations where there is an inherent demand and supply imbalance for new homes. We aim to meet this demand through our five core standard house type ranges. This standardization allows efficiency in procuring materials and construction, increased certainty of cost and timing of delivery, and assists in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and our partners’ preferences. We are continually working with new technologies that underpin and refine our designs. We are committed to deliver a range of affordable housing, predominantly for open market sale, social housing and shared ownership – which provides us with a higher degree of market resilience over the long term due to generally consistent demand from first-time buyers and well-funded Registered Providers. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site), with the remaining approximately 26% of our sales comprising sales to Registered Providers that are contracted at the outset of development of a site, including but not limited to those contracted to satisfy Section 106 obligations. Approximately 87% of our open market sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 were to private sale customers, of which approximately 76% were to first-time buyers (first-time buyers accounted for 76% during the financial year ended October 31, 2019). In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 45% of our total sales, including 67% of sales to first time buyers, involved the use of the Government HTB scheme. We believe that first-time buyers provide more resilient structural demand than the typically discretionary and cyclical home-mover segment. ----- The following charts show our sales mix (by percentage of total homes delivered) and our private sales customer mix for the twelve months ended July 31, 2021:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Strong Fundamentals Underpinning the UK Housing Sector, Supported by a Favorable Government Policy Environment
Subsubsection Text: The supply of housing in the UK market has lagged behind demand and the regions where we operate in particular are characterized by a structural supply-demand imbalance. The UK Government’s position has historically been that everyone should have the opportunity to own an affordable, decent home within a sustainable and mixed community. To this end, support for the housing market and first-time buyers has been a target of government policy over recent years, starting with the introduction of the NPPF in 2012. In its 2021 annual budget, the Government reiterated its pledge to increase the number of new homes built per annum, with the goal of delivering at least one million additional homes through this parliamentary cycle. Overall, the Government has a target to build 300,000 homes per year through the mid-2020s (as announced in the Budget 2017), and we expect there to be continued support for the housebuilding sector as the Government seeks to achieve this target. The following chart shows the number of homes completed by private sector and public sector funding, as compared to the Government target of 300,000 per year. In particular, the first-time buyer market outside of London, our core target market, is aided by a supportive structural and political backdrop promoting both home ownership and affordable housing, including through UK central Government funds, loans, grants and subsidies, which assist in both the viability of schemes and also pace of delivery. As demonstrated by the recently launched “First Homes” program, which offers firsttime buyers a minimum 30% discount on the purchase of a new build home, we expect this segment to continue to be a key focus area for the UK government in the future. This has contributed to a rise in housebuilding completions to 178,310 in England in the year ended December 31, 2019, the highest level since 2007. This is, however, far below the 300,000 per year needed in England as estimated by the UK Government in early 2021 despite the macro-economic uncertainty created by the pandemic. As household formation continues to rise and the pandemic has reinforced buyer preferences for houses over flats, we have experienced a strong recovery in 2021 to date. ----- The demand backdrop for housing remains supportive with the continued increase in UK household formation. The following chart shows the number of homes in the UK since 2011, as of June 29, 2020, with 20212039 data estimates completed by private sector and public sector funding, as compared to the Government target of 300,000 per year. (6) Office for national statistics While it is not currently known whether the HTB scheme will be extended after 2023, what modifications to any extensions may be, or if other government support for the sector may be put in place, we believe the Government will remain focused on supporting those purchasers who form our key customer base. For instance, when the HTB scheme was modified and extended to March 2023, reforms were implemented to restrict the scheme to support only first-time buyers from April 1, 2021 onwards and with regional price caps from £186,100 in the North East to £600,000 in London. As our ASP was £162,000 in the year ended October 31, 2019, we believe this modification will have little to no adverse impact for our business. Our ASP compares favorably for entry price point customers when compared to our listed peers. Further, based on our ability to navigate recent changes to the Scottish equivalent of the HTB scheme, we do not believe that any termination of the HTB scheme would have a material effect on the demand for our homes in England. In Scotland, the “Affordable New Build Scheme” remains available to larger housebuilders (including Keepmoat), though it stopped accepting new applications on February 5, 2021. The suspension of new applications has had no major impact on our performance in the region, which we believe is primarily a result of our target market dynamics, competitive entry price point and strong reputation as a 5-Star Homebuilder.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: We Operate in those areas of the UK Housing Market with the Highest Levels of Affordability and Resilience
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we are strategically positioned in the most attractive segment of the UK housing market, from both a demographic and a geographic perspective. Key attractions of this market segment include resilience in adverse macroeconomic environments, the greatest affordability levels in terms of income/price ratios and one of the strongest growth rates in historical and forecast volumes. This segment is also conducive to strong partnerships with land owners such as Homes England and other local authorities, as well as delivery partners, including Registered Providers, in their role as agents for the implementation of Government housing policies driven by social objectives. As a result, we have achieved consistently strong sales rates in recent years, outperforming more broadly focused housebuilders. From April 2017 to July 2021, Keepmoat has achieved an average open market sales rate per outlet per week of 0.82, which is above the broader housing sector’s average open market sales rate per outlet per week of 0.66. ----- The following charts illustrate the demographic breakdown of our private sales customers, including by purchase type, age, employment type, occupation.

First-time private buyers are a segment that has historically been resilient as purchases are more frequently driven by a “need to buy” rather than the typically discretionary and cyclical home-mover segment. Most first-time buyers also see a financial benefit to purchasing as compared to renting, with average mortgage payments in the UK approximately 18% lower than the cost of renting a private two-bedroom home (based on 2020 average payments). In addition to personal life cycle reasons, this provides a financial incentive to purchase even in economic downturns. First-time buyers accounted for 76% of our sales to private customers in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, while only 50% and 51% of all home purchase loans obtained in the UK in 2020 and 2019, respectively, were for first-time buyers. Further enhancing resiliency, our customers represent a wide range of occupations, reducing exposure to potential slowdowns in any individual occupational sector. Each of these regions is characterized by belowaverage house prices and mortgage payments as a percentage of take home pay for first-time buyers. The average income to mortgage payment ratio for the regions we operate in is in excess of 4.0x, compared to approximately 2.0x to 2.5x for London and the South East or approximately 3.3x for the UK as a whole. Additionally, in each region, our ASP is below the regional average, leaving room for price inflation while remaining at the affordable end of the spectrum.
