We have a well-established presence in North England and are expanding our footprint in the Midlands and Scotland, where these regions are expected to have higher home completion volumes than the UK average in the medium term. Forecasted growth rates for ASP between 2021 to 2025 are 28.0%. in the North West, 28.0% in Yorkshire and the Humber, 23.9% in the East Midlands and 23.9% in the West Midlands, compared to an already strong UK average of 21.5%.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Our Partnership Model Carries Inherently Less Risk than the Traditional Housebuilding Model, with High Barriers to Entry and Partners that are Structurally Aligned
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the UK’s leading dedicated partnership-focused housebuilders with a proven track-record and a strong reputation of delivering large scale, multi-faceted, residential-led regeneration schemes throughout England and Scotland. Unlike traditional housebuilders, we primarily develop in collaboration with partners that have some form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility) in the relevant development. We are a partner of land owners such as Homes England and other Local Authorities, as well as delivery partners, including Registered Providers of affordable housing, strategically catering to structural demand driven by social objectives and Government housing policies. Partnership relationships promote effective and capital light land sourcing and site development (often with deferred payment terms correlated to the pace of site development and unit sales), as well as the ability to unlock development sites often inaccessible to traditional housebuilders. Unlike the traditional model, the partnership model offers an attractive financial profile with lower land acquisition costs, favorable (often deferred) payment terms, cash generative and competitively priced deals with Registered Providers, access to grant funding and accelerated delivery, enabling us to pursue investments with an attractive ROCE. ----- The following chart provides an illustration of the lifecycle of a development and key differences in our model. (2) Keepmoat profile based on a sample of sites. Traditional profile based on management’s experience of the UK housebuilding industry. Over the past 25 years, we have developed strong relationships with many of the largest land partners in the UK, which are predominantly public land owners but also include private land owners, and have built a strong reputation for delivery, quality and place making (i.e., creating thriving, sustainable communities where people genuinely want to live, work and play). Relationships are maintained at multiple organizational levels, which help identify future projects and facilitate successful tender processes. This results in a high volume of repeat business and a strong visibility of the order book. Long-standing partner relationships such as ours are inherently difficult to replicate for new entrants. We believe that the partnership model also has a reduced risk profile, as it is fundamentally based on a structural alignment of objectives among ourselves and our partners, which results in pragmatism and flexibility when required. As demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, working with our partners, we were able to agree a deferral of 80% of committed land spend and 97% of forecast uncommitted land spend, without losing any site investment opportunities as a result.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Operating Model with Best-In-Class Processes and Cost Structure
Subsubsection Text: We have specialized in offering a standardized product range of family homes as the optimal means of building affordable and high quality housing units, while minimizing execution risk and improving predictability of costs as well as improving construction build times. This focus on product standardization is a key differentiating element of our business model and commercial proposition to our partners, contributing to the creation of a strong brand. To facilitate standardization, we typically utilize our five standard house type ranges, catering to the requirements of private sale, sale to Registered Providers and local authorities, future mobility standards and Scottish building standards (where applicable), which assist in establishing optimal site layout mix based on demand and partner’s preferences. Although it varies from year to year, in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88% of our homes were built using standardized housing types. The in-house development process of our portfolio of core standard designs is based on internal feedback for saleability, buildability, customer feedback and land/commercial optimization, and is a key driver of the continued operational improvements across the Group that have resulted in enhanced operating margins. ----- Standardization of house types has enabled us to accurately reflect third party designs (such as heating, roofs, furniture and kitchens) for space and accessibility standards. These standard details allow us to promote best practices for quality, safety and precise material scheduling, optimizing waste as a result. Importantly, standard specifications facilitate forward demand planning, purchase leverage and rebate maximization. It allows contractors to bid aggressively on our projects as they have greater confidence around deliverability on cost and on time. The standardization process has also enhanced the quality of our products which, in turn, has increased customer satisfaction and reduced aftercare costs. The efficiencies across the supply chain and cost control and optimization have strengthened our ability to maintain strong margins and provide a partial defense from cost inflation pressures. This is further enhanced by our disciplined approach through all stages of capital allocation, acquisitions and cost control. Standardization has also enabled us to continue to maintain a low ASP, providing the potential to benefit from sale price increases during inflationary periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Proven Ability to Source Land through a Disciplined Acquisition Process
Subsubsection Text: We have implemented a structured and agile land acquisition process, enabling a continued replenishment of our land pipeline that has contributed to sustained margin improvement over the last few years. As there is a lag between the securing of land and the ultimate delivery of finished product on that land, we may see benefit from this focus on land acquisition being realized over time. We have a controlled and disciplined internal land acquisition approval process, working within defined control gateways each requiring senior executive and/or Capex Committee approval. Our land approval protocol involves three stages. The Pre-Bid Capex proposal establishes the nature, suitability and targeted financial returns (for gross margin and ROCE) of the opportunity. The Capex 1 Proposal includes a review of planning, title and legal reports, site risks/mitigants and required approvals, with continued focus on delivering in line with the threshold financial returns. Finally, the Capex 2 proposal is the region’s final proposal to develop the site (including financial plan) once all legal matters and major approvals are received. We believe this rigorous land sourcing process, together with sales price optimization, build and sales management and the resulting increasing mix of higher quality and better procured sites, may all be contributing factors driving continued margin expansion. For example, for sites under development that were approved between 2017 and 2019 (excluding the North West MCI region), average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval range from approximately 22% to 23% by year, whereas for sites either approved since 2020 or within our secured pipeline and to be approved, average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for each year of approval or for the “to be approved” category, range from approximately 24% to 25% by year or category. This is an increase from the average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins for sites under development that were approved in 2016 and pre-2016, for which average forecasted full-site-life Gross Development Margins are approximately 21% and 18%, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Strong Management Team with Proven Operational Experience
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong management team with a proven track record in UK housebuilding, including expertise in land acquisition, construction, planning, development and partnering with housing associations, local authorities, and Registered Providers. This has been instrumental in helping us to achieve 5-Star Homebuilder status in 2021 with a 92.6% customer satisfaction score. Since the formation of our executive management team in 2018, we have delivered consistent year-onyear revenue growth, Gross Development Margin and EBIT growth (excluding the COVID-impacted financial year ended October 31, 2020). The team has accomplished this primarily through an increase in scale, improved operational efficiency and a disciplined land acquisition process spearheaded by the divisional management team which has extensive knowledge of the selected regions in which we operate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Strong Financial Track Record of Growth and Returns
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong track record of growth and increase in profitability in recent years, resulting from the combination of our geographical expansion process and strong focus on operational improvements and margin expansion. From the financial year ended March 31, 2015 to the financial year ended October 31, 2019, revenue grew by a CAGR of 22% and home completions grew from 2,133 to 4,035 (representing a CAGR of 15%), driven ----- by methodical expansion in established regions and into new regions, including in January 2017 the acquisition of MCI Developments Limited in the North West, as well as benefiting from ASP increases. The KM Group’s Adjusted EBIT increased 47.7% from £41.4 million for the financial year ended March 31, 2018 to £61.1 million in the financial year ended October 31, 2019. Inevitably, the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic had a negative impact in the KM Group’s financial performance in 2020. However, illustrating the strength and resiliency of our business model, we generated revenues of £628.5 million and Adjusted EBITDA of £73.8 million in the twelve months ended July 31, 2021, representing a decrease of 3.3% and an increase of 18.3%, respectively, as compared to the financial year ended October 31, 2019. Concurrently with this growth, we have made significant investments in structure and personnel at both regional and head office levels, creating a national platform optimally crafted to support our future growth in our target geographies. Margins have remained stable over this period, proving our ability and further potential to continue investing and increasing scale.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: High Visibility on Medium Term Revenue Growth, Risk Mitigation Opportunities and Margin Improvement
Subsubsection Text: Our current land pipeline reflects a strong level of land security to deliver on the business plan and continue to drive future growth, providing us with excellent forward visibility. As of July 31, 2021, there were 24,654 plots in our land pipeline, of which approximately 81% were legally secured, meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract. This equates to a land pipeline of six years at pre-pandemic annual volumes. We intend to continue to leverage our strong land pipeline and high near-term land visibility to increase delivery volumes. We currently characterize five of our nine regions (the East Midlands, South Midlands, North West MCI, Scotland and West Midlands regions) as “growth regions,” and we believe these regions have significant potential to deliver additional plots within the existing regional management structure as they mature. We will target both continued growth in volume and margin improvement, as the business delivers on regional management team investments that have been made in these growth regions and benefits from the continued realization of land acquired through improved sourcing processes. Approximately 86% of our land pipeline has agreed deferred land payment terms with our partners. Of our land pipeline plots that have been legally secured as of July 31, 2021, approximately 37% represents projects that were not legally completed and there remained conditionality (e.g., planning and groundworks survey) prior to finalizing the contract. There are further risk mitigation opportunities available to us within our partnership model such as land payments made by Registered Provider partners, overage agreements, pace and tenure delivery flexibility and multi-tenure development. The benefits of these risk mitigation features have been demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, with our strong relationships with partners providing flexibility to recalibrate land and delivery obligations during this challenging period. Altogether, we were able to either defer or pay in alignment with plot delivery £58.4 million of £65.5 million total forecast land payments (89%) from April 1, 2020 to August 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Continued Development of Our Large and Strong Land Pipeline
Subsubsection Text: In addition to building out our strong land pipeline of over 24,000 plots, we intend to continue to pursue new land opportunities to maintain the secured land pipeline, particularly increasing the amount of higher quality, better procured sites (reflecting our enhanced requirements and processes prior to approval for an opportunity being granted). We expect to continue to have a structured, disciplined and agile approach to land acquisitions to facilitate securing suitable land opportunities across all of our regions, who each have dedicated land acquisition teams focused on high quality land opportunities within each region’s geographical area of operation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We intend to build on our long-standing relationships with key stakeholders such as Registered Providers, Local Authorities, and Government agencies, such as Homes England. These relationships have been nurtured ----- over two decades and are held throughout our organizational structure and that of our partners, from executives to regional management and staff. We have a proven track record for delivery, quality and placemaking resulting in winning repeat business. Going forward, we will continue to align objectives with key partners in areas such as climate and biodiversity emergency targets, in addition to the growing need for affordable homes. We will also seek to develop new relationships through our new business teams.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Continue to Focus on Delivering Best Services while Maintaining Strong ESG Benefits and H&S Standards at our Sites
Subsubsection Text: Customer satisfaction is at the heart of our business and we strive to deliver high-quality homes and customer service, reflected by our 5-star customer status. We intend to continue to focus on ensuring that our customers are supported throughout their house buying journey, meeting their expectations, and providing them with a high-quality new home. Sustainability is core to the partnership business model and we are committed to prioritizing ESG initiatives. Key stakeholders are aligned in their focus with approximately 74% of Local Authorities in the UK declaring a climate and biodiversity change emergency, with regeneration areas often more vulnerable to climate and environmental impacts. We are working with Wildscapes, which is a wildlife trust consultancy, to develop methodologies to support the delivery of a net gain in biodiversity for future developments. We are responsible for placemaking and regeneration which in turn helps create direct and indirect employment opportunities within low-income communities. We are focused on providing affordable, low carbon homes to contribute to delivering on our and our partners’ objectives of improving the environmental sustainability of the UK’s homes. We have committed to a number of near term ESG targets, including: introducing science-based carbon targets aligned to limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius along with carbon performance metrics (currently anticipated to be set in late 2021); setting our decarbonisation roadmap within 12 months from July 2021, with the aim of achieving a net zero carbon position by the mid-2040s; mitigating supply chain risks and supporting our supply chain to become more sustainable; and updating our sustainability structure, providing greater oversight and focus on sustainability with the function reporting directly to the CEO and receiving greater focus from the Board. Additionally, we have well-developed and structured H&S policies, certified to ISO 45001:2018, and training programs, as reflected in our health and safety track record. We have clear policies, best practice guides and robust standards and operate a number of forward looking and backward looking metrics. We continuously seek to improve our H&S performance and approach, focusing on risk throughout all phases of a development. Our strategic objectives are centered around (i) keeping people safe and healthy every day; (ii) protecting and enhancing the environment; and (iii) being assured and informed. Each of the these strategic objectives contain a number of initiatives focused on achieving the objectives and cover, amongst other matters, active and visible leadership; managing risk effectively and proportionately; accountability, behavior and culture; capability; contemporary management systems; and key performance indicators. As initiatives are implemented, they are reviewed for effectiveness by our executive EHS committee and monitored.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our strategy is to maintain and strengthen our position as one of the leading partnerships-focused housebuilders in the UK, while delivering enhanced margins and returns from our maturing regional platform. To achieve this goal, we are focused on the following key strategic priorities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our origins as a partnership focused homebuilder date back to 1931, when we were founded as Bromell & Ogden to work with local authorities in South Yorkshire to build and maintain essential amenities. Since then, we have grown organically and through acquisitions. During the 2008 financial crisis, we came under the ownership of the Lloyds Banking Group, which was then our financial lender. The Lloyds Banking Group exited in 2014, with TDR Capital LLP (“TDR”) and Sun Capital Partners (“Sun”) acquiring controlling interests. Under TDR’s and Sun’s control, we introduced a new management team focused on growing our business, expanding from four regions in 2014 to nine regions as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Our organic growth was enhanced in January 2017 by the acquisition of MCI a developer of social housing projects for local authorities and other Registered Providers, which strengthened our capacity, particularly in the North West of England. Following the acquisition of MCI, we further streamlined our operations, selling our regeneration business to ENGIE for £330 million. With our renewed focus on homebuilding, and the ----- completion of a successful internal restructuring exercise to streamline our regional operations, we obtained 5star Homebuilder status in 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We operate exclusively in the UK, with nine regional teams organized into two divisions: (a) the North Division, comprising Scotland, North West, North West MCI, North East and West Yorkshire; and (b) the South Division, comprising East Yorkshire, East Midlands, West Midlands and South Midlands. A Divisional Chairman is responsible for each of the two divisions, supported by a Divisional Finance Director in each division. Our current operational structure was adopted in 2020, following an internal reorganization aimed at optimizing our regional office locations versus our target geographies. We believe that our current divisional structure provides an appropriate span of control for the divisional management team, allowing the right level of oversight for each region to ensure that performance is carefully monitored while maintaining alignment of our overall strategy and growth plans. The following map shows the regions in which we operate and the locations of our regional offices as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, as well as the blended ASP of each region for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. We also have a satellite office located in Bristol, which is part of the West Midlands region. (1) Source: Savills UK Residential Property Forecast (March 2021). Yorkshire growth assumed to be the same across Yorkshire West and Yorkshire East. (2) Build outlets represent sites under development and are calculated based on the average monthly number of build outlets for the six months ended April 30, 2021. (3) Represents blended ASP for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. Each of the regions has its own management board, which typically includes a regional managing director who supervises a team of regional directors, each of whom has their own area of expertise, such as commercial, construction, customer care, finance, land and partnership, sales and technical. The regions are empowered to deliver the Group’s overarching operational excellence strategy, applying the Group’s policies and systems to ----- local markets and circumstances. The regions have a high degree of autonomy, with clear reporting channels to central management and the ability to share central infrastructure support functions. We believe that this structure and approach means that we are well positioned for future growth in the right locations. However, we intend that our regions and their boundaries will remain flexible in the future to allow for growth and expansion into new areas where there is a compelling commercial rationale, and to enable all offices to remain at an optimum size for effective management.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our partnership model is central to our approach to development and sets us apart from our competitors. Our partnership model presents the following benefits: - reduced competition for large scale land opportunities; - resilient demand for affordable homes; - capital light approach delivering strong ROCE; and - repeat business through track record and reputation. Unlike traditional housebuilders, we primarily develop in collaboration with partners that have some form of long-term continuing interest (either through ownership or social responsibility) in the relevant development, which are primarily land owners (such as Homes England, Local Authorities and private land owners) and Registered Providers of social housing. We assist our partners in achieving their key goals of regenerating sites that achieve positive social outcomes through the provision of high-quality, affordable housing. Our focus on this segment of the market provides us with significant expertise in the management of regeneration projects, which is a key differentiator between us and most traditional housebuilders. We believe that this model facilitates efficient, effective and capital light land sourcing and site development, while also enhancing returns and mitigating market and development risks. The following chart provides a comparison of certain key differences between our partnership model and the traditional housebuilding method: (1) Traditional housebuilders includes Barratt Developments plc, Bellway plc, The Berkeley Group Holdings plc, Crest Nicholson Holdings plc, Persimmon plc, Redrow plc, Taylor Wimpey plc, Vistry Group plc. ----- (2) Land cost is calculated as land cost as a percentage of ASP. (3) Asset turn calculated as Group Revenue divided by average opening and closing tangible net operating asset value. (4) Targets are provided for illustrative purposes only. This illustration does not purport to reflect the current returns on any particular site or for the Group as a whole or the potential returns that could be achieved on any particular site or the Group as a whole. These are medium term targets only and not a profit forecast. There can be no assurance that these targets can or will be met and it should not be seen as an indication of the Group’s expected or actual results or returns. Some of our partner agreements facilitate the drawdown of land under phased viability assessments. These forms of agreements accounted for approximately 19% of our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021, and see large development opportunities broken down into phases, with the land for each phase being appraised and valued at the time that we are ready to develop it. Payment terms are also agreed and drawn down once we are ready to develop that phase, and are therefore based on the prevailing market conditions at the time. This allows us to assess the performance of a prior phase before we commit and agree to payment terms and a land valuation for the following phase. The characteristics of phased viability schemes help to reduce the working capital requirements of each project, limit our market and planning risk (including exposure to unexpected land cost depreciation) and allow us to mitigate any exposure to challenging partner specifications or cost inflation related to construction and materials. For our other partner agreements, land is purchased from our partners as a single site, with the land value and payment terms (often deferred) agreed at the completion of the deal. We complement this approach with a build timescale that matches our sales patterns. Below is an illustrative comparison of the cash profile of our partnership model through the life of a site, compared with that of traditional housebuilding companies: As of July 31, 2021, our land pipeline comprised 24,654 plots equating to six years of land supply at prepandemic volumes. The composition of the land pipeline is as follows: - 19% is that which we categorize as “preferred developer” status, where we have been chosen by the land vendor as the final candidate to progress to contract for the development of the site. - 30% is secured with a conditional contract, often subject to planning approval and ground condition resolution. Consolidating these first two categories, 49% of the pipeline is made up of sites on which we have some conditionality prior to finalizing the contract. - The residual 51% is land on which we have legally completed the purchase or securing of the site. Our legally secured plots have certain features which mitigate certain risks associated with developing the plots. These features include (i) deferred payment terms, which are often correlated to the pace of delivery; (ii) land payments that are made by Registered Provider partners; (iii) low base land costs through negotiation and the inclusion of an overage share; (iv) pace and tenure delivery flexibility, which is particularly significant during periods of market slowdown; and (v) opportunities for multi-tenure delivery. ----- _Land Creditor Commitments_ Our partnership model seeks to enhance returns and mitigate risk by reducing upfront investment in the land through deferred payment terms, payments on a per-plot basis, payments triggered by cumulative plot sales or similar development milestones (that may or may not include specified backstop dates) and deferred land tranche payments. As of July 31, 2021, 86% of our land pipeline was purchased with land payments to be made on deferred terms. We believe that our land creditor profile provides us with an element of risk mitigation, as the majority of our payments are linked to development delivery milestones rather than needing to be made up front. Our land creditor commitments are unwound as the relevant payments for these deferred land costs fall due and are made from period to period. The following chart shows the amount of land creditor commitments as of July 31, 2021, that we expect to unwind during each of the periods indicated: In addition, some of our arrangements with development partners include overage mechanisms, whereby we may make additional payments to our development partner following completion of the land sale contingent upon exceeding agreed financial thresholds, with payments often deferred to the end of the development of the site or of a significant phase of the site. Together, these deferred payment obligations and overage obligations comprise our land creditor commitments. We believe that our land creditor profile, which is inherent to our partnership model, provides us with an element of risk mitigation as the majority of our payments are linked to development delivery milestones rather than needing to be made up front. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and _Results of Operations—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Contractual Obligations and Commercial Commitments.”_ The following table shows the breakdown of our land creditor commitments, by contract terms, as of July 31, 2021: #### Total Contract Terms (in millions of £) Fixed Date Liabilities .........................................................................  41.7 Overage (Determined)........................................................................  8.6 Sub Total ............................................................................................  50.3 Milestone Payments – with Backstop ................................................  70.7 Milestone Payments – without Backstop ...........................................  28.4 Overage (Not yet determined) ............................................................  60.1 Other ..................................................................................................  8.4 Sub Total ............................................................................................  167.6 Total .................................................................................................. 217.9 As of July 31, 2021, the majority of our land creditor commitments were to Homes England (43%) and ----- Local Authorities (34%), with the remainder to other partners (13%) and private vendors (11%). The following table illustrates our land creditor breakdown by partner type:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We leverage our long-term partner relationships to both access target sites and proactively identify delivery partners for development opportunities. As of July 31, 2021, 79% of the plots in our land pipeline were being developed under the partnership model. Our partners include public and private sector land owners as well as Registered Providers. In particular, we benefit from strong, long-standing relationships with public bodies (including Homes England, Local Authorities and charitable organizations, and Registered Providers) and private land owners. These relationships have been built using our successful track-record of delivering projects, our reputation for aligning our approach with our partners’ objectives, our established national scale and our deep understanding of the motivations beyond financial returns that are important to our partners (including social value, sustainability, accelerated delivery and design quality). We have established a track record of doing repeat business with a growing number of partners. Our partners select housebuilders that can help them deliver their housing, economic, social and environmental goals. Choosing a developer who can (a) repurpose brownfield land into well-designed schemes of affordable, high-quality homes, (b) regenerate neglected, derelict areas into thriving mixed tenure communities that are socially and economically inclusive, and (c) deliver this in a way that enhances the public realm and biodiversity and reduces carbon outputs which is at the forefront of partners’ objectives. In order to successfully operate our partnership model, it is imperative that we understand our partners’ goals and maintain and promote strong relationships and a strong reputation for delivery. Our reputation and understanding of these features contributes to our strong forward pipeline of projects and our competitive advantage. We believe that this understanding, alongside our extensive experience with the public procurement process and proven regeneration expertise, provides us with a significant competitive advantage. Furthermore, our partnership oriented focus allows us to remain closely aligned with Government housing policy and our close work with various levels of government allows us to participate in a wide range of pilot projects and government consultation initiatives. Working with these partners provides us with the potential to access grant funding and investment support (particularly from Homes England and Local Authority partners) to facilitate the development of land that would otherwise be unviable to develop. As a result of the structured and lengthened timelines that we operate under while working with our partners, we are able to carry out extensive due diligence and thorough evaluations of the technical and economic feasibility of a project development before committing to a land value, which in turn serves as an important risk mitigation tool. Conversely, in traditional development and in speculative transactions, the due diligence and evaluation of a site is often undertaken in a compressed timeframe so that the site can be acquired before the vendor has the opportunity to sell the site to another prospective purchaser. Registered Providers are experts in delivering multi-tenure housing, which may include social rent, affordable rent, market rent and shared ownership homes in a single development. We believe that a multi-tenure housing offer is essential in order to regenerate and deliver truly sustainable communities and this acts as a driving factor as to why we work with delivery partners including Registered Providers. In addition, creating multi-tenure communities allows us to diversify our revenue streams among various demographics and through shared ownership, outright sale and private rented homes. ----- Our largest delivery partner is Homes England, the non-departmental public body that provides funding and land to the housing sector to deliver the Government’s housing policies. Similarly, we are one of the largest strategic delivery partners of Homes England. Our relationship with Homes England (and its predecessors) extends over two decades and across all of its operating regions. Our relationship with Homes England has included support in matters related to the sourcing of land, infrastructure funding, the accessing of grants to assist in developing otherwise unviable sites, funding affordable housing programs and participation in the Help to Buy scheme. We have also participated in piloting new Government initiatives and providing input on policy consultations. We are a member of Homes England’s current DPP (“DPP3”), which was set up to facilitate public sector bodies bringing public land to the market. We have been a member of all of Homes England’s DPPs to date and are one of the most active developers on DPP3. Having been a member of each of the DPPs, we have extensive knowledge and understanding of the bid process, assessment criteria and delivery requirements, which in turn provides us with a significant competitive advantage when bidding on sites offered by Homes England. As of July 31, 2021, we had secured approximately 9,223 homes, across 38 sites through the successive DPPs. In June 2021 we applied to be part of Homes England’s new “dynamic purchasing system” and received confirmation in early September 2021 that our application had been successful. This system was designed to modernize the bidding process through the use of a digital platform, simplifying the process for housebuilders to join the list of preferred developers and bid for land, and is due to be used for land procurement from Autumn 2021 onwards. We are also a registered investment partner of Homes England, which gives us the ability to apply for affordable housing grants alongside Registered Providers. Homes England also provides development finance, long-term infrastructure funding and grant funding to both the housing sector and Local Authority partners to facilitate housing outputs. Since 2009, we have directly and indirectly benefitted from approximately £450 million of funding initiatives from Homes England to facilitate the delivery of new development sites and homes. The following table illustrates the key details of our top ten partners as of July 31, 2021:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the UK’s largest partnership-focused housebuilders, working with over 200 partners to date including Homes England, Local Authorities and Registered Providers, as well as private partners, with strong expertise in regeneration projects to develop affordably priced housing and positive social outcomes. Approximately 79% of the plots in our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021 were being developed under the partnership model. The remainder of our homes are planned to be developed under speculative land deals whereby we purchase land to then develop sites on our own. We have a presence across much of the UK (excluding the greater London area, Wales, southern home counties and directly west and north west of London) and were one of the top-ten UK housebuilders from 2018 to 2020 (measured by the number of homes sold), delivering a total of 3,988 homes in the twelve months ended October 31, 2018, 4,035 homes in the financial year ended October 31, 2019, 2,460 homes in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 (reflecting the impact of COVID-19 during the second half of the financial year ended October 31, 2020) and 3,652 homes in the twelve months ended July 31, 2021. We focus on building homes with standardized designs, which in turn contributes to design and building efficiencies and quality control. Our designs are also relatively straightforward to build and sell, as they do not involve high rise buildings, complex construction methods or cladding. Our homes typically have two to four bedrooms, with 25% of our plots as of October 31, 2020 consisting of two bedroom homes, 59% consisting of three bedroom homes and 13% consisting of four bedroom homes. Of those private homes which achieved legal completion in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 57% were semi-detached houses, 15% were detached houses, 11% were end of terrace houses, 10% were mid-terrace houses and 7% were apartments. The following chart illustrates our housing portfolio and the ASP for each type of home for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 based on private legal completions in that period: Our homes are primarily aimed at first-time buyers and social landlords, with an average selling price of £161,000 for the financial year ended October 31, 2019, £165,000 for the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and £174,000 for the nine months ended July 31, 2021. Our customers are primarily private purchasers and Registered Providers. Open-market sales (including elective sales to Registered Providers agreed during the development of the sites) represented 75% of the total plots that we sold in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 (with an average selling price of £175,000 over the same period). The remaining 25% were sold to Registered Providers as part of the Section 106 affordable housing obligations in connection with the planning consent for the sites, or otherwise agreed with Registered Providers at the outset of development. Registered Providers are the main providers of new homes in the UK social housing sector and are part-funded by the Government. We have a proven track record of revitalizing communities through the delivery of high-quality homes in well-designed and well-connected neighborhoods and at prices that customers can afford. Over the past 25 years we have successfully delivered new homes in some of UK’s most challenging housing markets, demonstrating our commitment to delivery even in the most demanding market conditions. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 71% of our legal completions were situated in areas falling within the most deprived 30% of the UK, based on the Indices of Multiple Deprivation. ----- Brownfield sites represented 73% of our legal completions in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Brownfield land is typically characterized by high population density, proven demand and a shortage of housing supply, and is often equipped with infrastructure (public transport, schools and shops). Local authorities have increasingly focused on the regeneration of brownfield land, which is where we have a significant portion of our developments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Top Ten Land Owner Partners in Land Pipeline Duration of Plots in land** **relationship** **Total Homes** **Land pipeline No.** **Partner** **pipeline** **(years)** **Delivered** **(%)

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our work with Registered Providers can be divided into three distinct categories: - _Registered Provider sales required through Section 106 obligations (categorized as Registered _Provider sales): Local planning policies often specify the proportion of homes on new_ residential developments that must be provided as social housing through a Registered Provider. This obligation is often a condition to planning consent for a particular site, and is set out in each case through a Section 106 agreement. Social housing that must be delivered through a Section 106 agreement is ineligible for Affordable Homes Programme funding and, as a result, Registered Providers generally purchases these homes at a significant discount to their open market value. This discount is factored into our land appraisal at the outset of the development. Registered providers typically pay for these homes incrementally as the site is developed. ----- - _Registered Provider sales, in addition to Section 106 obligations, agreed at the outset of _development of a site (categorized as Registered Provider sales): These sales represent_ agreements (agreed at the outset of development) to sell all or a proportion of the homes on a site to a Registered Provider as part of our strategy for purchasing and developing a site, in addition to any Section 106 obligations. As these sales are in addition to any social housing obligations under Section 106 agreements, they are eligible for Affordable Housing Programme funding, which helps generate attractive commercial offers from the Registered Provider. Registered providers typically pay for these homes incrementally as the site is developed. - _Elective Registered Provider sales agreed during the development of a site (categorized as open _market sales): These are sales agreed with Registered Providers after the development of a site_ has already commenced. Had each such sale not been made, we would otherwise have sold the home to a private buyer as part of our overall open market selling activity for the site. The decision to agree this form of sale is based on the specific economics of each potential Registered Provider elective sale, as benchmarked against other open market sale opportunities. These sales are particularly useful in periods where the residential housing market has slowed, or where a site is less attractive on the open market than otherwise predicted. As these elective sales are in addition to any Section 106 obligations, the Registered Provider is able to access Affordable Homes Programme funding, which helps generate attractive commercial offers. Registered Providers typically pay for these units through a deposit with the balance paid upon completion. Our work with Registered Providers provides us with a number of benefits, including: - a capital efficient work stream, as Registered Providers often pay incrementally and in advance of their homes being built (often with a significant upfront deposit), which thereby strengthens each project’s ROCE; - the multi-tenure housing (including shared ownership homes) that we offer to Registered Providers serves as a natural complement to our private sales; - Registered Providers are well funded by the Government and have delivery commitments to fulfil in a defined period of time; and - in addition to our developments with Registered Providers pursuant to Section 106 obligations or pursuant to build agreements at the outset of a site development, we have found that Registered Providers’ strong appetite for homes generally provide us with an opportunity to make additional elective sales during the period of development, on commercial terms that are in line with a home’s full open market value. The benefits of our partnership model and our work with Registered Provides have been demonstrated during the COVID-19 pandemic, with our strong relationships with partners providing flexibility to recalibrate land and delivery obligations during this challenging period. Altogether, we were able to either defer or pay in alignment with plot delivery £58.4 million of £65.5 million total forecast land payments (89%) from April 1, 2020 to August 31, 2020. The following chart further describes our ability to defer or pay in alignment with plot delivery during the COVID-19 pandemic: -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Some of our current projects being undertaken through our partnership model include: - _Charlestown, Salford:_ Charlestown is a brownfield development project that we have undertaken together with Salford City Council. The development, which was launched in October 2016, is a 15 hectare development of 425 homes, located in a deprived community in Salford. The development will include two hectares of green space, amounting to 13% of the total area of the development. 85 homes at the site, equating to 20% of the total homes developed, will be affordable homes. The project is expected to complete in June 2024. Environmental benefits at the site include the creation of a Sand Martin nesting colony on the riverbank and 99% of waste being diverted from the landfill. The sites environmental benefits have received notable recognition, having been shortlisted for the BIG Biodiversity Award for NEET (not in education, employment or training) horticultural project. - _Primrose Lodge, Goscote: Primrose Lodge is a brownfield development project that we have undertaken together with Walsall Housing Group (selected through its DPP). The development, which was launched in November 2019, is a 11.9 hectare development of 407 homes, located in a deprived community in Goscote, Walsall, on the site of a former interwar housing estate. 126 homes at the site, equating to 31% of the site’s total homes, will be affordable homes. The project is expected to complete in May 2026. Environmental benefits at the site include: (i) no net loss of biodiversity through native species planning in woodlands and public open spaces; (ii) sustainable drainage ponds providing amphibian habitats and local species nesting boxes and habitation; (iii) the inclusion of an electric vehicle charging point in all homes; (iv) sustainable drainage designed for a one in one hundred year flood plus 40% climate change adaptation; and (v) 99% of waste being diverted from the landfill. Social benefits include a commitment to providing work placements, school support, construction college support and apprenticeships, with 44 jobs having already been created to date. - _Waterside, Leicester: Waterside is a brownfield development project that we have undertaken together with Leicester City Council, and which represents our first major scheme in the city. The development, which was launched in November 2019, is a 6.95 hectare development of 288 homes, located in a deprived community near Leicester city center on a site formerly occupied by an industrial estate and cement batching plant. The site will include a 79 bedroom extra care facility. The project is expected to complete in April 2026. Environmental benefits at the site include: (i) a low carbon homes specification that generates 5% lower emissions when compared to building regulations; (ii) a design to achieve zero net loss of biodiversity; (iii) sustainable drainage to prevent localized flooding in a high flood risk area; and (iv) 99% of waste being diverted from the landfill. Social benefits include (i) the creation of 88 work placements to date along with nineteen full-time jobs that will continue to exist after development has completed; (ii) a commitment to create three apprenticeships; and (iii) the creation of a “World of Work” program that will be delivered to construction students at Leicester College. - _Seacroft Hospital, Leeds: Seacroft Hospital is a brownfield development project that we have undertaken together with Homes England. The development, which was launched in December 2016, is an 18.7 hectare development of 503 homes, located in a deprived community near Leeds (a community which is ranked in the bottom twentieth percentile in the UK index of multiple deprivation), on a former hospital site. The site will include 15% affordable homes, with 15% built to lifetime homes standards. The project is expected to be complete in October 2022. Environmental benefits at the site include: (i) a low carbon homes specification that has 20% lower emissions and 10% lower energy requirements when compared to building regulations; (ii) 2.7 hectares of public open space, with ecologically sensitive features including species habitats and 277 trees; (iii) the inclusion of an electric vehicle charging point in all homes with off-road parking; and (iv) 98% of waste being diverted from the landfill. Social benefits include the development of active travel routes linking to the Bradford Leeds Cycle Superhighway and links to the Primrose Valley park. The project was a finalist for the Housebuilder Awards 2020 – Best Community Initiative and Best Training or Recruitment Initiative. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Although joint ventures are not one of our key areas of focus, in certain cases our partners require that we set up joint ventures to facilitate delivery of specific schemes. These requirements are most common when working with Local Authorities on large-scale projects that involve multi-year, multi-phase development and land draw-downs. These joint venture opportunities generally allow us to obtain exclusivity on land within certain areas, limiting competition and boosting land security over an extended period of time. We currently have three active joint ventures: - _Durham Villages Regeneration Limited (“Durham Regeneration”): Durham Regeneration is a 50/50 joint venture that we entered into with Durham Council in 2003. It is our longest standing joint venture. The original purpose of Durham Regeneration was to regenerate the former coal mining villages and towns around Durham City. Durham Regeneration now operates across the county. Discussions are ongoing with Durham County Council regarding potential future sites. - _Sheffield Housing Company (“Sheffield Housing”): Sheffield Housing was incorporated in 2011 and is 50% owned by Sheffield City Council, 45% owned by us and 5% owned by Great Places, a Registered Provider. We typically provide the build and sales capability to Sheffield Housing under a contract for a set return, which serves as a low-risk source of revenue. We are also then eligible for dividends as a shareholder of Sheffield Housing, thereby also benefitting from any upside potential in the developments. - _New Tyne West Development Company LLP (“New Tyne”): New Tyne was incorporated in 2011 and is 50% owned by Newcastle City Council and 50% owned by BK Scotswood LLP. BK Scotswood LLP is in turn a joint venture subsidiary that was originally 50% owned by us, and 50% owned by Barratt Developments, which is a company engaged in residential property development. In December 2020, we acquired Barratt Developments’ 50% interest in BK Scotswood LLP. The area of the development is expected to create one very large neighborhood, covering approximately 65 hectares. In addition to being an indirect joint-venture partner, we are also a delivery contractor for New Tyne.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of July 31, 2021, the number of plots within our land pipeline was 24,654, with approximately 81% of our land pipeline, or 19,933 plots, being legally secured (meaning that we have a contractual right to develop or a conditionally exchanged contract). As of July 31, 2021, approximately 19% of our land pipeline, or 4,721 plots, were those on which we had been appointed preferred developer (meaning that we had been chosen by the land vendor as the final candidate to progress to contract for the development of the site). Together, these plots are equivalent to a six-year supply of homes, based on our pre-pandemic annual completion levels. As of August 20, 2021, we had secured 101%, 105%, 104%, 82% and 56% for the financial year ended October 31, 2021 and the following four subsequent financial years (expressed as a percentage of our planned future completions for the current year), respectively. Approximately 79% of the plots in our current land pipeline are being developed on a partnership basis (including sites that have not yet been secured, but will be developed on a partnership basis if secured). Furthermore, 86% of our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021 was purchased with land payments to be made on deferred terms. ----- The following table sets out the composition of our land pipeline as of July 31, 2021:
