Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _Sourcing Development Opportunities_ Land sourcing opportunities and strategy are a crucial aspect of our business and receive a significant amount of attention from our senior management. We source land for our business from both public and private sector partners. We believe that by understanding bid briefs and being agile and resourceful in delivering on the land vendors’ requirements, we make ourselves an attractive partner. Our largest source of land (currently representing approximately 79% of our land) are our partnerships with the public sector, typically Homes England and Local Authorities, with whom we have formed strong relationships and strategic private partners, with whom we achieve a high proportion of repeat business. We also source land from the private sector through our regional contacts with individual land owners and land agents (which currently represent approximately 21% of our land). With both public and private partners, our participation in a partnership development may be structured in several ways, each of which is intended to provide a blend of risk and return appropriate to the land being acquired. Certain arrangements may require us to acquire the land being developed (sometimes in phases). Other arrangements may grant us with development rights while the original land owner retains ownership of the site and ultimately transfers completed units directly to the home purchaser. In some instances, we may also enter into joint ventures with partners to secure exclusive development rights over large scale land holdings, with our longest running joint venture lasting over 25 years. The timelines from identification of a site to beginning its development can vary widely from as little as 12 months to two years or longer, and then the development phase can last for a number of years depending on size and complexity of the project. Public-sector land is usually brought to market through a competitive tender process, determined by the “Find a Tender Service” (“FTS”) (previously the Official Journal of the European Union (“OJEU”)) process, which governs how the public sector disposes of its land assets and procures development services. In the case of Homes England, disposals are currently effected through the DPP (currently DPP3), of which we are a member. Historically, being a member of DPP3 has reduced the number of competitors that we have competed with to secure large scale public land opportunities, providing us with access to development sites typically unavailable to housebuilders who are not members of DPP3. However, Homes England launched its successor to the DPP, the DPDPS, on September 1, 2021, which has been designed to modernize the bidding process through the use of a digital platform which encourages new entrants to the market, and thereby simplifies the process for housebuilders to join the list of preferred developers and bid for land. We have submitted an application to be a member of the DPDPS and have received confirmation of our membership on the panel. With this new system, ----- housebuilders will still have to ‘qualify’ to be able to join the list of preferred developers, but they will be able to apply to join at any time, rather than only upon renewal of the delivery partner panel once every four years, as is currently the case. The public procurement process is a formal, complex and sometimes lengthy process, which, along with the regeneration aspect of most public-sector land and the pricing dynamics of the affordable housing market, deters some larger housebuilders from competing for these opportunities. However, our significant experience with developments of this type and deep knowledge of the financial dynamics and the requirements of these public sector partners allows us to navigate this process efficiently and effectively. We often begin preparations for a scheme bid well before we receive formal notification of a project. Land purchased through the public sector will generally involve multiple phases over an extended timeframe. The typical process and indicative timeframe is as follows:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The average site size for our secured and preferred bidder partnerships sites is 186 plots as of July 31, 2021. The quality of our land pipeline also benefits from our knowledge of, and relationships with, local markets. These factors allow us to successfully work with local planning authorities, and our planning risk is significantly mitigated by the fact that we often partner with partners such as Homes England and Local Authorities, who support us throughout the planning application process. The overall timetable associated with the planning process generally takes approximately 18 months, with the planning committee meeting taking place approximately 16 months after a preferred bidder has been selected. Historically, we have had a significantly higher success rate than traditional housebuilders in obtaining planning consents. As of July 31, 2021, 79% of our land pipeline had detailed or outlined planning permission.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Month 0 Release of site for sale / notification of project Month 2 Submission of an expression of interest Month 3 Shortlisting by vendor / invitation to tender sent Month 6 Submission of bid document Month 8 Formal presentation / bid interviews Month 10 Clarification sessions Month 9-12 Appointment of preferred developer partner Month 17-18 Entry into binding contract Month 24 Planning consent received Month 24-28 Finalize land value and legal completion Vendors in the public sector decide between developer bids according to set, published scheme criteria and a scoring matrix. The bid assessment criteria often include land value, quality of design, use of modern methods of construction (“MMC”) and socio-economic elements (including the use of local supply chains and training and apprenticeship opportunities). A housebuilder’s reputation and track record of delivery will also be a consideration in awarding large scale regeneration projects. The criteria are usually broken down into specific categories, with scores and weightings attached to each. Therefore, developers are generally aware of how bids will be assessed before they are submitted. For example, Homes England typically assesses scheme bids against two core categories, with 50% of the weighting attributed to the financial offer and 50% attributed to design and social value. Local authorities often more evenly weigh the financial offer, design and social value. We tailor our bids in accordance with the bidding criteria that is released for each project, and we believe that we enjoy a significant advantage against many competing bidders by virtue of our deep understanding of the public procurement process, combined with our experience and track record of delivering notable regeneration and development projects aligning with the social goals of public sector partners. Public bodies generally focus on disposing of brownfield land, which typically has lower land value and can therefore provide a greater potential upside upon development (depending on regeneration costs). This contributes to our relatively low average land cost of approximately 11% of sales. Private sector land is often brought to the market through the owner or a land agent working with the owner. We also identify site opportunities directly through land searches and planning leads. These provide the potential for off-market deals where one-on-one negotiation may take place. In both cases, we conduct an initial assessment to filter out opportunities and compete only for those where we believe we have a high chance of successfully securing the site. We have strong relationships with a small number of national private sector land owners with whom we do repeat business, as well as with a number of land agents. The strength of these relationships, which are based on a mutual track record of delivery and understanding of business drivers, has been instrumental in our ability to secure large scale, capital light deals with private sector vendors. In those cases where we are successful in our bid for a project, we are appointed as the preferred developer and each other party will work towards signing a binding contract while we complete additional due diligence, as described below. _Approval Process and Due Diligence_ Once a potential development opportunity has been identified, we follow a clearly defined due diligence process before we finalize any land purchase. We have a controlled and disciplined internal land acquisition ----- approval process, working within defined control gateways with extensive senior executive review. Our approval process can be divided into three stages: - _Stage 1 — The “Pre-Bid Capital Expenditure” Proposal: This stage occurs prior to the submission of a formal bid or offer for a land parcel, and is intended to establish the financial suitability of an opportunity. The proposal sets out the nature of the opportunity, including scale and scope, and considers the opportunity against our targeted returns for gross margin and ROCE. These target financial returns are then used as benchmarks in stages 2 and 3 of the process (as described below). Our regional teams, led by the regional managing director, complete the “Pre-Bid Capital Expenditure” proposal and present it to the Divisional Chairman for approval. Homes England bids also require approval from the Group Development Director. There is very limited expenditure incurred at this stage of the majority of bids. Approval of a Stage 1 proposal allows the region to perform more detailed planning, design, technical and legal due diligence, as described in Stage 2 below. - _Stage 2 — “Capital Expenditure 1” Proposal: This stage is completed before we enter into a contract to purchase or develop a site. A region commissions a suite of reports to facilitate the formulation of a plan to develop the site. The due diligence undertaken by the region to prepare a “Capital Expenditure 1” proposal includes: (i) _Land — legal reports and reports on title; (ii) _Technical — planning reports, geo-technical (ground) reports, surveys (topographical and environments) and design (architectural and engineering working); (iii) _Sales — market research reports; (iv) _Commercial — cost estimates and validation; and (v) _Construction — health and safety assessments, environmental assessments and programs to facilitate the accurate appraisal of a site. The focus is on identifying the key constraints (including sustainability constrains), risks and mitigation plans for the site, embedding them into the site appraisal and ensuring it still delivers in line with the threshold returns expected for gross margin and ROCE. The costs incurred as part of this stage include the design work by the architects and engineers, geotechnical work, surveys, solicitors fees and other consultants fees. The regional team presents this proposal to our Capex Committee, which comprises our Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Group Production Director and Group Development Director, and which is supported by our legal team. Our Capex Committee reviews the scheme’s risk profile against the anticipated returns and cohesion of the regions plan while assessing the site for approval to proceed to exchange of contract. Approval is also required from the relevant Divisional Chairman and the Divisional Finance Director. Once Stage 2 approval is obtained, our legal team authorizes our panel solicitors to exchange contracts to purchase or develop a site. - _Stage 3 — “Capital Expenditure 2” Proposal: This stage is completed before we commence construction of the site. It reflects the completion of our pre-development due-diligence process, presenting the region’s final proposal to deliver the site, including the financial returns the region is committing to deliver (gross margin and ROCE). It reviews the final position on the land contract conditions, other legal matters, final details of the deal, technical constraints, latent risk and mitigation plan, breakdown of the site start budget build cost, a construction plan, a sales plan confirming values and volume (with updated independent market research) and the final profit output and cash requirements of the proposal. At this stage, planning consent has been granted and most, if not all, of the technical approvals have been obtained. Additionally, we will have already tendered the construction work, providing more cost certainty prior to commencing the development of the site . The regional team present this proposal to our Capex Committee for approval, along with approval from the Divisional Chairman and Divisional Finance Director. ----- Each region within the Group has land, technical, commercial, construction and sales functions to undertake (directly or through consultants) all of the pre-development due-diligence when assessing a site for acquisition. The technical function has overall responsibility for the ground, design, planning, utilities and environmental investigations. The nature, scale and assessed risk of a scheme and land deal, will determine the extent of the investigation undertaken, The work undertaken by consultants in high-risk areas, including geotechnical and groundworks areas, is peer-reviewed by other panel consultants to ensure we have identified the extent of any risk and to ensure that we have robust mitigation plans to protect our financial returns. Examples of the due diligence work that we undertake during our land acquisition approval process include: - full schedule of technical fees to undertake land due diligence; - planning consultation with Local Authorities and planning consultants to establish policy and requirements; - establishing site boundaries and legal ownership; - topography of the site; - conducting site access checks with the land registry and highways authority; - establishing the full requirements to develop the site, including remediation, foundation types, roads and sewers design and drainage connections and requirements; - conducting a full utilities trace which includes gas, water, electrical and communications equipment using ground penetrating radar; and - conducting engineering appraisals such as current drains and site requirements. The technical planning process is detailed and aimed at avoiding and minimizing risk when construction teams are on site. Following technical due diligence, the scheme will be packaged, tendered and costed for submission as described with respect to Stage 3 as described above. _Agreement of Development Framework and Objectives_ With respect to our partnership developments, after being selected as preferred developer we begin to negotiate with our partner an agreement laying out the basic framework of our relationship in each development. Typically, the framework agreement outlines terms applicable for the drawdown of land (sometimes on a phased basis), funding sources, the development timeframe, development milestones, permissible types of development, land price, land payment timing and the overage share, where applicable. We will then refine the objectives of our development with our partners. With Local Authorities, this usually entails neighborhood transformation through mixed-tenure housing construction and sometimes other community facilities. We are able to offer our partners a wide range of housing designs to suit their different needs and can tailor our developments to meet specific goals, such as space standards, tenure, sustainability and affordability. _Project Execution_ Land Acquisition and Construction The ways in which we secure development opportunities may require us to acquire the land being developed (sometimes in phases), or otherwise we may be granted with development rights while the original land owner retains ownership of the site and ultimately transfers completed units directly to the home purchaser. Our developments predominantly utilize the partnership model, although we from time to time acquire land in speculative deals where we believe that we can achieve attractive financial returns by developing the land on our own. These private developments may sometimes shift to partnership arrangements during the course of development, for example, by entering into an agreement with a Registered Provider during the course of development rather than at the outset. ----- Our North West MCI region has a different, but complementary operating model to our other regions. The North West MCI region, which became a part of our business following our acquisition of MCI in 2017, works exclusively with Registered Providers. The North West MCI region sources land in much the same way as our other regions, but agrees to deals whereby a Registered Provider buys the site and also pays us to build homes on the site through build contracts. The Registered Providers pay in advance for the land and progressively for the construction of the homes, resulting in a model with minimal working capital requirements and substantially removing the land and sales risk. Our other regions may also enter into similar arrangements with Registered Providers to deliver all homes on a site to that provider. This typically happens if we have a commercially attractive offer from the Registered Provider and can generate both a requisite gross margin and an attractive ROCE, with the Registered Provider funding both the land and build WIP. Once land is acquired or secured for development, we commence construction, with a focus on realistic build programs, product and process standardization and a focus on quality at each stage of the build. Standardized designs allow us to achieve design and building efficiencies while helping to maintain quality control and simplifying compliance with relevant building requirements. We seek to leverage our scale and procurement capabilities to deliver homes reliably and manage costs appropriately, utilizing rigorous “cost to complete” meetings to maintain control on costs throughout the process. Our construction team is responsible for the delivery of the build process on site to ensure it meets the required safety, quality and program requirements. Sites are appropriately resourced with experienced management teams to ensure the construction phase runs smoothly at each site. Infrastructure work is carefully programmed to optimize ROCE. Quality is a top priority for our business, and all supporting design detailing, workmanship and material specifications have been developed to embody good practice and simplification. These specifications, created in collaboration with all departments and subcontractor forums, are used at all stages of our design, procurement and subcontractor appointment processes. They are embedded in our quality training programs and site inductions and are also used as build quality checks. We have a formal inspection and sign off process that allows us to benchmark our build quality, consisting of an internal quality inspection process and external NHBC key stage inspections. Alongside this, we have produced a series of best practice guides for our site teams to ensure that our homes meet the required standard and comply with our detailed trade specifications. Customer satisfaction is supported by our inspection process, which drives our culture of keeping customers as the key focus of our business. Sustainability is also one of our key focus areas in terms of our approach to construction. Our sustainable construction practices include the utilization of timber-frame construction (accounting for 12% of homes completed in each of the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020), the integration of digital and standardized designs which increase our ability to use offsite manufactured components, improved site efficiency, control of waste, and a modular homes partnership with ilke Homes. See “—Environment and Sustainability” below for further detail. Our core house type range is designed using Building Information Modelling (“BIM”). BIM is used to create house types using digital 3D models which facilitate simpler design, scheduling, cost estimating, programming, construction, sales visualizations, and sharing with partners and consultants (such as architects, engineers, community groups and planners). Certain house types designed and built using BIM further support improved efficiency, waste reduction and collaboration with our third-party designers. Our core house types accounted for 85% of all homes that we delivered in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Additionally, we have been at the forefront in the use of MMC. These methods, which we believe are particularly well suited for high-volume developments, range from whole homes being constructed with factorybuilt volumetric modules to the use of componentized elements in the construction process. In Scotland, timber frames are used exclusively, whereas at other of our sites, they are used selectively where required in the bid brief. Furthermore, we look to integrate off-site manufactured components, such as roof and floor cassettes, which minimize waste and on-site processes within a traditional build. We have a strong understanding of MMC and make use of this in testing new technology and exploring and responding to demand for MMC-built homes on our sites. Standardization We focus on building homes from our standard house type range, with over 75% of our homes completed in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 being standard types. Standardization, and in particular a “Standard House Type Range” contribute to design and building efficiencies and quality control, as well as simplifying compliance with relevant building requirements. We utilize a clearly defined standard house type range that enables our business to benefit from standardization while facilitating flexibility to adapt both internal levels of specification and external elevations. ----- We apply standardized elevation and specification detailing in order to adapt to local planning design guides and regional market expectations. Standardization leads to less risk and greater cost predictability, while different exterior designs provide us with the flexibility to adapt to the local vernacular. The following charts shows the percentage of homes built by us that have used standardized designs during each of the years indicated below: We utilize a number of core standard design types as set out below: - _Open Market Sale Homes: these homes are designed to meet the needs of open market sales customers, and are focused on keeping homes affordable while optimizing land use and profitability. This is the default setting when planning a site, unless partners specify different, larger space standards. - _Design Quality Standards Homes (“DQS”): this is a house type of range aligned to an older design code, still preferred by some Registered Providers, which is larger than the “Open Market Sale Homes” range. These homes are designed for social rent at full occupancy. Homes built in accordance with these standards adhere to enhanced space standards for circulation, internal storage and specific minimum furniture layouts. - _Nationally Designed Space Standards Homes (“NDSS”): this is a house type range aligned to the Nationally Described Space Standards, representing a larger internal space standard, which is available for adoption by Local Authorities. NDSS homes are subject to local plan viability testing and approval by the planning inspectorate. These homes are deemed suitable across all tenures defined by the level of occupancy and were introduced to supersede DQS. - _Mobility Standards Homes: this house type range meets a higher level of accessibility and incorporates adaptability to address future mobility requirements for occupants. These homes typically include wider doors, enlarged circulation spaces and ground floor washrooms which are sized and serviced for future conversion into a ground floor shower room. - _Scottish Homes: these homes are developed to meet the Scottish building regulation and space standards. Our use of standardization provides us with a number of benefits, including the following: - increased efficiency resulting in reduced pre-development time scales and professional fees; - improved cost certainty, construction program certainty and accuracy of land feasibility analysis; - standard details promoting best practices for quality, safety and precise material scheduling, which in turn reduces waste; - standard finishes specification enabling forward demand planning, purchase leveraging and rebate maximization; - improved quality resulting in enhanced customer satisfaction and a reduction in aftercare costs; ----- - strong brand creation and the sharing of marketing assets between sites and regions; - repeat delivery supporting the efficiencies of our supply chain from tender to completion; and - streamlined incorporation of new regulatory standards and considerations into future project designs. Our approach to standardization is developed based on internal feedback for saleability and buildability, customer feedback, commercial viability, and land optimization. Furthermore, trade specifications have been developed to support the delivery of our homes to promote quality and safety in build and occupation. Design and Place-Making We have a proven track record of revitalizing communities through the delivery of high-quality, affordable homes, in well-designed and well-connected neighborhoods and we believe that our focus on design quality and place-making helps drive our success in planning applications and sales performance. We actively contribute to the NHBC Standard Review Group and other industry working groups to help ensure our design, detailing and specification represent best practices and are aligned to future change. Fundamental to our design principals is the creation of a sense of inclusion and community through the delivery of new homes of mixed tenures in attractive, regenerative environments that complement existing local areas and promote health and well-being. We consider the unique characteristics of each site and its surroundings and seek to incorporate and enhance existing natural landscape features and habitat to create a sense of place. Design guides support the use of the house types and elevational styles in delivering the principles of good place making. For example, strong street scenes, gateway access blocks, urban squares, overlooked public realm and vista stoppers can all be efficiently achieved using the standard range of houses. Our design model ultimately creates an attractive living space while maximizing development density. Pursuant to our partnership model, we engage with Local Authorities and other partners at an early stage to create design schemes that are acceptable to our local community and help to shape the social and community infrastructure provided in the area. Early planning and clear design and construction briefs for a regeneration site are particularly important to set a distinctive sense of place and the tone for the partnership with the local community. We also engage with communities at early stage regarding regeneration schemes to engender local support in both a political sense and from the community directly. We believe that our reputation for design and related collaborative working relationships with regeneration stakeholders are important factors that land owners and their advisers consider when considering us as a development partner. We strive to innovate and develop our designs to suit the requirements of all of our customers, including first-time buyers, families, social housing partners, supported housing providers, and the elderly. Our designs include enhanced mobility standards, where required, to support the needs of both able-bodied and disabled people. In certain situations, the design of new homes has been adapted to include special features to support the customer in their daily routine, for example including a lift, a bathroom with a lifting hoist and wider doors to allow for a wheelchair user to be able to easily access all areas of the home and garden. While tailoring designs in order to meet the needs of the customers is a focus of ours, we are also committed to ensuring the homes that we design are commercially optimized with respect to house type profitability, plot profitability and development density. The house type range that we’ve established creates a balanced mix of designs to foster generational and social diversity, support good place making and deliver plotting efficiency. We recognize the key role that commercial and other non-residential buildings and amenities (including neighborhood centers, retail space and schools) contribute to creating vibrant communities. Although our core business does not involve the development of these buildings and amenities, these are typically developed or delivered by third parties, and many of our brownfield developments are anchored around existing commercial and non-residential buildings and amenities. We are committed to building stable, sustainable, diverse and balanced communities, which have at their core an integration of public space, landscaping, biodiversity and sustainable drainage systems. Procurement and Supply We widely employ sub-contractors to build our homes, both for the purposes of efficiency and as part of our commitment to supporting local communities. Because of the fragmented nature of the market in which subcontracting firms operate, we typically work with local small-and medium-sized enterprises instead of national ----- companies. Prior to appointing sub-contractors, we pre-qualify them in line with the PAS 91 standardized questionnaire, through the use of a third party assessment provider. Each sub-contractor is assessed across a range of areas covering, among other items, health and safety, insurances, environmental, quality management, antibribery and corruption, financial standing, modern slavery and equal opportunities. Sub-contractors submit tenders based on the house type and design specifications, at which point we then compare the tender quotes against the appraisal and standard regional costs. Sub-contractors operate under our Keepmoat brand and our health and safety (“H&S”) team provides them with advice and support and monitors compliance with regulatory and best practice standards. We work continuously with sub-contractors to ensure a high-quality of product is delivered at a competitive cost base. We employ a diversified range of sub-contractors, which limits our exposure to individual sub-contractor risk and provides more downside protection and flexibility than a direct labor force. The construction and delivery of homes involves a substantial supply chain. We operate an advanced centralized procurement process to minimize lead time and construction delay, obtain quota guarantees and negotiate fair payment terms. Our materials supply-chain strategy is typically underpinned by annual, Group-wide deals with suppliers with a national, regional or local coverage. This enables us to negotiate better commercial terms through our consolidated volume and enables the utilization of volume-related rebates. We procure all material components centrally and have no sole supply agreements on any key materials. Our supply strategy is delivered through our supply chain director, who is supported by experienced commercial teams employed by us to manage our material supply chain and sub-contractor relationships. Our subcontractors are responsible for providing and installing a proportion of the materials required to build a house. Our suppliers play an essential role in our business, providing the materials and services that we use to build homes. Our business requires substantial amounts of construction materials, including bricks and blocks, in addition to construction and equipment and waste disposal services. We believe that maintaining a high-quality supplier base that is fully aligned to our values is critical to support our growth. Consequently, we seek to maintain a close partner-based relationship with local supply chains. This approach encourages face-to-face engagement with our suppliers to maintain core standards and to continuously improve quality, safety, service, innovation and cost competitiveness. We operate a series of group-wide, long-term strategic frameworks providing preferential commercial terms and service levels at a national and regional level to supply the requisite services, materials, site equipment and business consumables. These frameworks capture both direct purchases of supplies by us and indirect purchases of supplies, which we specify for use, by our contractors, offering significant pricing advantages, while also including important delivery, service and product warranties which helps us maintain and improve our quality and service to our customers. Our “Supply Chain Team” manages over 97 arrangements, which include framework agreements, commercial arrangements and formal price lists. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 88% of our direct spend was channeled through these frameworks. Our supply frameworks align with the Keepmoat Homes Standard Specification and opportunities to work closely with suppliers to assess new products and technologies to support our drive for standardization (for example, using roof and floor cassettes to simplify, speed up, make safer aspects of construction, while reducing the amount of waste). Our supply frameworks also provide customer care and product warranty support to our customer services teams, with many providing value engineering support, free site surveys and scheduling and pricing services. Additionally, our supply frameworks reduce business risk and help ensure a secure supply of our essential materials. We work hard to mitigate price increases and to ensure that our agreements are always competitive and provide the best quality without compromising on standards. Many of our framework agreements include rebate agreements. We maintain regular contact with suppliers and manufacturers to ensure continuity of supply, and negotiate our product allocations by volume. The availability of materials is secured in line with demand and we carefully manage the supply of our key products, including bricks and plasterboard, by working with our regional businesses and our supply chain partners. We engage with our suppliers to keep them informed of key forecasting information, providing them with a rolling build program on a monthly basis, in addition to product specific demand schedules. We also notify our supply chain of any changes to our working practices as appropriate. Subsubsection Text: We have regional sales teams that are supported by a centralized marketing team. These teams collaborate with our partners and local communities throughout a development’s lifecycle, from inception to viability assessment, planning applications and infrastructure planning and then construction and completion. Our central marketing team is responsible for branding, corporate literature, digital support and public relations. It also operates our social media platforms, produces sales and marketing literature, promotes our developments and works towards strengthening our brand identity. As of July 31, 2020, we had two employees in our central marketing team. We utilize a number of typical marketing strategies, including the following: - targeted social media advertising aimed at our core market demographics, using Facebook and Instagram, focusing on key locations identified in our market research; - advertising in suitable local and professional publications, aimed at our core market; - local advertising on bus routes and using digital platforms at stations near sites; - development and house type brochures available in our onsite marketing suites; - informative brochures and advertising explaining the “Shared Equity” and Help to Buy schemes, available in our marketing suite and through online and postal mail shots, as well as print, online and social media; - first-time buyer clinic events; - first-time buyer and drop-in sessions arranged with large local employers and held at their premises and coupled with potential incentives for employees of these organizations; and - an “Easymove” facility to help customers with the sales process of their existing home. Our regional sales teams operate out of our sales outlets, of which we had 56 outlets operating as of July 31, 2021. Regional sales teams are overseen by sales managers, who maintain a detailed understanding of the local real estate market and trends. Members of our sales teams are generally present at our active sales outlets and guide buyers through the home buying process. Our sales outlets are typically open five days per week, with sites in certain high demand areas being open seven days per week. We directly recruit, employ and train our sales ----- executives to deliver their sales services to our specific target customer demographics. As of July 31, 2021, we had 145 employees in our regional sales teams. Our sales teams are supported by our digital sales capabilities, which have taken on increased importance in recent years. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, we opened eight digital sales offices. We also secured 1,254 online reservations through our digital sales offices and our “Reserve Online” tool in the same financial year, which was equivalent to approximately 50% of our completions in the period. The typical process and timeframe for a house sale is as follows: - _Site visits (week 0): at this stage, the customer typically undertakes multiple visits to the site to review the development and the available housing choices; - _Preliminary credit assessment (weeks 1-4): at this stage, the customer has narrowed down his or her interest. Our sales team refers the customer to an independent financial advisor to make a preliminary credit assessment and evaluate mortgage eligibility; - _Reservation (week 4): the customer reserves the property and pays a nominal fee; - _Exchange contracts (weeks 12-14): at this stage, the customer typically instructs a solicitor to undertake the conveyancing work, progresses the mortgage application and enters into a contract for the purchase; and - _Legal completion (week 24-26): the customer completes the purchase and moves in, after the house is built and inspected for quality. We pursue a sales strategy that blends the potential for margin enhancement through open-market sales with the certainty, risk mitigation and cash generation of selling to Registered Providers. In the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 74% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site) and 26% to Registered Providers as part of the Section 106 affordable housing obligations agreed in connection with the planning consents required for our sites or as otherwise agreed with Registered Providers at the outset of development. In comparison, in the financial year ended October 31, 2019, we sold 78% of our plots in the open market and 22% to Registered Providers. Open market sales are delivered primarily through our sales team, who are present at each site. We typically design a sales area, including a sales office and show homes, to present a shop-window of how the site will look once developed. We look to open these sales areas as early as possible in the development of our sites to allow customers to experience what they may eventually purchase. Conversely, sales to Registered Providers are agreed at the time of the planning process, pursuant to our Section 106 obligations, in accordance with an authority’s affordable-housing policy. Through our strong relationship with national and local Registered Providers we are able to agree commercially-driven elective sales to Registered Providers subsequent to the initial planning stage, which serves an important tool in maintaining sales flexibility throughout the life of the site. These sales are often only at a small discount to open market prices as they benefit from grants or other funding (such as Affordable Homes Programme funding). Although a relatively small proportion of our business, we treat private rental sector (“PRS”) sales as complementary to our open-market and Registered Provider sales. PRS sales are location sensitive as they only work on commercially acceptable terms in areas with strong rental demand and rental values. We discuss PRS sales with our partners and seek to devise sales strategies on a site-by-site basis. We completed sales for a total of 2,774 homes, 2,460 homes and 4,035 homes in the nine months ended July 31, 2021, the financial year ended October 31, 2020 and the financial year ended October 31, 2019, respectively. As of July 31, 2021, our forward order book, which represents (i) plots that are contracted for but homes have yet to be completed on the lot and (ii) plot reservations for which contracts have yet to be exchanged, was approximately £503.2 million, comprising of 3,151 plots. As of September 19, 2021, we had reserved, exchanged or legally completed almost all of our planned sales for the financial year ending October 31, 2021. Furthermore, as of September 19, 2021, we had secured ----- approximately 40% of our planned sales for the year ended October 31, 2022, 85% of our planned sales for the three months ended January 31, 2022 and 45% of our planned sales for the three months ended April 30, 2022..

Subsubsection Text: Once a customer has reserved a property, identified the particular home they want and paid a reservation fee, they still have the option to cancel their reservation and receive a refund if they choose to withdraw from the sale. The customer may cancel at any time before the exchange of contracts, and if they have purchased through the Help to Buy scheme and have cancelled within ten calendar days of the reservation, they will be entitled to a full refund of their reservation fee. Otherwise, the customer will be refunded the reservation fee less administrative costs of £125. Once contracts have been exchanged, the customer may only serve notice to cancel the sale if (i) we have not served the completion notice (confirming the date on which completion will take place) before the long stop date specified in the sale contract; or (ii) we have made substantial changes to the property that were not agreed in advance by the customer. If the purchaser does not serve notice to cancel where the property is not ready and the completion notice has not been served by the relevant long stop date, then we may continue to build the property, concluding as soon as reasonably practicable, and the customer must complete the purchase. If the customer fails to complete the purchase on the completion date (once such date has been set), we may provide ten days’ notice to complete the purchase, following which we will have the right to rescind the contract if the customer still fails to complete the purchase. If we are to exercise our right of rescission, we may retain the deposit and any accrued interest, claim damages if applicable and re-sell the property. If we fail to complete our performance under the contract before expiry of the notice, then the customer has the right to rescind the contract and to the return of their deposit.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have a diverse customer base, and in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, 75% of our sales were on the open market (which includes sales to private customers as well as elective sales to Registered Providers that are agreed during the development of a site) and 25% to Registered Providers as part of the Section 106 affordable housing obligations agreed in connection with the planning consents required for our sites or as otherwise agreed with Registered Providers at the outset of development. First-time buyers are one of our key demographics, representing 76% of our private sales in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. First-time buyers with the benefit of financial support schemes from the Government have historically proven to provide resilient structural demand and constitute a deep and relatively predictable market. First-time buyers are typically “need to buy” customers, in that they are experiencing life events such as moving out from parental homes or getting married. We serve a young and diverse customer group, with 73% of private sale customers aged 35 or younger (based on statistics from a survey of 1,053 customers in the financial year ended October 31, 2020). We generally do not have large exposure to customers in any particular occupation, implying a well-diversified customer economic exposure. In terms of the way that our customers finance their purchases, based on statistics from the same survey in the financial year ended October 31, 2020, approximately 68% of our private sale customers utilized the Help to Buy scheme, 30% were unassisted and 1% utilized the Affordable Homes Programme. Our strategy is not targeted at the relatively more discretionary and cyclical “home-mover” segment, but instead is focused on the more affordable end of the market. As a result, our ASP is lower than the industry average in each of the regions in which we operate: - Average new build sales value is derived from the UK House Price Index (“UKHPI”) Bulletin December 2020 (a weighted average for November 2019 – October 2020). Keepmoat Private Values are based on regional sales data. Keepmoat “South” region has been compared to the UKHPI “South East” region as the most applicable comparator based on locations served. ----- A profile of our customers in the financial year ended October 31, 2020 is set forth below:

Subsubsection Text: Up to 25 10.0% 26 - 30 41.0% 31 - 35 22.0% 36 - 40 10.0% 41 - 65 15.0% 65+ 2.0% Total** 100.00% Source: Keepmoat survey of 1,053 customers in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Delivering high-quality new homes and delighting our customers is our top priority. As a business, we are committed to providing our customers with superior levels of service, from providing comprehensive information and guidance on customers’ new homes to dealing with issues and queries quickly and efficiently. As a testament to our focus on customer service, in 2021, we increased our NHBC customer satisfaction score to 92.6%, achieving 5-Star Homebuilder status across our business. Our NHBC customer satisfaction score was a 5.7% increase on the results from the prior year, while our 5-Star Homebuilder status has improved from a 4-Star status in 2020 and a 3-Star status in 2019. We review our processes on an ongoing basis and continually strive to introduce further improvements to allow us to deliver greater levels of customer service. We include all regional management teams in this process to ensure improvements are delivered consistently across the entire business. Our bespoke quality inspection process has enabled us to deliver greater and more consistent levels of quality control in the homes that we build. We are continuing to develop our quality inspection process to introduce even more rigor to processes to make sure we continue to deliver high-quality homes for our customers. In addition to the changes to our quality inspection process, we have also developed a range of training programs for our people, which are regularly delivered to ensure that they understand the importance that we place on delighting our customers. We maintain close contact with our customers throughout their journey, from their initial enquiry, during the exciting process of purchasing their new homes and after they move in, to ensure they consistently receive a high level of service. We also provide other innovative schemes to assist our customers in purchasing, designing and moving into their new homes: - _Home Options: this service allows customers to personalize their home to fit their individual style preferences. Customers can choose colors, designs, appliances and fittings to be included in their home, including in the kitchen, bathrooms, interiors and gardens. We offer our customers pre-designed standard packs and also allow our customers to select “additional extras” to customize their house. - _Easy Move: this service assists customers in the process of selling their current homes by arranging for valuations, paying for agents’ fees and managing the entire process on their behalf.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to our H&S performance and focus strongly on managing our risk throughout all phases of a development, with particular emphasis on site risks. We have implemented clear policies, created best practice guides and developed specific, robust performance standards for high-risk activities, such as timber frame construction, carrying out work at heights, managing plant and pedestrian interface and avoiding damaging underground services when excavating. ----- Our H&S performance is overseen by our Executive Health and Safety Standards (“HSS”) committee, which is comprised of our CEO, our executive and our HSS Director. The HSS committee’s terms of reference include determination of our strategic objectives and improvement initiatives, H&S policy, performance monitoring, assurance (internal and external audit) and maintenance of ISO 9001, 14001 and 45001 certification. We received a Gold Award from the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (“RoSPA”) in 2020. The criteria for the award included, among other items, accreditation to ISO standards, levels of compliance with guidelines for high-risk activities and objective H&S performance, including accident rates. The Gold Award is the achievement awarded by RoSPA and is awarded to companies that can demonstrate: - excellent occupational health and safety management systems evidenced by strong third party audit results and company culture demonstrated by answers to key performance questions; - a rigorous approach to occupational health; - high levels of compliance with control measures (evidenced by active monitoring of performance) for principal risks; - low/reducing rates of error, harm (accidents and work related ill health) and loss (e.g. accident and ill health costs); - no fatal or major injuries due to employer negligence; and - no significant enforcement issues such as notices and/or prosecutions. In line with Home Builders Federation reporting requirements, our annual injury incident rate in June 2021 was 205 per 100,000 employed. Following a recent Government announcement, in which the Government indicated that it was committed to funding and supporting the removal of unsafe cladding on high-rise buildings, we have conducted a desktop review and did not identify the need for any remedial works associated with the removal of combustible cladding in relation to multi-occupancy residential structures in our legacy development portfolio. In support of industry initiatives to improve fire safety moving forwards, we have become a registered signatory to the Building A Safer Charter Declaration of Commitment, which is designed to drive a culture of change and action to improve building safety, by making improvements to current practice and behaviors. We actively contribute to the NHBC Standards Review Group and other industry working groups, to help ensure that our design, detailing and specification represent best practice and are aligned to future change. Our H&S management system and key processes such as the pre-qualification of sub-contractors, inductions, training, incident recording and reporting are managed through contemporary platforms and technology. This has also proved important in the fight against COVID-19, preventing contact between people and reducing the risk of infection transfer.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our operations are also subject to national and local laws and regulations relating to the management, use, storage, disposal, emission, and remediation of, and exposure to, hazardous and non-hazardous substances, materials and wastes. We have compliance programs and monitoring projects to help ensure that we are in substantial compliance with applicable environmental laws, including internal and external compliance audits, national quality assurance certification audits (both centrally and regionally), monthly inspection of all development sites by our H&S team and annual construction compliance audits of all sites by our H&S team. We also engage a third party expert adviser (Waterman EHS) to maintain an environmental legal register for us, identifying compliance requirements and assisting us in identifying and developing actions needed to comply with forthcoming environmental legislation. Our priority areas of focus are carbon & energy, waste & resource efficiency, remediation (with brownfield development being a core part of our business model), pollution & water and ecology & biodiversity. We regularly review our objectives for each of these areas, driving continual improvements across our business. We also provide regular environmental training for our staff. Our environmental management system is certified to ISO 14001:2015. In July 2020, following stakeholder consultation, we published our Sustainability Strategy in which we identified our material issues and aligned our strategy to eight United Nations SDGs. Through our Sustainability Strategy, we are committed to ----- minimizing our impact on the environment and biodiversity. Additionally, in working with Wildscapes, which is a wildlife trust consultancy, we are looking to develop methodologies to support the delivery of a net gain in biodiversity for future developments. The protection of ecological features is essential to our business, as is the inclusion of sustainable drainage solutions and green infrastructure strategies, supported by ecological assessments, to enhance and future proof the sustainability and attractiveness of our developments. We also strive to address the future impacts of climate change such as extreme weather events and overheating. Another key component of our sustainability drive is the employment of advanced techniques and the minimization of our environmental impact in our design and build processes. For instance, we have recently been focusing on timber-frame construction, which, in addition to having a faster return on capital outlay, is also a sustainable form of construction. We were an early adopter of sustainable building information modelling to maximize development efficiency and align design to off-site manufacture and on-site assembly techniques. Additional actions and practices that we have employed include the use of standardized designs to improve site efficiency and control waste, modular homes provided by ilke Homes aimed at contributing toward a high-quality, low-carbon and precision-engineered housing solution and participation in Gorton low carbon homes trials. Approximately 96% of our construction waste was diverted from landfills in the financial year ended October 31, 2020. Since May 2021, we have transitioned to 100% of electricity from renewable sources. Our portfolio has been developed to meet the needs of our partners in the delivery of enhanced NDSS space standards and mobility standards for a mix of tenure. Furthermore, given that digital technology is considered to be one of the strands to achieving a healthier life and an essential element for enabling the flexibility for home working, future developments will benefit from broadband fiber connectivity with speeds of one gigabit. Through continued customer focus, we strive to innovate and develop our design solutions to meet the needs of customers and partners with regard to flexible living, low/zero carbon performance and reduced running costs to address fuel poverty.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to risks particular to all our business activities and the environment in which we operate. Therefore, risk management is fundamental to our business and plays a central role in all of our activities, from identification and assessment of contract or development opportunities to bidding and delivery of contracts or developments. Our Board of Directors is primarily responsible for approving the risk parameters, credit policies and our overall risk capacity. The Board of Directors oversees our risk management activities and periodically reviews our risk management policies and procedures relating to strategic, operational and financial risks.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our core IT applications are a combination of industry standard off-the-shelf applications, software as a service applications and innovative bespoke digital products. We currently use Construction Industry Solutions as our main enterprise resource planning software (“ERP”), and have recently committed to the adoption of DXC Home Builder One, a homebuilder ERP solution powered by Microsoft Dynamics 365. We have also recently completed our implementation of Anaplan, the market leading financial planning and analysis system which underpins key finance activities throughout the Group. We believe this platform will give us best in class systems to take our business forward. To lead our team in this period of significant transformation, we recently appointed Myles Gibbins to the role of IT & Digital Director. Myles brings over 20 years’ experience in the home building industry and possess exceptional knowledge and experience of delivering similar business transformation projects. Over the past several years, we have invested significantly in digital technologies in order to re-engineer the customer journey and make the process of buying a new home easier and more closely aligned to the expectations of our young customer demographic. This investment ensured that we were able to sell homes through our reserve online tool while brick-and-mortar sales offices were closed during COVID-19 related lockdown periods. Recent enhancements to our digital technologies include a new appointment booking system, an online “House Configurator” to allow new customers to add options and upgrade their new homes and an online payment tool to enable all payments to be made through our website. In particular, the addition of the booking tool has resulted in additional benefits to our business, including improved visibility on footfall to sites, ----- which has in turn enabled us to optimize our staffing levels accordingly. Further enhancements are now in development, including additional features such as identity checks and anti-money laundering checks. We make use of Business Intelligence and Dashboards to support our internal monitoring and reporting and strategic decision making. Additionally, our core desktop and server infrastructure has been aligned such that each relies on Microsoft, and in particular, Microsoft Office 365 and Microsoft Azure. The alignment of these systems promotes certain efficiencies and allows for the quick restoration of data and services in the event of any disruption.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our employees focus on project development, coordination and delivery, with actual construction subcontracted to third parties. As of October 31, 2021, we had an average tenure per employee of approximately 4.5 years. Together with our generally stable core management team, our employees and management have supported us in maintaining long-standing regional relationships with our partners. Our employees are an important component of our strong reputation and record of community engagement, both of which differentiate our offering from our peers. We have focused significant resources in developing the skills of our employees through in-house and bespoke training and development programmers. We have made substantial investments in training our employees and have been accredited by the Investors in People Community Interest Company as “Investors in People” since 2014. Additional e-learning modules designed to cover topics such as personal resilience, personal leadership, building relationship as well as modules on delighting customers feature in the training programs for all customerfacing employees. As of July 31, 2021, approximately 6% of our employees were trainees, apprentices or graduates, with all of our apprenticeships complying with the National Apprenticeship Council’s scheme. We also run leadership programs for our management, and are aligned with the Construction Industry Training Board. In May 2021, we introduced a new graduate program and we are further looking to launch a “Contracts Manager and Site Manager Development Programme” to support high performing teams. We maintain a good balance of internal promotion and external recruitment in order to add to our talent pool. We do not recognize or negotiate with any employee or sub-contractor unions. We contribute to the KPP, which is an occupational defined contribution pension scheme whose assets are held in independently administered funds. Separately, the Company has entered into the Underpin with less than 15 members of the KPP, through an unfunded contractual promise falling outside the scope of pension legislation. The Underpin, should it be applicable, is in addition to the benefits payable under the KPP. The obligations arising under the Underpin have been calculated by a qualified independent actuary and accounted for as a long-term employee benefit.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We lease our corporate headquarters and registered office located in Doncaster, England. We further lease nine properties (excluding properties being developed or being held for development) which are used as office-spaces. ----- We generally seek to enter into real-property lease agreements with a maximum lease term of five years, with a tenant’s break-clause at three years. The fees payable under the majority of our leases escalate periodically at a pre-agreed fixed percentage.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we maintain insurance policies that reflect the risk profile of our business and are consistent with best industry practices in terms of limitation of indemnity and scope of coverage. Our management, as advised by our insurance broker, considers our coverage to be sufficient in amount and scope. We maintain insurance policies covering a range of risks including those related to physical damage to, and loss of, equipment and property and injury to employees and third parties, as well as claims and general liabilities that may arise through the course of normal business operations as well as acts of terrorism. Our buildings (for which we are responsible) and property, including WIP, are covered by “all risks” property damage insurance, which includes physical loss, destruction or damage to the property, unless otherwise excluded, as well as subsidence and theft. We renew our insurance policies annually. Our homes come with either a ten-year NHBC comprehensive warranty and insurance policy or a tenyear LABC insurance policy for the benefit of the customer covering structural defects, improper environmental remediation and waterproofing. In both cases, we pay the premiums for these policies. We also maintain insurance policies for employees, with respect to work-related injuries, insurance for all of our vehicles, directors’ and officers’ liability insurance, pension trustee liability insurance and professional indemnity insurance.

Subsection Title: MANAGEMENT Board of Directors of the Company
Subsubsection Text: The Company, Maison BidCo Limited, was incorporated as a private limited company under the laws of England and Wales on July 23, 2021, with company number 13528295. The registered address of the Company is c/o Alter Domus (UK) Limited, 18 St Swithin’s Lane, London, EC4N 8AD, United Kingdom. The board of directors of the Company (the “Board”) determines the Group’s business activities; strategy; risk management policies; commencement of any new business activities that differ from existing business activities; expansion and diversification into new geographies; acquisitions, divestments, disposals and other transactions; business combinations; significant financial decisions; capital structure and dividend policy; termination or execution of contracts and other transactions outside delegated limits; conclusion, amendment or termination of partnerships and joint ventures; issuance of shares and options; material changes to accounting policies or practices; internal and external communications; commencement, defense or settlement of any material litigation; Board committees; and the Board structure, composition and succession. Set forth below is a brief biography of each member of the Board. _Tim Beale, Chief Executive Officer_ Tim Beale became Chief Executive Officer of the Group in February 2019, having been Chief Operating Officer and Deputy Chief Executive since February 2018 and is expected to join the Board following the consummation of the Transactions. Mr. Beale joined Keepmoat Homes in May 2017, having previously worked at Crest Nicholson PLC where he had spent 14 years, including most recently as a member the executive board and chairman of their South West, Chiltern and Southern divisions. Mr. Beale also served as Managing Director of the South West division and the Midlands division at Crest Nicholson PLC. A Chartered Town Planner, he was a member of the senior management team that led the successful flotation of Crest Nicholson back on the public markets in 2013. He holds a BA(Hons) in Urban Studies from Sheffield University and a post graduate diploma in Town Planning from Sheffield University. Mark Priest,_ Chief Financial Officer Mark Priest was appointed Chief Financial Officer of Keepmoat Homes in October 2017, having joined as Deputy Chief Financial Officer in December 2016 and is expected to join the Board following the consummation of the Transactions. Previously he was Global Director of Corporate Finance at Premier Farnell, a listed high service distributor of technology products and solutions. Prior to joining Premier Farnell, he held roles at Aviva and Wolseley plc. He is a Chartered Accountant, qualifying with PwC, with over 20 years wide-ranging senior financial experience, at both corporate and divisional level, within major listed businesses. Mr. Priest holds a Ph.D. in Pure Mathematics from the University of Leeds. Paul Golding,_ Director Paul Golding joined the Board as a Director in July 2021. Mr. Golding is also a partner and a member of the Investment Committee at Aermont. Prior to joining Aermont, Mr. Golding was Head of Real Estate Asset Strategies at Norges Bank Investment Management (NBIM), the group which manages the Norwegian Global Pension Fund, and prior to that, Mr. Golding worked at Merrill Lynch, where he was Head of Real Estate Investment Banking in Europe and the Middle East. Mr. Golding graduated from the London Business School with a Masters in Finance. ----- Alison Trewartha,_ Director Alison Trewartha will join the Board as a Director in following the consummation of the Transactions. Ms. Trewartha is also a partner and a member of the Investment Committee at Aermont. Prior to joining Aermont, she was an associate in mergers & acquisitions at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom in London and, prior to that, she was an associate at Deacons (now Norton Rose Fulbright) in Melbourne, Australia. Ms. Trewartha graduated from Monash University with a Bachelor of Laws with honors and Bachelor of Business Management. Kevin Pierre,_ Director Kevin Pierre joined the Board as Director in July 2021. Mr. Pierre is also a principal on the acquisitions and asset management team of Aermont, focusing on Pan-European investment activities. Prior to joining the Company, Mr. Pierre was an analyst at AREA Property Partners in Paris. Mr. Pierre graduated from HEC Paris with a Master of Science in Management. Subsubsection Text: The Company’s senior managers, whom the Board believe are relevant to establishing that the Company has the appropriate expertise and experience for the management of the Company’s business (the “Senior

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Management”), as of the date of this Offering Memorandum is comprised as follows: Name** **Age** **Position
Subsubsection Text: Tim Beale ............................................... 44 Chief Executive Officer Mark Priest ............................................. 54 Chief Financial Officer Ian Hoad ................................................. 41 Divisional Chairman – North Andrew Mason ....................................... 40 Divisional Chairman – South Tim Wray ............................................... 51 Group Development Director Tom Dwyer ............................................ 58 Group Production Director Debbie Waddington................................ 58 Group Human Resources Director Lyn Charters ........................................... 51 General Counsel & Company Secretary Set forth below is a brief biography of each member of the Senior Management. _Tim Beale, Chief Executive Officer_ For biographical details of Mr. Beale, see the description under “—Board of Directors of the Company.” Mark Priest,_ Chief Financial Officer For biographical details of Mr. Priest, see the description under “—Board of Directors of the Company.” Ian Hoad,_ Divisional Chairman – North Ian Hoad joined the Group in 2009 and moved from the Midlands region to Yorkshire in 2010. With a strong track record in the housing industry working at a senior level, he has served as Operations Director and then the Regional Managing Director of the Group’s Yorkshire One region. Mr. Hoad was appointed as Divisional Chairman in May 2019. He has previously worked as Development Director at Bovis Homes Limited and resigned in December 2008. Andrew Mason,_ Divisional Chairman – South Andrew Mason was appointed as Divisional Chairman in February 2018 having previously set up and led the East Midlands region as Regional Managing Director. Mr. Mason joined the Group in 2012 as Financial Controller in the Midlands business before rising to Regional Finance Director and then Operations Director. He is a Chartered Accountant having qualified with Grant Thornton before undertaking financial analyst and management roles for Eon UK. He holds an Accountancy & Finance Management degree from the Loughborough University. _Tim Wray, Group Development Director_ Tim Wray joined Keepmoat Homes Limited in 1996 as management accountant. Over a long spanning career with the Group, he has setup and led the North West region as Regional Managing Director, before ----- becoming the Financial Director of Keepmoat Homes in 2008. Mr. Wray was appointed as Group Development Director in 2018. He has a degree in Accountancy and Management Control from Sheffield Hallam University. _Tom Dwyer, Group Production Director_ Tom Dwyer joined Keepmoat Homes in 2019 as Production Director. Prior to joining the Group, he worked at Crest Nicholson for almost 14 years, starting as Production Director for the Midlands and South West regional businesses before becoming Managing Director of the South West business. Prior to Crest Nicholson, he served as Construction Director at Redrow West Midlands for five years, having joined them from Barratt where he headed up the construction team in the South Midlands region. Mr. Dwyer is a Chartered Builder and Fellow of the Chartered Institute of Building. _Debbie Waddington, Group Human Resources Director_ Debbie Wray became the Group Human Resources Director in May 2017, having joined the Group as the Human Resources Reward Director in 2015. She has spent the majority of her career within major listed businesses including BT, HBOS, Aviva and Lloyds Bank. Having started her career in various operational roles progressing to a senior level, she then moved into human resources and now has 20 years of wide-ranging, senior level HR experience both corporately and regionally. Lyn Charters,_ General Counsel & Company Secretary Lyn Charters joined the Group in 2013 and was appointed General Counsel and Company Secretary in 2017. Ms. Charters qualified as a solicitor in 2004 into the real estate team at Squire Sanders and had a previous career in engineering as a Chartered Civil Engineer for 9 years. She has a Bachelor of Engineering with honors from the University of Leeds and a post-graduate Diploma in Law and Legal Practice from the College of Law (now University of Law).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Company historically has offered a long-term incentive plan to incentivize certain members of management. Following the Acquisition, this long-term incentive plan will be discontinued.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Under an incentive package that will be granted in connection with the Acquisition, on the Completion Date certain members of senior management and certain other key employees of the Group will subscribe for ordinary shares, loan notes and preference shares in Holdco (the “Management Incentive Plan”). A proportion of the senior management’s transaction proceeds following the acquisition of the Target will be settled and subsequently reinvested by management in connection with this subscription. It is anticipated that the ordinary shares will comprise of A ordinary shares (representing the “sweet equity”) and B ordinary shares (representing the “institutional strip,” together with the preference shares and loan notes,). The ordinary A shares will be entitled to distribution amounts calculated on the basis of the total acquisition price and the return on investment generated by an exit. The agreements will include standard good-leaver and bad-leaver provisions in the case of exiting senior management or other employees participating in the plan. The Management Incentive Plan is not entirely allocated and is open to subscription by additional members of management or certain employees who may join the Group in the future. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of the results of operations and financial condition of the Group based on the audited consolidated financial statements of the KM Group and its subsidiaries as of and for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020, and the unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements as of and for the nine months ended July 31, 2020 and 2021, in each case, prepared in accordance with IFRS. From April 1, 2018, the KM Group prepared its audited consolidated financial statements based on an October 31 fiscal year end. Previously, the KM Group audited consolidated financial statements were prepared based upon a March 31 fiscal year end. As such, the KM Group prepared audited consolidated financial statements for the fiscal year end March 31, 2018 and the seven months ended October 31, 2018, each of which are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. However, a discussion of these results are not included in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” given that they are not directly comparable to the audited consolidated financial statements of the KM Group for the financial years ended October 31, 2019 and 2020. Except as the context otherwise indicates, when discussing historical results of operations in this “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” the “Group,” “KM Group,” “we,” “our” and other similar terms are generally used to refer to the business of the Keystone Midco Limited and its subsidiaries. You should read this discussion in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of the KM Group and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in the Offering Memorandum. A summary of the critical accounting estimates that have been applied to the KM Group’s consolidated financial statements is set forth below in “—Critical Accounting Estimates.” You should also review the information in the sections “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Selected Historical Financial Data.” This discussion also includes forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties which could cause actual events or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. For a discussion of risks and uncertainties facing us as a result of various factors, see “Risk Factors.”_

The Issuer is a direct wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company. The Company will be indirectly owned by funds and co-investment vehicles advised by Aermont together with certain management shareholders. Aermont is an independent asset management group focused on real estate and real estate related investment activities. Aermont was established in 2007 (previously, under a different name) and is currently comprised of a team of 23 investment professionals (including five partners) who have significant relevant experience, such as with real estate asset-rich operating companies and platforms. Aermont’s strategy is centered on long-term value creation through an operator-oriented approach, focusing on prime assets or projects at top locations in major cities in the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Spain and other western European countries, as well as operating businesses and platforms with growth potential. Since 2007, the Aermont funds have received equity commitments of around €6 billion in aggregate. -----

We are engaged in certain minority investments and participations in joint ventures which, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we regard to be related party transactions. These include our participation in Durham Villages Regeneration Limited, Sheffield Housing Company Limited, New Tyne West Development Company LLP and Ilke Homes Holdings Limited.
